Students will gain this experience by 1) completing problem sets to be embedded in lecture to prepare for class facilitation, 2) providing assistance to students during small group work in lecture, 3) exploring current literature in chemical education research.  This course is recommended for all Chemistry and Chemistry-related students since it improves their depth of knowledge of chemistry while enhancing their communication skills. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 05301 - Chemistry in the Environment Credits: 3 This course relates the fundamentals of chemistry learned in the prerequisite course to the natural processes found in nature.  It also examines how chemistry is related to environmental concerns in our modern world.  The course is not designed for majors in science and engineering. Prerequisite Courses: MATH 03305 with a minimum grade of D- or ENST 94101 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 06100 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry
CHEM 05310 - Independent Study-Chemistry Credits: 1 to 6 Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 05311 - Professional Development III Credits: 1 This course is the third in a sequence of three courses. It should be taken during the junior year. This course will cover preparation for entering the workforce and graduate programs. Graduation planning, career planning, resume preparation, mock interviews and other opportunities will be discussed. Ethics in science and employment will also be discussed. Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 05350 - Forensic Chemistry Credits: 4 This course considers the application of physical and chemical methods to the identification and analysis of the physical evidence associated with a crime. The course emphasizes those areas of chemistry and to a lesser extent physics, biology and geology useful for determining the evidential value of crime scene and related evidence. The laboratory experience emphasizes the application of physical and chemical analytical procedures to the examination of materials that would likely be considered evidence in a crime. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 05430 - Advanced Topics in Chemistry Credits: 3 This course covers special topics in individual areas of chemistry. Specific prerequisites are determined by the nature of the course when it is announced. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 07201 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 05435 - Cooperative Experience in Chemistry Credits: 3 The goal of this course is to provide the student with the opportunity to participate in a research/development experience in a non-academic setting. The course may be taken as an advanced elective by students with Junior or Senior status for a maximum of 3 s.h. credit. It may be elected to fulfill the research requirement of the BS in Chemistry major, It can be taken more than once. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 05440 - Research I Credits: 3 This course provides individual laboratory investigation of a topic outside the scope of existing courses; laboratory and conferences are required. The results of investigation will be presented in a written and oral report. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 05441 - Research II Credits: 3 This course is a continuation of CHEM05.440. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 05440 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 05450 - Seminar I Credits: 1 In this course students give oral reports on topics chosen from the current chemical literature. Students must attend local professional meetings. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 07348 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 08400 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 05500 - Teaching Pedagogy in Chemistry Instruction Credits: 3 This graduate level course focuses on pedagogy as it applies to teaching in a general chemistry and organic chemistry lab.  Topics covered in this course will include various pedagogical approaches and strategies for teaching both lab concepts and technical skills for general and organic chemistry. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry
CHEM 05501 - Principles of Chemistry Credits: 3 Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 05502 - Clinical Laboratory Science Seminar Credits: 1 to 3 This graduate course serves as a capstone course in clinical laboratory science. Students will review, discuss and present on core and emerging topics relating to clinical laboratory science. Course Attributes: CLIN, GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Biological & Biomedical Sciences

CourseTitle: Introduction to Cannabis - A Chemistry Perspective
Description: CHEM 05504 - Introduction to Cannabis - A Chemistry Perspective Credits: 3 This graduate course is an introduction to various chemistry aspects of cannabis and related compounds. Topics discussed in this course include isolation of cannabis from natural sources, post-processing, separation, purification, and formulation, all of which play a key role in large-scale preparation of cannabis products.  While the focus will be on chemistry, this course is designed for anyone who aspires to be a part of this growing industry or is interested in expanding their knowledge in the field. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 05530 - Special Topics in Chemistry Credits: 3 Selected topics in individual areas of chemistry (analytical, organic, inorganic or physical). Consent of the instructor is necessary. Prerequisites are determined by the nature of the topic. The requirements of this course include a graduate laboratory project and/or research paper. This course may not be offered annually. Course Attributes: CAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry
CHEM 05544 - Intro to Research Credits: 3 Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 05550 - Advanced Seminar Credits: 1 Oral presentation of scientific studies and data at the graduate level. The talks are accompanied by 35 mm slides prepared by the student. Attendance at South Jersey American Chemical Society meetings is required. This course may not be offered annually. Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 06100 - Chemistry I Credits: 4 This course presents the basic principles involved in the study of chemistry. It emphasizes modern theories and laws used in the understanding of the structures and reactions of the elements and compounds and also includes gas laws, stoichiometry, and solution theory. Prerequisite Courses: CHPL with a minimum score of 51 or CHEM 05100 with a minimum grade of C- Corequisite Courses: CHEM L6100 Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, GNED, LAB, SCIL, SM, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 06101 - Chemistry II Credits: 4 This course is a continuation of CHEM06.100. It covers these topics: equilibria, including acids and bases, complexes, and sparingly soluble compounds, thermodynamics, kinetics, electrochemistry, and solution theory. Descriptive inorganic chemistry is also covered. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 06100 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 06105 with a minimum grade of D- Corequisite Courses: CHEM L6101 Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, GNED, LAB, SM, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CourseTitle: Advanced College Chemistry I (Lecture and Lab)
Description: CHEM 06105 - Advanced College Chemistry I (Lecture and Lab) Credits: 4 This course is an introductory chemistry course for students in chemistry and biochemistry.  The content includes theories and laws used in the understanding of the structures and reactions of elements and compounds, atomic structure, stoichiometry, gas laws, states of matter, and solution theory.  Illustrative examples focusing on the research interests of the Department will be used to introduce topics.  Introduction to Advanced laboratory methods will also be covered.  It is not recommended for those who do not have a declared science or engineering major. Prerequisite Courses: AP25 with a minimum score of 3 or CHEM 05100 with a minimum grade of C- Course Attributes: CAT, GNED, LAB, SM, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CourseTitle: Advanced College Chemistry II (Lecture and Lab)
Description: CHEM 06106 - Advanced College Chemistry II (Lecture and Lab) Credits: 4 This course is a continuation of Advanced College Chemistry I. Topics include thermodynamics, chemical kinetics, chemical equilibrium, acid base chemistry, precipitation reactions, redox reactions, and electrochemistry. Illustrated examples focusing on the research interests of the Department will be used to introduce topics. Advanced laboratory methods will also be covered. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 06105 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, GNED, LAB, SM, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 06300 - Advanced Inorganic Chemistry Credits: 4 This course studies concepts and models of inorganic chemistry. It explains molecular geometries and other physical and chemical properties on the basis of the several chemical bonding theories and with reference to the periodic table. Students study both main group and transition element chemistries. The laboratory component emphasizes the synthesis and characterization of inorganic compounds. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 08400 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 06301 - Inorganic Chemistry Credits: 3 This course covers the basic concepts and models of inorganic chemistry.  The course encompasses the study of various elements in the periodic table along with their components.  Students study the descriptive chemistry of both main group and d-block transition elements. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 07201 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07202 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry
CHEM 06302 - General Chemistry Credits: 4 Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 06400 - Advanced Inorganic Chemistry Lecture Credits: 3 This course covers concepts and models of inorganic chemistry.  It encompasses molecular geometries and other physical and chemical properties on the basis of the several chemical bonding theories and with reference to the periodic table.  Students study the chemistry of both main group and d-block transition elements. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 06301 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 06401 - Advanced Inorganic Chemistry Laboratory Credits: 2 This course covers concepts and models of inorganic chemistry in the laboratory setting.  Students study both main group and transition element chemistries.  The laboratory component emphasizes the synthesis and characterization of inorganic compounds. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 06301 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, LAB, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 06500 - Modern Inorganic Chemistry Credits: 3 This course covers concepts and models of inorganic chemistry.  It encompasses molecular geometries and other physical and chemical properties on the basis of the several chemical-bonding theories and with reference to the periodic table.  Students study the chemistry of both main group and d-block transition elements. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 06501 - Modern Inorganic Chemistry Laboratory Credits: 2 This course covers concepts and models of inorganic chemistry in the laboratory setting.  Students study both main group and transition element chemistries. The laboratory component emphasizes the synthesis and characterization of inorganic compounds. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD, LAB Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07101 - Cosmetic Chemistry I Credits: 3 This course provides an introduction to the chemistry necessary to understand the structure, function, and application of materials used in cosmetic products. Topics covered include periodic table introduction, bonding, nomenclature, intermolecular forces, acid and bases as well as an introduction to calculations required for compounding of fundamental classes of dosage forms. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07102 - Cosmetic Chemistry II Credits: 3 This course focuses on the physical, chemical properties and function of the varied raw materials used in cosmetics and personal care products.  Topics covered include discussions of emulsifiers, surfactants, emollients, thickeners, colorants, chelators, preservatives, and other ingredients commonly utilized in cosmetic applications. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 07101 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07200 - Organic Chemistry I Credits: 4 This course studies the chemistry of carbon compounds and their properties, structures and reactions. It emphasizes the study of the principle classes of aliphatic and aromatic compounds, which in conjunction with selected experiments, gives an understanding of the mechanisms of organic reactions. Required for science majors. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 06101 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 06106 with a minimum grade of D- Corequisite Courses: CHEM L7200 Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07201 - Organic Chemistry II Credits: 4 This course is a continuation of CHEM 07200. Required for science majors. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 07200 with a minimum grade of D- Corequisite Courses: CHEM L7201 Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07202 - Industrial Organic Chemistry Credits: 3 Industrial Organic Chemistry will cover common topics found typically in Organic Chemistry II (CHEM07.201) but will focus on the utility of this chemistry in an industrial setting. Highlights include: polymer synthesis, mineral sources of chemicals, renewable sources of chemicals, green chemistry, aromatic materials, coal, organic color chemistry, detergents, food, pharmaceutical chemistry, and others. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 07200 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07205 - Biochemical Foundations of Nutrition Credits: 3 This course will advance students understanding of organic chemistry topics and will serve as an introduction to biochemical concepts that are related to nutrition. This course is geared specifically towards the students pursuing the coordinated BSMS nutrition and dietetics degree. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 07200 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07220 - Cosmetic Formulations Lecture Credits: 4 This course focuses on cosmetics and personal care products with an emphasis on ingredient selection, product design, formulation development, preparation, product testing, as well as an introduction to the principles, theory, and processes involved in the manufacture and compounding of fundamental classes of dosage forms. Prerequisite Courses: ( CHEM 07101 with a minimum grade of D- and CHEM 07102 with a minimum grade of D-) or ( CHEM 06100 with a minimum grade of D- and CHEM 06101 with a minimum grade of D-) Course Attributes: CAT, LAB, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07348 - Biochemistry (Lecture And Lab) Credits: 4 This course deals with chemical compounds and reactions important to the functioning of biological systems and includes a discussion of the metabolic pathways for energy production and biosynthesis. Prerequisite Courses: ( CHEM 07201 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07202 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07203 with a minimum grade of D-) and ( MCB 01102 with a minimum grade of D- or BIOL 01202 with a minimum grade of D- or BIOL 01203 with a minimum grade of D-) Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07357 - Chemical Biology Credits: 3 The goal of this course is to describe how chemistry is applied to biochemical and biological systems to answer specific questions.  It examines the use of small, synthetic molecules that are used as probes of biochemical function as well as how to design experiments using these molecules.  The course also encompasses the use of purely synthetic compounds as functional or structural mimics of biological molecules.  The methods and techniques used to measure designed interactions will also be discussed. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 07201 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07202 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07203 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07388 - Natural Products Chemistry Credits: 3 This course is an introduction to the various aspects of chemistry that contribute to the extraction, isolation, analysis, and biochemical effects of natural products.  This course will focus on pharmaceutical, biotechnological, and medicinal applications of these molecules with a special emphasis on cannabinoids. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 07201 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07202 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07203 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry
CHEM 07400 - Independent Study-Biochemistry Credits: 1 to 6 Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07405 - Introduction to Polymer Chemistry Credits: 3 This course presents an introduction to the topic of polymer chemistry. The subject matter, by its nature, crosses all the lines of specialization within chemistry. The structure, properties and synthesis of polymeric materials are covered in accordance with the recommendations of the joint polymer education committee of the American Chemical Society. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 07201 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07202 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07203 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07407 - Advanced Biochemistry Lecture Credits: 3 This lecture course deals with complex biochemical processes involving the interaction of numerous classes of biomolecules.  Specifically the course focuses on the interplay of proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, and nucleic acids in the cellular response and adaptation to the environment, both locally in the cell and of the organism as a whole.  The course relies on both traditional descriptions of biochemical processes and the inclusion of primary literature sources to analyze experimental data, explain methodology, and introduce cutting edge concepts. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 07348 with a minimum grade of D- and CHEM 09250 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07408 - Advanced Biochemistry Credits: 4 This course provides an in-depth study of the principles involved in biological processes. It emphasizes the significance of biochemical reactions and regulations as well as mechanisms. A thorough elucidation of the structure, function and mechanism will be presented. The overall strategy of living systems will be illustrated. The laboratory experiments will provide exposure to representative procedures and some important modern techniques. Prerequisite Courses: BIOL 14348 with a minimum grade of D- OR CHEM 07348 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07409 - Advanced Biochemistry Laboratory Credits: 2 This laboratory course deals with isolation and characterization of molecules from biochemical systems.  The fundamentals and applications of chromatographic, electrophoretic, and spectroscopy techniques applied to biological molecules are taught through laboratory projects. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 07407 with a minimum grade of D- (may be taken concurrently) and CHEM 09250 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07410 - Medicinal Chemistry Credits: 3 A study of the biochemical principles and metabolic pathways with particular emphasis on pharmaceutical applications and biotechnology. This course will focus on the molecular mechanisms of drug action and chemical basis of drug therapy. Current methods used to study medicinal chemistry including recombinant DNA, combinatorial chemistry and bioinformatics will be reviewed. A 3-D molecular modeling of drug targets and drug design will be integrated throughout the course. Clinical trials of drug case study are included. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 07201 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07202 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07203 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07412 - Introduction to Antibiotics Credits: 3 Antibiotics are broadly defined as agents that arrest or kill bacteria and serve a central role in modern medicine.  Chemical compounds that exhibit antibiotic activity are wide ranging in chemical composition and biochemical mechanism of action.  This course will provide an overview of the important class of biologically active molecules. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 07201 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07202 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07203 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07431 - Advanced Topics In Biochemistry This course covers special topics in individual areas of biochemistry. Specific prerequisites are determineed by the nature of the course when it is announced. Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07442 - Biochemical Research Methods This course provides individual laboratory investigation of a topic beyond the scope of existing courses based on current research in the department.  The results of the research project will be presented in a written and oral report. Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07464 - Advanced Organic Chemistry I- WI Credits: 3 This course provides an advanced presentation of the major classes of organic chemistry reactions, giving major emphasis to the detailed mechanisms of such reactions. Modern organic theory is included. This course is generally offered in fall every other year. A writing intensive course. Prerequisite Courses: (ENGL 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01201 with a minimum grade of D-) and CHEM 07201 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, RE, UGRD, WRIT Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07465 - Physical Organic Chemistry Credits: 3 This course covers the study of the physicochemical properties of organic reactions.  Major topics of discussion include the study of kinetics and conformational analysis of molecules.  The basic reactivity patterns and the physicochemical rules that define reaction mechanisms will also be introduced.  The course is ideal for Chemistry, Biochemistry, Chemical Engineering, and Biology majors. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 07201 with a minimum grade of D- Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07466 - Advanced Organic Chemistry II (Lecture) Credits: 3 This is a continuation of CHEM07.464. It examines classes of compounds and reactions not presented in CHEM07.464. This course is not offered annually. Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07467 - Organic Preparations Credits: 3 This is a laboratory course that provides an in-depth study of the procedures and key organic transformations that can be applied to the pharmaceutical and fine chemical industry.  Major topics of discussion include the preparations of carbonyl derivatives and functionalized aromatics as well as other key pharmacological scaffolds.  The course is ideal for Chemistry, Biochemistry, Chemical Engineering, and Biology majors. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 07201 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07202 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07203 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07470 - Organic Spectroscopic Analysis Credits: 3 This is a laboratory course with class discussion on the separation and identification of organic compounds. It uses both classical and instrumental techniques in compound structure determination. Lectures emphasize interpreting IR, NMR and mass spectra. This course is not offered annually. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 07201 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07202 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07203 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07472 - Organometallic Chemistry Credits: 3 This course covers the chemistry of organometallic compounds and corresponding applications in diverse fields such as organic synthesis, pharmaceutical industry, and the petroleum chemical industry.  Major topics of discussion include the study of physical and chemical properties, characterization, and preparation of organic compounds.  The basic reactivity patterns and the reaction mechanisms will also be introduced.  The course is ideal for Chemistry, Biochemistry, Chemical Engineering, and Biology majors. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 07201 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07202 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07203 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07475 - Polymer Synthesis Credits: 4 This course provides an in-depth study of the procedures, techniques and theoretical aspects of polymer synthesis. Reaction mechanisms including kinetic and thermodynamic considerations will be studied. The topic of polymer synthesis will be examined from raw material sources through product usage. The laboratory experiments will provide exposure to representative procedures and techniques. Prerequisite Courses: ( CHEM 07201 with a minimum grade of D- OR CHEM07203 with a minimum grade of D-) AND ( CHEM 08401 with a minimum grade of D- OR CHEM 08305 with a minimum grade of D- ) Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07478 - Polymer Characterization Credits: 4 This course provides an in-depth study of the procedures, techniques and theoretical aspects of polymer characterization. Major topics include molecular weight determinations, polymer solutions, viscoelasticity and bulk properties. The laboratory experiments will provide exposure to representative procedures and techniques with emphasis on molecular weight determination and thermal methods. Prerequisite Courses: ( CHEM 07201 with a minimum grade of D- OR CHEM07203 with a minimum grade of D-) AND ( CHEM 08401 with a minimum grade of D- OR CHEM 08305 with a minimum grade of D- ) Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07490 - General Aspects of Pharmacology Credits: 3 This course provides an understanding of the basic principles and mechanisms in pharmacology. Topics discussed include drug discovery, pharmacodynamics, and pharmacokinetics, and the interactions between drugs and living tissues. It also provides fundamental knowledge about mechanisms of action, structure-activity relationships, drug metabolism, testing and regulation of pharmaceuticals, and drug-drug interactions. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 07348 with a minimum grade of D- or MCB 01333 with a minimum grade of D- or BIOL 14440 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07492 - Pharmaceutical Chemistry Credits: 3 This course covers the structure, properties, and preparation, of organic and inorganic pharmaceutical drugs.  Some of the topics that will be discussed include natural source derived organic pharmaceuticals, inorganic pharmaceuticals, and their properties under biological conditions, etc.  This course is ideal for Chemistry, Biochemistry, Biology, and Chemical Engineering majors. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 07201 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07202 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07203 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07493 - Introduction to Regulatory Affairs Credits: 3 This course will provide an introduction to the regulatory requirements associated with the medial product/device development.  This course would be relevant to the students majoring in chemistry and biochemistry with an interest in allied health professions. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 07201 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07202 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07203 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07494 - Good Laboratory Practice (GLP) Techniques Credits: 3 This course will provide an introduction to Good Laboratory Practice (GLP) techniques in Food and Pharmaceutical industries.  The course will cover Good Laboratory Practice techniques commonly employed in the non-clinical as well as clinical laboratory studies.  This course might be relevant to the students majoring in chemistry, biochemistry, and chemical engineering. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 07201 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07202 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07203 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07512 - Antibiotics Credits: 3 Antibiotics are broadly defined as agents that arrest or kill bacteria and serve a central role in modern medicine.  Chemical compounds that exhibit antibiotic activity are wide ranging in chemical composition and biochemical mechanism of action.  This course will provide an overview of this important class of biologically active molecules. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07531 - Special Topics in Biochemistry Credits: 3 This course covers special topics in individual areas of biochemistry. Specific prerequisites are determined by the nature of the course when it is announced. Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07548 - Biochemistry Credits: 4 This course is concerned about Chemical compounds and chemical reactions which are of paramount importance to the functioning of biochemical systems. The major metabolic pathways for energy production and biosynthesis are examined. Laboratory experiments reinforce and expand the lecture material. The requirements of this course include a graduate laboratory project and/or research paper. Admission to the course will be at the discretion of the Graduate Advisor. This course is taught in the Chemistry and Biochemistry Department. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07557 - Chemical Biology Credits: 3 The goal of this course is to describe how chemistry is applied to biochemical and biological systems to answer specific questions.  It examines the use of small, synthetic molecules that are used as probes of biochemical function as well as how to design experiments using these molecules.  The course also encompasses the use of purely synthetic compounds as functional or structural mimics of biological molecules.  The methods and techniques used to measure designed interactions will also be discussed. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07558 - Advanced Biochemistry Credits: 4 This course provides an in-depth study of the principles involved in biological processes. It emphasizes the significance of biochemical reactions and regulations as well as mechanisms. A thorough elucidation of structure, function and mechanism will be presented. The overall strategy of living systems will be illustrated. Laboratory experiments will provide exposure to representative procedures and some important modern techniques. Students are encouraged to design their own molecular biology experiments using the facilities provided. A term project is incorporated into this course. Students are required to conduct an in-depth review of the literature regarding a topic. Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07560 - Advanced Biochemistry Lecture Credits: 3 This lecture course deals with complex biochemical processes involving the interaction of numerous classes of biomolecules.  Specifically the course focuses on the interplay of proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, and nucleic acids in the cellular response and adaptation to the environment, both locally in the cell and of the organism as a whole.  The course relies on both traditional descriptions of biochemical processes and the inclusion of primary literature sources to analyze experimental data, explain methodology, and introduce cutting edge concepts. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07561 - Advanced Biochemistry Laboratory Credits: 2 This laboratory course deals with isolation and characterization of molecules from biochemical systems.  The fundamentals and applications of chromatographic, electrophoretic, and spectroscopy techniques applied to biological molecules are taught through laboratory projects. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 07560 with a minimum grade of D- Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07564 - Advanced Organic Synthesis Credits: 3 This course will provide and in-depth overview of several synthetically useful chemical methodologies, reagents, and reactions that are essential in synthesis of organic pharmaceuticals.  Some of the general categories of reactions to be discussed in this course include reduction, oxidation, protecting groups, and carbon-carbon bond forming reactions.  This course will survey a broad and diverse range of enantioselective, diastereoselective, chemoselective, and/or regioselective chemical transformations critical for the preparation of medicinal compounds.  This course would suit the needs of graduate and senior undergraduate students who intend to pursue careers in the field of pharmaceutical sciences. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07565 - Organic Reactions And Mechanisms Credits: 3 An advanced presentation of the major classes of organic chemical reactions, with the major emphasis being placed upon the detailed mechanisms of such reactions. Modern organic theory is included. The requirements of this course include a research paper or individual project. Admission to the course will be at the discretion of the graduate adviser. This course may not be offered annually. Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07567 - Advanced Organic Preparations (Lecture and Lab) Credits: 3 This is a laboratory course that provides an in-depth study of the procedures and key organic transformations that can be applied to the pharmaceutical and fine chemical industry. Major topics of discussion include the preparation of densely functionalized organic compounds that are used as pharmaceutical scaffolds. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07568 - Medicinal Chemistry Credits: 3 This course describes various topics related to the biochemical principles and metabolic pathways with particular emphasis on pharmaceutical applications and biotechnology. This course will focus on the molecular mechanisms of drug action and chemical basis for drug therapy. Current methods used to study medicinal chemistry including recombinant DNA, combinatorial chemistry and bioinformatics, will be reviewed. A 3-D molecular modeling of drug targets and drug design will be integrated throughout the course. Clinical trials of drug case study are included. A term project is incorporated into this course. Students are required to conduct an in-depth review of the literature regarding a topic. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07570 - Organic Spectroscopy Credits: 3 This is a laboratory course with class discussion on the separation and identification of organic compounds. Both classical and instrumental techniques are used in compound structure determination. Lecture emphasis is placed on interpreting IR, NMR, and mass spectra. The requirements of this course include a graduate laboratory project and/or research paper. Admission to the course will be at the discretion of the graduate adviser. This course may not be offered annually. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07572 - Advanced Organometallic Chemistry Credits: 3 This course covers the chemistry of organometallic compounds and their applications in organic synthesis, and pharmaceutical industry.  Some of the topics discussed in this course include the study of physical and chemical properties, characterization, analysis, and preparation of organometallic compounds, along with advanced organometallic reaction mechanisms such as substitution, addition, elimination, and insertion, etc.  The course is designed for pharmaceutical sciences students and includes submission of a written report on original research literature in organometallic chemistry. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07575 - Polymer Chemistry Credits: 3 This course presents a comprehensive overview of polymer chemistry. The subject matter, by its nature, crosses multiple specializations within the field of chemistry. The structure, properties and synthesis of polymeric materials are covered in accordance with the recommendations of the joint polymer education committee of the American Chemical Society. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07580 - Synthesis of Polymers Credits: 4 This course provides an in-depth study of the procedures, techniques and theoretical aspects of polymer synthesis. Reaction mechanisms including kinetic and thermodynamic considerations will be studied. The topic of polymer synthesis will be examined from raw material sources through product usage. The laboratory experiments will provide exposure to representative procedures and techniques. Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07582 - Characterization of Polymers Credits: 4 This course provides an in-depth study of the procedures, techniques and theoretical aspects of polymer characterization. Major topics include molecular weight determinations, polymer solutions, viscoelasticity and bulk properties. The laboratory experiments will provide exposure to representative procedures and techniques with emphasis on molecular weight determination and thermal methods. Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07588 - Advanced Natural Products Chemistry Credits: 3 This course is an introduction to the various aspects of chemistry that contribute to the extraction, isolation, analysis, and biochemical effects of natural products.  This course will focus on pharmaceutical, biotechnological, and medicinal applications of these molecules with a special emphasis on cannabinoids. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07590 - General Aspects of Pharmacology Credits: 3 This course attempts to provide an understanding of the basic principles and mechanism in pharmacology.  Some of the topics discussed include pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics of drugs, and their interactions with the living tissues.  It also provides a fundamental knowledge about the mechanism of action, structure-activity relationships, and interaction of therapeutics with physiological system and metabolism of drugs. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07592 - Advanced Pharmaceutical Chemistry Credits: 3 This course covers the structure, properties, preparation, and analysis of organic and inorganic pharmaceutical drugs.  Some of the topics that will be discussed include pharmacognosy, organic and inorganic pharmaceuticals, solubility characteristics and properties of these compounds under biological conditions, etc.  The course is designed for pharmaceutical sciences students and includes submissions of a written report on original research literature in pharmaceutical chemistry. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 07593 - Regulatory Affairs Credits: 3 This course will provide an overview of the regulations associated with the commercial development of pharmaceutical drugs or medical devices.  The course would be useful for students in MS Pharmaceutical Sciences and COGS in Industrial Chemistry. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CourseTitle: Good Laboratory Practice (GLP)/Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) Techniques
Description: CHEM 07594 - Good Laboratory Practice (GLP)/Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) Techniques Credits: 3 This course will provide an introduction to Good Laboratory Practice (GLP) and Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) techniques in Food and Pharmaceutical industries. The course will cover GLP/GMP techniques commonly employed in the non-clinical as well as clinical laboratory studies. This course might be relevant to the students majoring in pharmaceutical and related biomedical sciences and engineering. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 08305 - Biophysical Chemistry Credits: 4 This course covers the topics of physical chemistry and their applications in biochemistry. Topics include thermodynamics,  kinetics and spectroscopy. Prerequisite Courses: ( CHEM 07201 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07202 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07203 with a minimum grade of D-) and ( MCB 01101 with a minimum grade of D- or BIOL 01106 with a minimum grade of D-) and MATH 01131 with a minimum grade of D- and PHYS 00222 with a minimum grade of D- and CHEM 09250 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, LAB, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 08306 - Introduction to Biophysical Spectroscopy Credits: 2 Prerequisite Courses: MATH 01130 with a minimum grade of D- AND (PHYS02201 with a minimum grade of D- OR PHYS 00222 with a minimum grade of D- ) AND CHEM 09250 with a minimum grade of D- Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 08400 - Physical Chemistry I Credits: 3 This course deals with the problems of the fundamental principles underlying physical chemistry. It gives major emphasis to thermodynamics, kinetics and quantum mechanics. It also includes spectroscopy, group theory and statistical mechanics. MATH 01230 recommended. Prerequisite Courses: ( CHEM 07201 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07202 with a minimum grade of D-) and ( MATH 01131 with a minimum grade of D- or MATH 01141 with a minimum grade of D-) and ( PHYS 00222 with a minimum grade of D- or PHYS 00211 with a minimum grade of D-) Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 08401 - Physical Chemistry II Credits: 3 This is a continuation of CHEM 08400. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 08400 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 08402 - Physical Chemistry Laboratory I Credits: 2 Laboratory work in this course is designed to illustrate the principles of physical chemistry. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 09250 with a minimum grade of D- (may be taken concurrently) and CHEM 08400 with a minimum grade of D- (may be taken concurrently) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 08403 - Physical Chemistry Laboratory II Credits: 2 This course is a continuation of CHEM08.402 Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 08402 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, LAB, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CourseTitle: Applications in Experimental and Computational Chemistry
Description: CHEM 08405 - Applications in Experimental and Computational Chemistry Credits: 3 This course focuses on experimental and theoretical / computational techniques in chemistry, with emphasis on physical chemistry. This hands-on lecture-based course will provide students with hands-on experience in different physical chemistry methods for studying molecular structures, molecular interactions, reaction dynamics, and molecular electronic properties. Both experiment-based and computational-based techniques will be explored with emphasis on utilizing modern instrumentation and software to studying problems in diverse areas such as materials, biomedicine, and drug design. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 08400 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 08305 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 08410 - Survey of Molecular Modeling Methods Credits: 3 This survey course emphasizes the applications of molecular modeling theory and simulations in chemistry and biochemistry.  The course will present to students a broad and in-depth knowledge of different modeling concepts and methodologies, and provide students opportunities to apply modern computational software to investigate molecular structures, chemical reactions, and biomolecular processes such as enzyme catalysis and protein conformational changes, etc.  This course is ideal for Chemistry, Biochemistry, Bioinformatics, and Pharmaceutical Science students. Prerequisite Courses: ( CHEM 07201 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07202 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07203 with a minimum grade of D-) and ( MATH 01130 with a minimum grade of D- or MATH 01140 with a minimum grade of D-) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 08505 - Advanced Biophysical Chemistry Credits: 3 This is a graduate-level Biophysical Chemistry course, which focuses on applications of physical chemistry concepts and methods to biological systems.  Topics cover the basic concepts of thermodynamics, reactions kinetics and spectroscopy, etc.  Additionally, various specific biophysical chemistry topics and experimental techniques are to be discussed.  The course will equip students with a strong theoretical background to understand advanced topics covered in other courses.  Students will be additionally required to complete an independent literature report as directed by the instructor. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CourseTitle: Advanced Survey of Molecular Modeling Methods
Description: CHEM 08510 - Advanced Survey of Molecular Modeling Methods Credits: 3 This survey course emphasizes the applications of molecular modeling theory and simulations in chemistry and biochemistry.  The course will present to students a broad and in-depth knowledge of different modeling concepts and methodologies, and provide students opportunities to apply modern computational software to investigate molecular structures, chemical reactions, and biomolecular processes such as enzyme catalysis and protein conformational changes, etc.  The topics will include quantum chemistry calculations, molecular mechanics, molecular dynamics simulations, in silico drug design, etc.  This course is ideal for Chemistry, Biochemistry, Bioinformatics, and Pharmaceutical Science students. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09200 - Clinical Chemistry Credits: 3 This course focuses on the techniques and approaches to clinical chemistry. Topics covered include discussions of instrumentation used in the analysis of clinical specimens, the handling of clinical samples, panels for analysis and quality assessment. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 06101 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09201 - Clinical Chemistry Lab Credits: 1 This laboratory course provides hands-on training in selected techniques and approaches to clinical chemistry. This course is taken concurrently with CHEM 09200 Clinical Chemistry. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 06101 with a minimum grade of D- Corequisite Courses: CHEM 09200 Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09202 - Quality Assurance Credits: 3 This course focuses on the techniques and approaches to quality assurance in clinical chemistry. Topics covered include discussions of a range of activities that enable laboratories to achieve and maintain high levels of accuracy and proficiency despite changes in test methods and the volume of specimens tested. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09249 - Analytical Chemistry Credits: 4 This course is for those taking chemistry as a minor and covers basic concepts in analytical chemistry and serves to develop skills needed to solve analytical problems in a quantitative manner.  A wide range of techniques that are useful in modern analytical chemistry are introduced.  Statistics relevant to analytical chemistry molecular spectroscopy, atomic spectroscopy as well as acid base chemical equilibrium are covered. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 06101 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 06106 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, LAB, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09250 - Quantitative Analysis Credits: 4 This course provides lecture and laboratory experience in classical methods of gravimetric and volumetric analyses as well as electrical and spectroscopic analyses. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 06101 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 06106 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09300 - Environmental Chemistry Credits: 3 This course is comprehensive overview study of environmental science from a chemistry perspective.  The course is appropriate for junior/senior-level undergraduate students.  Topics include environmental pollution of soil, water and air, atmosphere and climate change, and methods for measuring and abating this pollution. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 07200 with a minimum grade of D- and CHEM 09250 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09322 - Bioanalytical Chemistry This course will focus on the details of analysis of biomolecules using a variety of analytical techniques including liquid chromatography, electrophoresis and capillary electrophoresis.  A thorough discussion of mass spectrometry technique, as applied to biomolecules, will be conducted.  This course will also introduce students to different DNA analysis techniques and electrochemical biosensors in biology and medicine.  This also includes the analytical centrifugation methods as used in determination of molecular weight of biomolecules.  This course prepares students for graduate school, careers in pharmacy, medical, and forensic among others. Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09330 - Chemical Analysis of Cannabinoids Credits: 3 This course is an introduction to the various aspects of chemical analysis that are used for the characterization of cannabinoid content in a variety of natural and commercial products. The focus will be on extraction, spectroscopic (including IR, UV/Vis, and mass spectrometry), and chromatographic techniques (gas chromatography, liquid chromatography, preparative chromatography, and supercritical fluid chromatography), specifically related to their use for cannabinoid analysis, residual solvent measurements, and pesticide detection. Prerequisite Courses: ( CHEM 09249 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 09250 with a minimum grade of D-) and ( CHEM 07201 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07202 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07203 with a minimum grade of D-) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CourseTitle: Chemical Characterization of Surfaces and Materials
Description: CHEM 09351 - Chemical Characterization of Surfaces and Materials Credits: 3 The majority of graduates from Chemistry and Biochemistry programs go on to obtain employment in the chemical and pharmaceutical industries, with a large number of these positions requiring knowledge in analytical techniques for quality control, quality assurance, and production.  These students require strong, hands-on experience in modern analytical techniques used for these jobs.  This course will be especially beneficial to students who want to pursue careers in pharmaceutical science and/or chemical manufacturing by combining specific lecture topics related to advanced experimental analytical techniques and laboratory experiences utilizing related instrumentation.  This is a combined lecture and laboratory course. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 09250 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, LAB, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09410 - Instrumental Methods Credits: 4 This course covers the use of instrumental methods in the solution of chemical problems. It stresses both the theoretical and practical aspects of obtaining and interpreting data. Among the instruments considered are visible, UV, IR, NMR, AA, ICP, Raman and Mass Spectrometers as well as electrical and chromatographic techniques. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 08400 with a minimum grade of D- and CHEM 09250 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09411 - Electrochemistry Credits: 3 This course covers principles of electrolyte solutions, thermodynamics and kinetics of electrochemical reactions, devices and instrumentation of electrochemical measurements, techniques of electroanalytical methods, and examples of bioelectrochemistry.  The course introduces a variety of applications of the electroanalytical methods in the areas of point-of-care diagnosis, hazard detection, and biosensors. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 09250 with a minimum grade of D- and PHYS 00222 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry
CHEM 09415 - Analytical Chemistry I Credits: 3 Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 09250 with a minimum grade of D- Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09420 - Supramolecular Chemistry Credits: 3 The course is about concepts, structures, functions, and applications of supramolecular molecular systems.  The supramolecular systems discussed in this course include surface assembled monolayer and multilayers, L-B films, host-guest molecular recognition systems, liquid crystals, and nanoclusters.  Application of supramolecular chemistry includes clinic diagnostics, drug design and drug delivery, biomimicry, and nanofabrication. Prerequisite Courses: ( CHEM 07201 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07202 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 07203 with a minimum grade of D-) and ( CHEM 08400 with a minimum grade of D- or CHEM 08305 with a minimum grade of D- or CHE 06340 with a minimum grade of D-) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09500 - Advanced Clinical Chemistry Credits: 3 This graduate course focuses on the techniques and approaches to clinical chemistry. Topics covered include discussions of instrumentation used in the analysis of clinical specimens, the handling of clinical samples, panels for analysis and quality assessment. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09501 - Advanced Clinical Chemistry Laboratory Credits: 1 This graduate laboratory course provides hands-on training in selected techniques and approaches to clinical chemistry. This course is taken concurrently with CHEM 09500 Advanced Clinical Chemistry. Corequisite Courses: CHEM 09500 Course Attributes: CLIN, GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Biological & Biomedical Sciences

CHEM 09502 - Quality Assurance Credits: 3 This graduate course focuses on the techniques and approaches to quality assurance in clinical chemistry. Topics covered include discussions of a range of activities that enable laboratories to achieve and maintain high levels of accuracy and proficiency despite changes in test methods and the volume of specimens tested. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09510 - Instrumental Analysis Credits: 4 The theoretical basis, construction, and data interpretation of most instruments used by chemist are studied. Among the instruments considered are visible, UV, IR, NMR, AA, fluorescence, flame emission, and mass spectrometers. Electroanalytical, potentiometric, conductometric, electrogravimetric, and voltametric methods of analysis are used. Laboratory experiments allow “hands-on” use of representative instruments. The requirements of this course include a graduate laboratory project. Admission to the course will be at the discretion of the graduate adviser. This course may not be offered annually. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09520 - Advanced Supramolecular Chemistry Credits: 3 The course is about concepts, structures, functions, and applications of supramolecular molecular systems.  The supramolecular systems discussed in this course include surface assembled monolayer and multilayers, L-B films, host-guest molecular recognition systems, liquid crystals, and nanoclusters.  Application of supramolecular chemistry includes clinic diagnostics, drug design and drug delivery, biomimicry, and nanofabrication. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09522 - Advanced Bioanalytical Chemistry Credits: 3 This course will focus on the details of analysis of biomolecules using a variety of analytical techniques including liquid chromatography, electrophoresis and capillary electrophoresis.  A thorough discussion of mass spectrometry technique, as applied to biomolecules, will be conducted.  This course will also introduce students to different DNA analysis techniques and electrochemical biosensors in biology and medicine.  This also includes the analytical centrifugation methods as used in determination of molecular weight of biomolecules.  This course prepares students for graduate school, careers in pharmacy, medical, and forensic among others. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09530 - Advanced Chemical Analysis of Cannabinoids Credits: 3 This course is an introduction to the various aspects of chemical analysis that are used for the characterization of cannabinoid content in a variety of natural and commercial products. The focus will be on extraction, spectroscopic (including IR, UV/Vis, and mass spectrometry), and chromatographic techniques (gas chromatography, liquid chromatography, preparative chromatography, and supercritical fluid chromatography), specifically related to their use for cannabinoid analysis, residual solvent measurements, and pesticide detection. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09592 - Pharmaceutical Techniques I Credits: 3 This course is intended to provide dedicated training for students in the design of research projects and their implementation in a laboratory setting.  The course will offer students the opportunity to focus on the preliminary aspects of research design and implementation in one or more sub-disciplines of chemistry relating to the pharmaceutical sciences.  Students will be expected to (a) retrieve, understand and evaluate prior contributions in the identified area of study and (b) design and implement hypothesis-driven studies within this area of study. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09593 - Pharmaceutical Techniques II Credits: 3 This course is intended to provide dedicated training for students in the chemical, biochemical and computational analysis of the chemical entities with relevance to the pharmaceutical sciences via spectroscopic and other characterization techniques.  The course will offer students the opportunity to focus on the preliminary aspects of research design and implementation in one or more sub-disciplines of chemistry relating to the pharmaceutical sciences.  Students will be expected to (a) understand, evaluate and discuss scientific information from the primary literature and (b) design and implement research or computational experiments and (c) analyze project outcomes and research data. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09594 - Pharmaceutical Techniques III Credits: 3 This course is intended to provide dedicated training for students in the development of professional, environmental and ethical best practices in the context of pharmaceutical research.  The course will offer students the opportunity to focus on managing professional, environmental and ethical challenges in one or more sub-disciplines of chemistry relating to the pharmaceutical sciences.  Students will be expected to retrieve, understand and evaluate prior examples of professional, environmental and/or ethical challenges the identified area of study. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09596 - MS Thesis Research I Credits: 3 This course provides individual laboratory research exploration of a topic beyond the scope of the existing courses.  The research performed would be instructor/advisor specific and is based on the current research being performed in the department.  The students would be expected to (a) conduct basic and applied research in pharmaceutical sciences, (b) retrieve and review research literature, (c) provide periodic updates and project reports, and (d) write manuscripts for publication in scientific journals or presentations at conferences and meetings. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09597 - MS Thesis Research II Credits: 3 This is a continuation course for MS Thesis Research I.  The students in this course would either expand upon existing research projects from their earlier course, or start newer research projects, which will be determined on an individual case by case basis.  The students would be expected to (a) conduct basic and applied research in pharmaceutical sciences, (b) retrieve and review research literature, (c) provide periodic updates and scientific project reports, and (d) write manuscripts for publication in journals or scientific presentations at conferences and meetings. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 09596 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09598 - MS Thesis Research III Credits: 3 This is a continuation course for MS Thesis Research II.  The students in this course would either expand upon existing research projects from their earlier course, or start newer research projects, which will be determined on an individual case by case basis.  The students would be expected to (a) conduct basic and applied research in pharmaceutical sciences, (b) retrieve and review research literature, (c) provide periodic updates and scientific project reports, and (d) write manuscripts for publication in journals or scientific presentations at conferences and meetings. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 09597 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09599 - MS Thesis Research IV Credits: 3 This is a continuation course for MS Thesis Research III.  The students in this course would either expand upon existing research projects from their earlier course, or start newer research projects, which will be determined on an individual case by case basis.  The students would be expected to (a) conduct basic and applied research in pharmaceutical sciences, (b) retrieve and review research literature, (c) provide periodic updates and scientific project reports, and (d) write manuscripts for publication in journals or scientific presentations at conferences and meetings. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 09598 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09600 - MS Thesis Research V Credits: 3 This is a continuation course for MS Thesis Research IV.  The students in this course would either expand upon existing research projects from their earlier course, or start newer research projects, which will be determined on an individual case by case basis.  The students would be expected to (a) conduct basic and applied research in pharmaceutical sciences, (b) retrieve, and review research literature, (c) provide periodic updates and scientific project reports, and (d) write manuscripts for publication in journals or scientific presentations at conferences and meetings. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 09599 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09601 - PhD Dissertation Research Credits: 1 to 9 The PhD dissertation highlights the innovative research contributions from a doctoral student to the field of pharmaceutical chemistry. The students would be expected to (a) conduct basic and applied research in the field, (b) retrieve, and review research literature, (c) provide periodic updates and project reports, and (d) write manuscripts for publication in scientific journals or presentations at conferences and meetings. This is a long-term process that requires significant time and effort from the student. PhD Dissertation Research is a research course designed to provide necessary time and guidance for the student to work on cutting edge research towards the Ph.D. degree. This course can and will be taken multiple times over the duration of the program. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09602 - Graduate Seminar Credits: 0 Graduate seminar is a required course for the PhD Pharmaceutical Chemistry students. In this course students give oral reports on topics chosen from the current chemical literature. Students are required to attend local professional meetings as well as the departmental seminars and colloquia to improve their theoretical background. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHEM 09603 - Professional Development and Doctoral Candidacy Credits: 3 This graduate course provides guidance for students in the PhD program in the development of materials required for advancement to candidacy. This course is required for Ph.D. students to advance to candidacy. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

INTR 01486 - Interdisciplinary Materials Science Credits: 3 This interdisciplinary course discusses selected topics of current technological importance drawn from the field of materials science. Three faculty members from different backgrounds in engineering and science will co-teach this course, offering the students different perspectives to a given topic. The topics are chosen by the faculty and may include nanotechnology, semiconductors, polymers, inorganic materials, superconductors, fiberoptics, spintronics, and photonics. Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CHIN 07101 - Elementary Chinese I Credits: 3 This is a beginning course in Chinese (Mandarin) for students who have not previously studied the language. It covers the mechanics of the Chinese language, including intensive practice in listening comprehension and speaking. It will also introduce students to basic Chinese reading and writing skills. Course Attributes: CAT, GLBL, GNED, HHL, UGRD Academic Department: World Languages

CHIN 07102 - Elementary Chinese II Credits: 3 This is a beginning course in Chinese (Mandarin) for students who have taken Elementary Chinese I. It covers the mechanics of the Chinese language including intensive practice in listening comprehension and speaking. It will also offer exercises for students to develop skills in reading and writing the language. Prerequisite Courses: CHIN 07101 with a minimum grade of C- Course Attributes: CAT, GLBL, GNED, HHL, UGRD Academic Department: World Languages

CHIN 07201 - Intermediate Chinese I Credits: 3 This intermediate level Chinese language course provides students the opportunity to develop further their listening comprehension and competence in spoken Chinese, their ability to engage in more substantial conversations in a variety of learning, work, and social settings. It will also help students build and utilize their knowledge of the Chinese way of life culture in conjunction with learning the notions and functions of the language. The course also focuses on students ability to read and write simple Chinese prose for their communication needs. Prerequisite Courses: CHIN 07102 with a minimum grade of C- Course Attributes: CAT, GLBL, GNED, HHL, UGRD Academic Department: World Languages

CHIN 07211 - Intermediate Chinese II Credits: 3 Intermediate Chinese II continues to provide students the opportunity to develop further their competence in listening comprehension and in spoken Chinese, their ability to engage in more substantial conversations in additional learning, work and social settings. It will advance and enrich their knowledge of Chinese culture enabling them to understand how to function in a culturally appropriate manner and to develop and appreciate more subtlety in language use. The course continues to help students improve their ability to read and write simple Chinese prose for their communication needs. Prerequisite Courses: CHIN 07201 with a minimum grade of C- Course Attributes: CAT, GLBL, GNED, HHL, UGRD Academic Department: World Languages

CHIN 07212 - Intermediate Chinese III Credits: 3 In Intermediate Chinese III, students will continue their development of communicative competence in all four language skill areas (listening, speaking, reading, and writing). Additionally, this course will allow students to increase their understanding of Chinese culture. Prerequisite Courses: CHIN 07211 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: World Languages

CHIN 07440 - Special Topics in World Languages Credits: 3 This course brings new perspectives and themes to the established World Languages curriculum.  Each semester the instruction of this course rotates among faculty members who select topics according to their current scholarly interests.  In this way, the course expands options for upper-level electives. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: World Languages

CEE 08102 - Engineering Graphics Credits: 2 The course deals with the creation and interpretation of engineering drawings, maps, and plans using engineering software programs. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08103 - Field Surveying Credits: 2 The course deals with the measurement of existing and man-made land profiles. The tasks performed include measurements of drainage areas, distances, angles, and elevations; closing traverses; topographic surveys; and highway alignments. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08301 - Civil Engineering Materials Credits: 2 This course deals with asphalt pavement, concrete pavement, and structural concrete including: the testing and analysis of aggregates, asphalt binders,  cement and admixtures; the design of asphalt pavement,  concrete pavement, and structural concrete; and the testing and analysis of asphalt pavement specimens, concrete pavement specimens, and structural concrete specimens. The course includes appropriate laboratory experiments. Prerequisite Courses: ENGR 01271 with a minimum grade of C- or ENGR 01272 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01273 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CourseTitle: Applications of CAD in Site Design
Description: CEE 08302 - Applications of CAD in Site Design Credits: 3 This course introduces students to computer-aided design tools used to plan, design, and manage civil engineering site development projects in a three-dimensional design environment. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08102 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08305 - Civil Engineering Systems Credits: 3 The course deals with the theories and principles of civil engineering systems as applied to real-world analysis and design problems. The course covers four important areas of civil engineering systems: linear programming, project scheduling, probability and statistics, and engineering economics. The course includes appropriate computer applications. Prerequisite Courses: MATH 01131 with a minimum grade of D- or MATH 01140 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08311 - Environmental Engineering Credits: 3 This course deals with topics in principles of environmental engineering, including ecosystems, water and wastewater treatment and design, and sludge/residuals management. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 06100 with a minimum grade of C- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08312 - Environmental Engineering II Credits: 3 This course deals with topics in solid and hazardous waste and air pollution engineering, including regulations, fundamentals, evaluation, management, prevention, treatment and disposal. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 06100 with a minimum grade of C- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08342 - Water Resources Engineering Credits: 3 This course deals with the analysis and design of basic water flow structures using the principles of hydraulics and hydrology. The topics covered in hydrology include the analysis of rainfall, runoff, groundwater flow, and stream flow. The topics covered in hydraulics include the analysis and design of hydraulic structures such as weirs, open channels, culverts, and storm sewers. The course includes appropriate laboratory experiments and computer applications. Prerequisite Courses: ( ENGR 01341 with a minimum grade of C- or ENGR 01342 with a minimum grade of C-) and ( MATH 01235 with a minimum grade of D- or MATH 01231 with a minimum grade of D-) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08351 - Geotechnical Engineering Credits: 3 The course deals with the basic principles of geo-technical engineering including soil properties and soil mechanics. The study of soil properties includes soil gradation, void ratio, porosity, water content, degree of saturation, specific gravity, soil consistency, soil classification. The study of soil mechanics includes  permeability, capillarity, seepage and stresses in soils. The course includes appropriate laboratory experiments. Prerequisite Courses: ( ENGR 01341 with a minimum grade of C- or ENGR 01342 with a minimum grade of C-) and ( ENGR 01272 with a minimum grade of C- or ENGR 01273 with a minimum grade of C-) and CEE 08301 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08361 - Transportation Engineering Credits: 3 The course deals with the analysis, design, construction, operation, maintenance, rehabilitation, and efficiency of transportation systems and mass transit systems. The course includes a study of the impact on transportation systems caused by  sociological, geographical, economic and environmental factors. The course also includes appropriate field measurements and computer applications. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08103 with a minimum grade of D- (may be taken concurrently) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08382 - Structural Analysis Credits: 3 This course deals with the analysis of simply-supported and continuous structures. Classical methods, including integration, moment-area, influence lines, virtual work, and force methods are used to analyze trusses, frames, and beams. The stiffness method is used to introduce matrix methods for trusses. Prerequisite Courses: ENGR 01272 with a minimum grade of C- or ENGR 01273 with a minimum grade of C- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08383 - Steel Design Credits: 3 This course deals with the analysis and design of structural frames. Analysis using the stiffness method is emphasized. The design of frame members includes the design of steel beams and beam-columns, connections for steel frames, bracing and composite steel/concrete members. Steel joists and decking are also introduced. The course includes appropriate computer applications. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08382 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08412 - Environmental Treatment Process Principles Credits: 3 Topics in Fundamentals of Physicochemical Processes in Environmental Engineering such as Absorption, Coagulation/Flocculation, Filtration, Sedimentation, Disinfection, Ion Exchange, Chemical Oxidation, Corrosion and Membranes. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08311 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08422 - Site Remediation Engineering Principles Credits: 3 This course deals with topics with site remediation engineering. Topics include site characterization, site safety, modeling site conditions, conducting feasibility studies, and designing remediation systems, such as pump and treat, stabilization, containment, treatment walls, natural attenuation, enhanced bioremediation, phytoremediation, oxidation, soil flushing, and soil vapor extraction. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08311 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08431 - Solid and Hazardous Waste Management Credits: 3 The course deals with solid and hazardous waste sources, regulations and management; engineering principles; treatment and disposal methods; design of landfills; recycling; toxicology principles; and risk assessment. The course includes appropriate laboratory experiments and computer applications. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08311 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08432 - Pollutant Fate and Transport Principles Credits: 3 This course deals with topics in characteristics and properties of organic pollutants, aquatic chemistry, transport mechanisms for pollutants (Absorption, Retardation, Attenuation, Volatilization, Biodegradation), groundwater (Properties, Flow Equations, Transport in Porous Media) and mathematical modeling. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08311 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CourseTitle: Principles of Integrated Solid Waste Management
