Description: CEE 08433 - Principles of Integrated Solid Waste Management Credits: 3 The course deals with the theories and principles of integrated solid waste management as applied to real-world analysis and design problems. The course covers the design of facilities and programs, such as landfills, composting facilities, transfer stations, collection programs, and drop-off centers, and planning of integrated systems for municipalities and counties. Computer applications are included. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08311 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08436 - Sustainable Technologies for Built Environments Credits: 3 This course introduces engineering and non-engineering students to innovative technologies that must be employed to sustain the human species on Earth by reducing the impact of urban communities.  After an introduction to Sustainability, technologies will be considered in five areas related to the built environment: environmental protection, energy, water, shelter, and transportation.  The course is designed to increase students understanding of sustainable technologies and ability to incorporate such technologies into programs to improve sustainability. Prerequisite Courses: MATH 01100 to 01199 or any STAT course is required as a prerequisite to CEE 08436. Course Attributes: CAT, GLBL, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08437 - Sustainable Buildings Credits: 3 This course introduces engineering and non-engineering students to innovative designs that can be employed to better sustain the human species on Earth by reducing the impact of buildings.  After an introduction to the impact of buildings on sustainability, technologies will be considered in five areas: sustainable sites, water, energy, materials, and indoor environmental quality. Prerequisite Courses: MATH 01100 to 01199 or any STAT course is required as a prerequisite to CEE 08437. Course Attributes: CAT, GLBL, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08441 - Surface Hydrology Credits: 3 This course is to increase knowledge on the application of hydrologic methods to water resources problems. Specifics include the use of probabilistic techniques to characterize hydrologic processes. Such analyses are characterized by data collection, analysis and interpretation, simulation, and forecasting. The level of understanding should, upon completion of the course, be sufficient to understand and appreciate the important issues in the current literature where statistical and optimization methods are used in prediction and interpretation of hydrologic processes. Synergy between hydrological processes and environmental quality, hydrometeorology, global warming, informatics, and ecology and conversation will be discussed. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08342 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08442 - Hydrometeorology Credits: 3 This course introduces hydrometeorology to the students and latest technologies used by water resources engineers for understanding, modeling and simulating the global water issues. This course will investigate the relationship between hydrology and meteorology and focus on key processes including precipitation, stream and ground water flow, flooding, water chemistry and contamination, and water resource management. A large component of the course will include collecting and analyzing data, estimating stream flow, and using spreadsheet and graphic programs to monitor water levels following precipitation events. Students in the class will use state of the art software to analyze the collected datasets. Topics included in this course are intended for students engaged in environmental and water resources engineering. The course is designed for students that are familiar with key concepts from courses in mathematics, hydrology, and water monitoring. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08342 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CourseTitle: Advanced Water Resources Engineering for Seniors
Description: CEE 08443 - Advanced Water Resources Engineering for Seniors Credits: 3 The fundamental theme of the course is the study of advanced topics in water resources engineering including the analysis and design of advanced hydraulic structures, hydraulic similitude and modeling, wave action, and advanced hydrology. The course includes appropriate laboratory experiments and computer applications. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08342 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08444 - Principles of Hydraulic Design Credits: 3 The fundamental theme of the course is the design and analysis of structures for controlling and conveying water in both the built and natural environment. Topics covered vary from year to year based upon instructor and student interests. Past topics have included open channel flow design, dams and spillways sanitary and storm sewers, culverts, pumping stations, turbomachinery, and hydraulic similitude and modeling. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08342 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08446 - River Engineering Principles Credits: 3 This course presents the theory and analytical techniques for the design and analysis of engineering projects that control or convey water in open channel systems. Topics include sediment transport, design of hydraulic structures, river restoration, and computer modeling. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08342 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: 0400 Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08447 - Watershed Engineering Principles Credits: 3 This course presents the theory and analytical techniques for the design and analysis of stormwater management projects.  Topics include environmental law, stormwater mitigation structures, rainfall-runoff analysis, limnology, and computer modeling. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08342 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CourseTitle: Introduction to Water and Environmental Monitoring
Description: CEE 08448 - Introduction to Water and Environmental Monitoring Credits: 3 This course introduces the latest technologies and techniques used by water resources and environmental engineers for mapping, modeling and monitoring. The goal of this class is to allow students to develop an understanding of water and environmental spaces and how maps represent them. This course will provide an overview of the application of advance geographic information system, remote sensing and complex mapping in water resources and environmental engineering. Students will use satellite images to extract data and produce viable information. State of the art software will be uses in this class. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08203 with a minimum grade of D- and CEE 08342 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08452 - Foundation Engineering for Seniors Credits: 3 The fundamental theme of the course is the analysis and design of structural building and bridge foundations based on advanced principles of soil mechanics. These advanced principles of soil mechanics include compressibility, shear strength, and bearing capacity. The types of foundations analyzed and designed include spread footings and pile foundations. The course includes appropriate laboratory experiments and computer applications. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08351 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08453 - Earth Retaining Systems for Seniors Credits: 3 The fundamental theme of the course is earth retaining systems including advanced principles of soil mechanics and analysis and design of earth retaining systems. The advanced principles of soil mechanics covered include lateral soil pressure and slope stability. The analysis and design of earth retaining systems includes slopes, embankments, retaining walls, and other systems. The course includes appropriate laboratory experiments and computer applications. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08351 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08454 - Introduction to Geosynthethics Credits: 3 The fundamental theme of this course is the engineering study of the types and methods used in the geosynthetics for geotechnical applications. These include understanding of the types and applications of geosynthetics, field construction of geosynthetic systems, and design methods for geotextiles, geogrids, geomembranes, and geocomposites. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08301 with a minimum grade of D- and CEE 08351 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CourseTitle: Transportation Planning, Demand, and Data Analysis
Description: CEE 08463 - Transportation Planning, Demand, and Data Analysis Credits: 3 This course introduces students to the general field of transportation planning including travel demand analysis and data collection methods. Statistical data collection and analysis methods are discussed. Examples using the traditional four-step planning process illustrate common planning procedures. Computer applications are included. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08361 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08465 - Pavement Analysis and Evaluation Credits: 3 The fundamental theme of this course is the engineering study of the mechanical behavior of flexible and rigid pavements. These include understanding of the pavement response and field performance data, and design of flexible and rigid pavements. The course will include appropriate computer applications. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08301 with a minimum grade of D- and CEE 08361 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08466 - Introduction to Transportation Systems Modeling Credits: 3 Introduces latest technologies and techniques used by transportation planners and engineers to study current travel characteristics and estimate future travel demand and supply. This course focuses on urban travel characteristics and activity analysis, travel demand and supply analysis, transportation system and project evaluation, and program and project implementation strategies. The course will (1) introduce concepts, procedures and methods associated with transportation planning; (2) provide basic knowledge of travel demand forecasting models; and (3) provide basic knowledge of relevant travel demand modeling software. The course is designed for undergraduate students who want to develop their career in transportation engineering and planning. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08361 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08467 - Introduction to Transportation Safety Systems Credits: 3 This course serves as an introductory course in the fundamentals and concepts of transportation safety for Civil Engineering students Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08361 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08468 - Introduction to Intelligent Transportation System Credits: 3 This course will introduce Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS) planning, design, implementation and evaluation concepts. The course will start with an introduction to systems engineering and fundamentals of ITS followed by detailed logical and physical architecture development for any ITS project. Furthermore, the course will introduce selected tools require to plan, design, implement and evaluate ITS projects. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CourseTitle: Introduction to Matrix Analysis of Structures
Description: CEE 08473 - Introduction to Matrix Analysis of Structures Credits: 3 The course deals with the matrix method of structural analysis. The topics covered include formulation of structural elements stiffness matrices using both stiffness and energy approaches, and the assembly and partitioning of global stiffness matrices. Approaches to solve for nodal displacements, reactions and member forces are presented. Modeling of distributed forces, temperature effects, and manufacturing errors are discussed. Linear, as well as both material and geometric nonlinear behavior are analyzed. The course includes appropriate computer applications. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08382 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08474 - Structural Mechanics Credits: 3 This course presents the foundations of structural mechanics. Topics include: stress and strain tensors; equilibrium; compatibility and consecutive relationships; stain energy density; energy methods for solid bodies, frames and trusses; and techniques for approximate solutions of problems. Prerequisite Courses: ( CEE 08383 with a minimum grade of D- or ME 10301 with a minimum grade of D-) and MATH 01235 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08476 - Portland Cement Concrete Credits: 3 The course deals with the proportioning, properties, and performance of different types of portland cement concrete mixtures.  It covers cementitious materials, admixtures, aggregates, microstructure, strength and durability; mixture design, properties, advanced performance testing of special types of concrete, such as high-strength, lightweight, fiber-reinforced, and self-consolidating portland cement concretes. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08301 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08481 - Reinforced Concrete Design Credits: 3 The course deals with the topic of reinforced concrete analysis and design. The analysis and design of reinforced concrete structural members includes types of concrete and steel, fundamentals of reinforced concrete behavior, analysis and design of rectangular and T-beams and slabs including flexural and shear behavior, development of reinforcement, deflections and crack control. Analysis and design of short reinforced concrete columns is also included. The course includes appropriate computer applications. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08382 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08483 - Steel Design II Credits: 3 This course addresses advanced topics not covered in a first course in steel design including topics such as design of plate girders, connections, and structural frames and bracing. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08383 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08484 - Prestressed Concrete for Seniors Credits: 3 The fundamental theme of this course is the analysis and design of prestressed concrete members for highway bridges, parking structures, office buildings, and industrial buildings. Topics covered include prestressed construction applications and materials, flexural analysis of pretensioned and post-tensioning beams, bending and shear design, loss of prestress, deflection, and composite beams. The course includes appropriate computer applications. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08481 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08485 - Reinforced Concrete Design II Credits: 3 The fundamental theme of the course is the design and analysis of advanced reinforced concrete structures and structural components including two-way slabs, footings, retaining walls, shear walls, and slender columns. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08481 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08486 - Bridge Engineering for Seniors Credits: 3 The fundamental theme of the course is the analysis and design of modern steel highway bridges utilizing the bridge code of the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials. The topics covered include bridge loads, load combinations, design methods, reinforced concrete deck slabs, steel wide-flange stringer bridges, steel composite wide-flange stringer bridges, continuous bridge spans, steel composite plate-girder bridges, elastomeric bearing connections, steel fixed bridge connections, and steel roller bridge connections. The course includes appropriate computer applications. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08382 with a minimum grade of D- and CEE 08383 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08488 - Pavement Rehabilitation Method Credits: 3 This course provides a wide knowledge in pavement distresses and rehabilitation, data collection and monitoring, pavement performance modeling, and economic analysis. Pavement rehabilitation and management is an essential part of pavement engineering as it improves the safety of our roadways and preserves our infrastructure assets. This course will explore the foundations of pavement rehabilitation using field case studies. The course will also include hands-on experience collecting, recording, and analyzing pavement condition data. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08361 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08490 - Civil Engineering Practice Credits: 1 This sequence of seminars and workshops is designed to give civil engineering students meaningful exposure to several critical topics related to the real-world practice of civil engineering. Topics covered will include bid specifications and documents, contracts and performance bonds, engineering estimates and cost engineering, engineering management and project scheduling, and professional ethics and responsibilities. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08305 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08491 - Civil Engineering Design Project I Credits: 2 This is the first course in a sequence of two courses that provides a culminating design experience for teams of undergraduate civil engineering students. The student teams address a challenging design problem that includes site design, water resources engineering, environmental engineering, geotechnical engineering, structural engineering, and transportation engineering. This first course in the sequence focuses on team formation, proposal development, identification of key constraints and design issues, alternatives generation and evaluation, and permitting. Teams prepare proposals and document their work through progress reports and a final written and oral report of their recommendations. Prerequisite Courses: ( CEE 08342 with a minimum grade of D- or CEE 08383 with a minimum grade of D- or CEE 08351 with a minimum grade of D-) and ( CEE 08361 with a minimum grade of D- or CEE 08311 with a minimum grade of D-) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08492 - Civil Engineering Design Project II Credits: 2 This is the second course in a sequence of two courses that provides a culminating design experience for teams of undergraduate civil engineering students. The student teams address a challenging design problem that includes site design, water resources engineering, environmental engineering, geotechnical engineering, structural engineering, and transportation engineering. In this second course in the sequence, teams further develop their recommended alternatives and prepare designs in compliance with local and national codes. Teams will prepare proposals and document their work through progress reports, design documents, and a final written and oral report. Prerequisite Courses: CEE 08491 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CourseTitle: Selected Topics in Civil and Environmental Engineering
Description: CEE 08493 - Selected Topics in Civil and Environmental Engineering Credits: 1 to 3 This course is designed to introduce students to emerging topics in the Civil and Environmental Engineering field.  Consent of the instructor is necessary, and prerequisites are determined by the nature of the topic. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08503 - Special Topics Civil Engineering Credits: 1 to 6 Civil engineering topics related to recent developments in industrial practice or engineering research. May be repeated. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08504 - Engineering Estimating Credits: 3 The course deals with the development of engineering estimates for civil engineering projects and project components including labor, materials and equipment. Total project costs including direct and indirect costs, field and home-office costs, and contingency are covered. Also covered are the various types of  civil engineering estimates including piles and cofferdams, wellpoints and earthdrilling, water and sewer systems, road and highway pavements, concrete buildings and bridges, and steel buildings and bridges. The course includes appropriate computer applications. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CourseTitle: Data Analysis for Civil Engineering Applications
Description: CEE 08505 - Data Analysis for Civil Engineering Applications Credits: 3 The fundamental theme of this course is the study of data science applications in the field of civil engineering. These include understanding of the types and sources of data, civil engineering instrumentation, testing methods, and data management. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08512 - Advanced Environmental Treatment Process Principles Credits: 3 Topics in Fundamentals of Physicochemical Processes in Environmental Engineering such as Adsorption, Coagulation/Flocculation, Filtration, Sedimentation, Disinfection, Ion Exchange, Chemical Oxidation, Corrosion and Membranes. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08522 - Site Remediation Engineering Credits: 3 Topics in site remediation engineering, including site characterization, site safety, modeling site conditions, conducting feasibility studies, and designing remediation systems, such as pump and treat, stabilization, containment, treatment walls, natural attenuation, enhanced bioremediation, phytoremediation, oxidation, soil flushing, and soil vapor extraction. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08531 - Solid and Hazardous Waste Management Credits: 3 The course deals with solid and hazardous waste sources, regulations and management; engineering principles, treatment and disposal methods; design of landfills; recycling; toxicology principles; and risk assessment. The course includes appropriate laboratory experiments and computer applications. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08532 - Pollutant Fate and Transport Credits: 3 Topics include Characteristics and Properties of Organic Pollutants, Aquatic Chemistry, Transport Mechanisms for Pollutants (Adsorption, Retardation, Attenuation, Volatilization, Biodegradation), Groundwater (Properties, Flow Equations, Transport in Porous Media) and Mathematical Modeling. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08533 - Integrated Solid Waste Management Credits: 3 The course deals with the theories and principles of integrated solid waste management as applied to real-world analysis and design problems. The course covers the design of facilities and programs, such as landfills, composting facilities, transfer stations, collection programs, and drop-off centers, and planning of integrated systems for municipalities and counties. Computer applications are included. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08537 - Sustainable Facilities Credits: 3 This graduate course discusses the energy efficient operation of building facilities. Topics include: introductory concepts of work, energy and power; sources of energy for facilities; the structure of electric, gas, and water utilities; use of energy in various building systems; and government programs to incent clean energy and energy efficiency. Course Attributes: 0500, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CourseTitle: Advanced Biological Treatment Processes for Engineers
Description: CEE 08538 - Advanced Biological Treatment Processes for Engineers Credits: 3 This engineering course will allow students to apply engineering concepts and techniques for the characterization and design of mathematical modeling of human impacts on microbial systems and vice versa. Special consideration will be given to microbe-mediated cycling of organic materials (i.e., pollutants) in natural and engineered systems, including: conventional water and wastewater treatment, municipal landfills, pristine and contaminated groundwater and surface waters, etc. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08541 - Advanced Surface Hydrology Credits: 3 This course is to increase knowledge on the application of advanced hydrologic methods to water resources problems.  Specifics include the use of probabilistic techniques to characterize hydrologic processes. Such analyses are characterized by data collection, analysis and interpretation, simulation, and forecasting. The level of understanding should, upon completion of the course, be sufficient to understand and appreciate the important issues in the current literature where statistical and optimization methods are used in prediction and interpretation of hydrologic processes. Synergy between hydrological processes and environmental quality, hydrometeorology, global warming, informatics, and ecology and conservation will be discussed. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08542 - Advanced Hydrometeorology Credits: 3 This course introduces advanced topics in hydrometeorology to the students and latest technologies used by water resources engineers for understanding, modeling and simulating the global water issues. This course will investigate the relationship between hydrology and meteorology and focus on key processes including precipitation, stream and ground water flow, flooding, water chemistry and contamination, and water resource management. A large component of the course will include collecting and analyzing data, estimating stream flow, and using spreadsheet and graphic programs to monitor water levels following precipitation events. Students in the class will use state of the art software to analyze the collected datasets. Topics included in this course are intended for students engaged in environmental and water resources engineering. The course is designed for students that are familiar with key concepts from courses in mathematics, hydrology, and water monitoring. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08543 - Advanced Water Resources Engineering Credits: 3 This course covers advanced topics in water resources engineering including the analysis and design of advanced hydraulic structures, hydraulic similitude and modeling, wave action, and advanced hydrology. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08544 - Hydraulic Design Credits: 3 The course focuses on the design and analysis of structures for controlling and conveying water in both the built and natural environment. Topics covered vary from year to year based upon instructor and student interests. Past topics have included open channel flow design, dams and spillways, sanitary and storm sewers, culverts, pumping stations, turbomachinery, and hydraulic similitude and modeling. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08546 - River Engineering Credits: 3 This course presents the theory and analytical techniques for the design and analysis of engineering projects that control or convey water in open channel systems. Topics include sediment transport, design of hydraulic structures, river restoration, and computer modeling. The course will culminate in an original research project and presentation. Course Attributes: 0500 Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08547 - Watershed Engineering Credits: 3 This course presents the theory and analytical techniques for the design and analysis of stormwater management projects.  Topics include environmental law, stormwater mitigation structures, rainfall-runoff analysis, limnology, and computer modeling.  The course will culminate in an original research project and presentation. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08548 - Water and Environmental Monitoring Credits: 3 Introduces the latest and techniques used by water resources and environmental engineers for mapping, modeling and monitoring. The applied goal of this class is to develop an understanding of water and environmental spaces and how maps represent them. This course will provide an overview of the application of advance geographic information system, remote sensing and complex mapping in water resources and environmental engineering. Students will use satellite images to extract data and produce viable information. Students will become familiar with state of the art software in remote sensing and mapping. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08552 - Foundation Engineering Credits: 3 The fundamental theme of the course is the analysis and design of structural building and bridge foundations based on advanced principles of soil mechanics. These advanced principles of soil mechanics include compressibility, shear strength, and bearing capacity. The types of foundations analyzed and designed include spread footings and pile foundations. The course includes appropriate computer applications. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08553 - Earth Retaining Systems Credits: 3 The fundamental theme of the course is earth retaining systems including advanced principles of soil mechanics and analysis and design of earth retaining systems. The advanced principles of soil mechanics include lateral soil pressure and slope stability. The analysis and design of earth retaining systems includes slopes, embankments, retaining walls and other systems. The course includes appropriate laboratory experiments and computer applications. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08554 - Design of Geosynthetic Systems Credits: 3 The fundamental theme of this course is the engineering study of the types and methods used in the geosynthetics for geotechnical applications. These include understanding of the types and applications of geosynthetics, field construction of geosynthetic systems, and design methods for geotextiles, geogrids, geomembranes, and geocomposites.  The graduate course will have a significant design component, which is not there in the undergraduate course. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08562 - Advanced Transportation Engineering Credits: 3 The fundamental theme of the course is the study of advanced topics in transportation engineering including advanced highway engineering and advanced mass transit systems. These advanced topics include the impact and interaction of sociological, economic, geographic and environmental factors on transportation systems. The course includes appropriate field measurements and computer applications. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08565 - Advanced Pavement Analysis and Evaluation Credits: 3 The fundamental theme of the course is the engineering study of pavement response. The topics covered include non-linear behavior of pavement materials and interaction between tires and pavements. Modeling and analysis of pavement behavior will also be taught, with content varying based upon instructor and student interests. The course includes field experiments and computer applications. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08566 - Transportation Systems Modeling Credits: 3 Introduces latest technologies and techniques used by transportation planners and engineers to study current travel characteristics and estimate future travel demand and supply. This course focuses on urban travel characteristics and activity analysis, travel demand and supply analysis, transportation system and project evaluation, and program and project implementation strategies. The course will (1) introduce concepts, procedures and methods associated with transportation planning; (2) provide basic knowledge of travel demand forecasting models; and (3) provide basic knowledge of relevant travel demand modeling software. The proposed course is designed for both undergraduate and graduate students who want to develop their career in transportation engineering and planning. Students in this class will deliver research papers/reports beyond those expected for students in CEE 08466, Introduction to Urban Transportation Planning. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08567 - Transportation Safety System Credits: 3 This course serves as an introductory course in the fundamentals and concepts of transportation safety for Civil Engineering students. The course introduces technologies and techniques used by transportation engineers to evaluate highway safety and develop effective safety countermeasures/strategies. Upon the completion of this course, students will: Understand concepts, procedures, and methods associated with the transportation safety system, understand basic knowledge of human factors and the fundamentals of highway safety, apply the roadway safety management process at a small roadway network, use predictive methods to estimate the number of crashes for different facility types, improve writing and presentation skills. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD, P_B- Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08568 - Intelligent Transportation System Credits: 3 The course will focuses on systems engineering & Intelligent Transportation System (ITS) fundamentals and design of regional ITS fundamentals. The course will introduce selected tools required to plan, design, implement and evaluate ITS projects. Students will work on projects that require data collection, simulation and analysis using various tools. The course is designed to investigate multidisciplinary aspects of ITS design and plan solutions for current and future transportation system. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08569 - Advanced Pavement Rehabilitation Methods Credits: 3 This graduate course provides a wide knowledge in pavement distresses and rehabilitation, data collection and monitoring, pavement performance modeling, and economic analysis.  Pavement rehabilitation and management is an essential part of pavement engineering as it improves the safety of our roadways and preserves our infrastructure assets. This course will use practical, industry-based data, methods, and evaluation techniques to evaluate roadway conditions, determine appropriate rehabilitation strategies, and assess economic impacts of pavement management. The graduate course will also include a semester long case-based research study using collected pavement performance data. Recent research on the influences of innovative technologies and sustainability on pavement rehabilitation strategies will be discussed. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08573 - Advanced Structural Analysis Credits: 3 The course deals with the matrix method of structural analysis. The topics covered include structural members, member joints, member end conditions, local and global coordinate systems, coordinate transformation, member structural matrices, global structural matrices, condensation of global structural matrices, static structural analysis, and dynamic structural analysis. The course will include appropriate computer applications. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering
CEE 08574 - Advanced Structural Mechanics Credits: 3 Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08576 - Advanced Portland Cement Concrete Credits: 3 This course deals with the proportioning properties, and performance of different types of portland cement mixtures. It covers cementitious materials, admixtures, aggregates, microstructure, strength and durability; mixture design, properties, advanced performance testing of special types of concrete, such as high-strength, lightweight, fiber-reinforced, and self-consolidating portland cement concretes. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08583 - Advanced Steel Design Credits: 3 This course addresses advanced topics not covered in a first course in steel design including topics such as design of plate girders, connections, and structural frames bracing.  Historic and current research that is the foundation of code requirements will be discussed. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08584 - Prestressed Concrete Credits: 3 The course focuses on analysis and design of prestressed concrete members for highway bridges, parking structures, office buildings and industrial buildings. Topics covered include prestressed construction applications and materials, flexural analysis of pretensioned and post-tensioning beams, bending and shear design, loss of prestress, deflection and composite beams. The course includes appropriate computer applications. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08585 - Advanced Reinforced Concrete Credits: 3 The emphasis is the design of advanced reinforced concrete structures and structural components not covered in an introductory reinforced concrete design course. Topics include columns in bending, slender columns, slab systems, and other advanced topics in reinforced concrete. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08586 - Bridge Engineering Credits: 3 The analysis and design of modern steel highway bridges utilizing the bridge code of the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials is emphasized. The topics covered include bridge loads, load combinations, design methods, reinforced concrete deck slabs, steel wide-flange stringer bridges, steel composite wide-flange stringer bridges, continuous bridge spans, steel composite plate-girder bridges, elastomeric bearing connections, steel fixed bridge connections, and steel roller bridge connections. The course includes appropriate computer applications. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08587 - Masonry and Wood Structures Credits: 3 This course provides the fundamentals of structural design using masonry and wood.  Topics include material properties, flexure, axial loading, lateral load resisting systems, and connections.  This course builds upon previously acquired fundamental concepts of structural analysis and design. A design project is required. Course Attributes: GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CourseTitle: Special Topics for Doctoral Students in Civil Engineering
Description: CEE 08603 - Special Topics for Doctoral Students in Civil Engineering Credits: 3 This course presents timely coverage of specific advanced and emerging topics in civil engineering, and it is intended for doctoral students.  Special topics courses may be traditional classroom-based courses as well as research-related courses supervised by specific advisers.  This class may be taken multiple times when offered with different special topics content. Course Attributes: DOCT, GCAT Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08635 - Anaerobic Treatment Processes Credits: 3 This course provides in depth exposure to anaerobic processes in wastewater treatment. It covers the microbiology of anaerobic processes, different types of anaerobic processes used in municipal/industrial wastewater systems, anaerobic reactor design and operation/evaluation. Students will have the opportunity to learn the fundamentals of anaerobic processes and design of anaerobic reactors with special focus to generating renewable energy-rich biogas. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08643 - Coastal Engineering Credits: 3 This course introduces coastal engineering processes. Topics include water wave mechanics, nearshore hydrodynamics, impacts of tides, sediment transport, and coastal structures. This course also (1) collects and analyzes field data (e.g., water elevations, waves, winds), and/or (2) introduces and investigates real-world projects. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08658 - Engineering Geology and Rock Engineering Credits: 3 This course provides a wide knowledge in engineering geology, rock mechanics and associated engineering applications, which will cover topics such as geological structures, geological map, rock types and minerals, laboratory and field testing of rocks, rock excavations and support, and rock structures (e.g. slopes, foundations, caverns, tunnels).  Engineering geology and rock engineering form the backbone of todays fossil energy exploration, energy production, geological storage and subsurface infrastructures.  The influences of rock properties on the engineering performance of rock structures will be discussed.  Students will have the opportunity to access and operate experiments on rock microstructure characterization from the research lab. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08673 - Structural Reliability Credits: 3 This course provides an outline for structural reliability analysis. The course covers the goals of structural reliability, including hazard analysis, reliability analysis, and structural design philosophy. The course applies advanced theories of probability and statistics, random variables analysis, and the Monte Carlo simulation technique to develop structural design concepts such as limit state functions, reliability and probability of failure analysis, load model, resistance model, system reliability analysis, and Code calibration. Structural reliability can be used to design new structures and assess existing infrastructural systems. Hence, many modern design codes utilize structural reliability concepts based on probabilistic models of load and resistance design (LRFD). Students will have the opportunity to access and perform computational analysis to analyze the probability of the failure of the structural components and system regarding the reliability index. Also, the students will learn the essence of the LRFD design equations and how to quantify the load and resistance factors using the calibration process. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08674 - Dynamics of Structures Credits: 3 This course is concerned with the analysis of single and multi-degree of freedom systems for time dependent loadings. Both analytical and numerical methods are addressed, with particular attention to earthquake excitation and response spectrum techniques. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

CEE 08675 - Fracture Mechanics Credits: 3 This course covers the behavior of cracks in bodies, and has a wide range of applications. Discussion focuses on the treatment of the singular stress and strain fields that occur near crack tips, with particular emphasis on fracture mechanics parameters such as K, G and J. Course material will include both elastic and plastic behavior. Both approximate and exact approaches will be considered. Numerical and analytical solutions and solution techniques will be presented. This course might not be offered annually. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Civil & Environmental Engineering

COSM 00352 - Co-op in Science and Mathematics Credits: 1 to 12 This course is for students doing an off-site professional co-op learning experience for credit. Each department and program will determine if and how this course counts towards the students program of study. Students will work with their departmental experience coordinator or point person for details before registering for this course. Prerequisite Courses: 75 credits are required as prerequisites to COSM 00352. Course Attributes: CAT, EXIN, UGRD Academic Department: Physics & Astronomy

COSM 03300 - Internship Credits: 1 TO 9 The internship course for the College of Science & Mathematics (COSM) allows students to receive credit for their internship experience.  Each program will decide if this course can count towards program electives  as well as the maximum number of credits that can count. This course will count towards free elective credits in situations where program elective credits are exceeded or is not accepted towards specific degree requirements by the students major of study.  In a semester, students will complete 120 hours for every 3 credits enrolled, as pre-determined by the internship coordinator and site.  Students will be expected to comply with all requirements of the internship site and will have a supervisor who oversees their learning outcomes and assessment.  Students will produce an end of semester product as agreed upon with the internship supervisor and Rowan University coordinator. This product can include but is not limited to a report, reflection paper, and/or presentation. Course Attributes: CAT, EXIN, UGRD Academic Department: Computer Science

CourseTitle: Introduction to Chemical Information and Modeling
Description: COSM 06101 - Introduction to Chemical Information and Modeling Credits: 3 Introduction to Chemical Information and Modeling (COSM 06.101) provides an essential introduction to the computational tools and techniques in chemical information and modeling.  The course covers Linux-based computers, Python scripting, chemical databases, molecular modeling software, and their applications in chemical and biochemical research. Students will learn Linux OS and command line, Python scripting, chemical data management (search, retrieve, analysis and utilization), molecular structure visualization, and basic molecular modeling. Through hands-on lab sessions and projects, students will develop skills to apply computational tools for solving real-world problems in chemistry and biochemistry. Chemistry 1 (CHEM 06.100) must be taken as a pre-requisite or taken concurrently with permission. Prerequisite Courses: CHEM 06100 with a minimum grade of D- (may be taken concurrently) Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Chemistry & Biochemistry

CMS 04200 - Introduction to Communication Studies Credits: 3 Introduction to Communication Studies introduces students to the field of Communication Studies by examining the various disciplines within the field. Such disciplines include interpersonal communication, communication ethics, health communication, family communication, organizational communication, intercultural communication, rhetorical studies, media studies, and others. The course also looks at the similarities and differences among the disciplines. Course Attributes: CAT, GNED, SBS, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04205 - Public Speaking Credits: 3 This course trains students in the fundamentals of public speaking, including study and practice of speech preparation and speech delivery. The goal is to enable the student to participate effectively in oral communication, as a student, professionally and as a citizen. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGL 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01201 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, COML, COMM, GNED, RE, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04206 - Digital Presentations Credits: 3 This course covers the fundamentals of presentations and meetings in digital contexts with attention to both the speaker and audience perspectives.  Although the course will instruct students in the use of current technological platforms to organize presentations and meetings, emphasis will be placed on effective message construction and critical interpretation. Students will learn how to conduct audience analyses, build audience interest, and strategically research and use supporting materials in digital presentations and meetings while maintaining ethical responsibilities. The ultimate goal of the course is to prepare students to participate effectively and ethically in digital discourse, such that they can be impactful professionals and citizens. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01201 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, COML, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04208 - Business and Professional Communication Credits: 3 This course offers a unique emphasis on communication in the workplace.  Techniques for negotiating communication in todays ever-changing business world will be focused on, with attention to business communication concepts.  These concepts range from management and leadership models to ethics in message communication.  Significant attention to various aspects of business presentations and interviewing strategies help to prepare students for success regardless of their past experience. Prerequisite Courses: CMS 04205 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04210 - Mass Media and Their Influences Credits: 3 This course studies the impact on our daily lives of television, radio, films, magazines and newspapers. Students examine how the media influence politics, purchases, and entertainment, and how the media affect the culture in shaping beliefs and attitudes. It discusses how each of the media operates and what each accomplishes. This course examines the gap between real life and “mediated” reality. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGL 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01201 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, GNED, SBS, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04215 - Fiction to Film Credits: 3 This course provides comparative study of film and literature. Students learn the critical vocabulary of literature and film and enhance their understanding of both art forms. The course covers American and foreign works. Prerequisite Courses: 30 credits are required as prerequisites to CMS 04215. Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04220 - Interpersonal Communication Credits: 3 Students explore the basic theories and concepts of interpersonal communication research and its application to their lives. The course covers topics that include perceptions and self-perceptions, social cognition, the relationship between culture and interpersonal communication, systems of communication, the influence of gender on communication, conflict, and other interpersonal communication contexts (i.e., family, friendship, romance). Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, GNED, SBS, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04223 - Sports Communication, Culture and Identity Credits: 3 This course focuses on how race, class, gender, sexuality, religion, and ability are viewed, discussed, and performed in sports. Approaching these topics through a critical lens, the class will address depictions of athletes in the media, equity issues, as well as the behaviors of consumers, among many other aspects. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04240 - Small Group Communication Credits: 3 This course focuses on the principles and theories of communication as they relate to the small group process. It deals with the barriers to effective group discussion and leadership with corresponding remedial measures, as well as an application of small group research as it pertains to hypothetical and actual small group situations. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04250 - Communication Theory Credits: 3 This course provides an overview of key theories in the study and practice of communication. It covers a mix of critical/interpretive and empirical/social science perspectives, including those drawn from socio-psychological, rhetorical, and cultural studies traditions. Students also learn skills for accessing, understanding, and synthesizing scholarly literature in the field. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGL 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01201 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, GNED, SBS, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04255 - Nonverbal Communication Credits: 3 This course will introduce students to the theories and applications of nonverbal communication. These theories and concepts will be applied to interpersonal, health, mediated, organizational, and intercultural communication contexts. The topics studied will include messages of and about the human body (physical traits and artifacts), the communicative use of space, gaze, touch, facial expressions of emotions, and the channels of voice and gesture. Students will be tested on their knowledge through a variety of discussions, application papers, and exams. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04260 - Organizational Communication Credits: 3 This course introduces students to the basics of communication in organizations. The class will focus on traditional and modern theories of organizations, and will address contemporary issues of communicating in organizations, such as: power and ideology, feminine and masculine identities and race and sexuality in the workplace, branding and entrepreneurial self, leadership and management, new technologies and knowledge work, globalization, socially responsible corporations, and meaningful work. Through prompted discussions, application papers, and exams students will be tested on their understanding and application of the course concepts. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGL 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01201 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04270 - Persuasion and Social Influence Credits: 3 Persuasion and Social Influence explores the principles and techniques used to shape opinions, beliefs, and behaviors in various social contexts. This course examines the psychological mechanisms behind persuasion, the role of communication, and the impact of social influence on decision-making. Through case studies, experiments, and practical exercises, students will learn to analyze and apply persuasive strategies in fields such as marketing, politics, and interpersonal communication. Course Attributes: CAT, GNED, SBS, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04290 - Rhetorical Theory Credits: 3 Rhetorical Theory introduces students to the concept of rhetoric and how it has been theorized from antiquity to the present.  The course provides students with a systematic history of rhetorical theory and spotlights significant theorists such as Plato, Aristotle, Cicero, Blair and Burke. Students will explore how both ancient and contemporary theories of rhetoric apply to contemporary society. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGL 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01201 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CourseTitle: Images of Gender in Popular Culture
Description: CMS 04310 - Images of Gender in Popular Culture Credits: 3 This course examines the concept of gender as it is rhetorically constructed in contemporary popular culture. Students will analyze how various cultural texts (such as advertisements, popular songs, television shows, or video games) communicate what it means to be masculine and feminine in U.S. culture.  The course will examine how these images have changed historically and how depictions of race, class, and sexual identity also contribute to our understandings of gender in popular culture. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGL 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01201 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04313 - Environmental Communication Credits: 3 This course explores the role of media and communication in shaping public understandings of the environment, as well as advancing movements for social, economic, and environmental sustainability. Topics include climate change, environmental justice, food systems, human-animal relations, green technology, and more. Coursework involves academic inquiry, case studies, and engaged learning opportunities. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04314 - Social Impact of Sport Credits: 3 Sport and social activism have always been closely intertwined, with some of the most prominent figures throughout history, as well as in the modern athletics world, using their platforms to speak out about issues they care about. From Muhammad Ali, Billie Jean King, Mahmoud Abdul-Rauf, LeBron James, and Megan Rapinoe, the social impact of athletes has been wide-ranging and significant in its scope. This course examines how sport has been used as a vehicle for social impact, change, equality, and justice. Using communication and media theories as the base, we will examine historical and contemporary events to see how various people (and entities) have used, and continue to use sport to foster change within society. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01102 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD

CMS 04315 - Digital Media Processes Credits: 3 This course examines the social, economic, and cultural implications of the use of digital media. Students taking this course will learn how to critically analyze digital platforms including Google, social media, and video games. The course includes analyses of data infrastructures, socio-cultural implications of data collection and content targeting, and breakdowns of how digital structures function. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGL 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04316 - Mediated Interpersonal Communication Credits: 3 The study of mediated interpersonal communication focuses on the role that communication technologies play in meaning making within interpersonal communication contexts, such as personal, family, community, and professional relationships. The purpose of the course will be to discuss the history and changing meaning of mediated interpersonal communication, survey relevant theoretical perspectives in the research literature, and apply those perspectives in contemporary issues. This course may not be offered annually. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01201 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGL 01112 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04317 - Social Media Strategies Credits: 3 This course focuses on strategies for building a community online through social media platforms. It includes a service learning component that allows students to apply what they are learning to a management campaign for a local nonprofit or startup organization. Students will learn how to research clients, research competitors, understand the relevant social media landscape, devise goals, choose platforms, create content, link social media, understand native and external metrics, and assess their success. Prerequisite Courses: CMS 04205 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, EXIN, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04318 - Leadership Communication Credits: 3 This course surveys theories of leadership communication and looks at leaders from different fields, including business, political, social, religious, and cultural, analyzing their ethical communication, and their vision and transformational influence. The course provides a basic introduction to leadership by focusing on the social construction of leaders and followers. The course will examine topics such as: the nature of leadership, theories of communication and leadership, communication ethics in leadership, creating a vision, communication leadership globally, and leadership for the greater good. The course will combine the theory and practice of leadership communication by having an applied component, such as case study analyses of “real world” leaders, and personal reflection of students leadership communication skills. Attention will be given to helping students to understand and improve their own leadership performance. Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04319 - Organizational Communication in Sports Credits: 3 This course juxtaposes the organization structure and communication of sports and sport industries with those of traditional corporations. It examines organizational, group, and interpersonal communication theories to explain how sport works, and ultimately, how it can work better. Given the strong cultural emphasis on the individual in sport, the course explores how interpersonal and organizational communication impact various stakeholders. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01201 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGL 01112 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04320 - Communicating Gender Credits: 3 This course will introduce students to the basic concepts, theories, and ideologies that exist at the intersection of gender, communication, and culture. Focus will be given to the ways in which gender, as a social construction, is created and performed in and through communication contexts. Students will also consider their own experience as gendered communicators while studying varying perspectives of gender from a communication perspective. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGL 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01201 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CourseTitle: Images of Athletes in Popular Culture
Description: CMS 04323 - Images of Athletes in Popular Culture Credits: 3 This course examines images of athletes and athletics as they are rhetorically constructed in contemporary popular culture. Students will analyze how various cultural texts (such as magazine covers, advertisements, television shows, films, or video games) communicate what it means to be an athlete in both the U.S. and internationally. The course will examine how these images have changed historically and how depictions of gender, race, class, and sexual identity also contribute to our understandings of what it means to be an athlete in popular culture. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01201 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGL 01112 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CourseTitle: Women and Nonbinary Identities in Sports Communication
Description: CMS 04327 - Women and Nonbinary Identities in Sports Communication Credits: 3 Women and nonbinary athletes have long been marginalized and underrepresented in organized sport, including domestically in the United States, and on an international scale. This course examines the communication, representation, depiction, and construction of women and nonbinary identities within sports from a rhetorical perspective, highlighting historical, cultural, and social contexts and analyzing the background and participation of individuals who encompass these identities as athletes, coaches, media members, in front offices, and more. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04330 - International Media Communication Credits: 3 This course examines systems of communication from a global perspective, analyzing the historical, cultural, and philosophical influences that have shaped those systems. The course enables students to analyze the systemic effects of globalization, new technologies, regulation, efforts of various groups to control development of communication structures, inequities in communication infrastructure, so-called cultural imperialism, and the linkage between international media and diplomacy, economics, and politics. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04333 - Special Topics in Sports Communication Credits: 3 This course provides students with an opportunity to thoroughly investigate specific areas critical to the field of communication and sport. Course topics change as new trends develop and as student interest necessitates scheduling. Topics are selected on the basis of timeliness and the availability of expert staff. General topics are announced as the course is scheduled. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01201 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGL 01112 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04340 - Family Communication Credits: 3 This course introduces students to how researchers study and understand the communication patterns, roles and relationships surrounding and embedded in families. Topics that are covered include family types, roles, expectations, sibling relationships, parent-child relationships, the dark side of family, conflict, and relationship maintenance. Students will be asked to consider a variety of perspectives and theories of family communication while applying them to their own family experiences. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGL 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01201 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04350 - Communication Studies Research Methods Credits: 4 This course introduces the student to quantitative and qualitative research methods used in communication studies. Students will learn about research procedures, identification and definition of variables, sampling methods, and basic statistical methods such as discourse analysis, correlational analysis, parametric and non-parametric tests, and descriptive techniques. Students will become familiar with current communication studies research and will design and complete a research project. Prerequisite Courses: ( CMS 04200 with a minimum grade of C- or CMS 01220 with a minimum grade of C-) and ( CMS 04250 with a minimum grade of C- or CMS 01300 with a minimum grade of C-) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04355 - Communication Studies Internship I Credits: 3 Under professional supervision in the field, students practice theories and skills learned in the classroom. No part is a prerequisite for another; order is not a factor in selecting this course. Prerequisite Courses: 75 credits are required as prerequisites to CMS 04355. Course Attributes: CAT, EXIN, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04356 - Communication Studies Internship II Credits: 3 Under professional supervision in the field, students practice theories and skills learned in the classroom. No part is a prerequisite for another; order is not a factor in selecting this course. Prerequisite Courses: 75 credits are required as prerequisites to CMS 04356. Course Attributes: CAT, EXIN, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04357 - Communication Studies Internship III Under professional supervision in the field, students practice theories and skills learned in the classroom. No part is a prerequisite for another; order is not a factor in selecting this course. Prerequisite Courses: 75 credits are required as prerequisites to CMS 04357. Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04360 - Intercultural Communication Credits: 3 Intercultural communication examines the nature of culture and its relationship to communication. This course will increase students understanding of the growing interdependence of nations and peoples. Students will learn to identify and appreciate the beliefs, values, and norms of their own culture, while developing a capacity to be inclusive of many other cultures. Through a variety of assignments students will test their familiarity with and understanding of different worldviews, cultural explanations of life and death, cultural histories, cultural values, and verbal and nonverbal messages in different cultures. Students will apply these concepts to different intercultural contexts, such as education, family, health care, and business relationships. By the end of the course, students will develop an informed ethical position on cultural values, customs, traditions, and ways of communicating. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGL 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01201 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, MCUL, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04365 - Research Practicum in Communication Studies Credits: 1 to 3 Research Practicum in Communication Studies allows students to apply the theories and methodology learned in Communication Studies courses to a research partnership with a member of the department faculty. Students earn 1 credit for every 40 hours of work, with most practica implemented for 3 credit hours. Students keep a detailed log of working hours, prepare a portfolio representative of their practicum experience, write an analytical critique of the practicum, and are evaluated by their faculty partner as well as the practicum supervisor. To receive approval for this course, students must have a minimum 2.5 grade point average. Prerequisite Courses: 75 credits are required as prerequisites to CMS 04365. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04370 - Political Communication Credits: 3 Political Communication looks at all of the ways language and media impact politics, including campaigns, citizenship, voting, and democracy. Prerequisite Courses: ( COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGL 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01201 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D-) and ( POSC 07100 with a minimum grade of D- or POSC 07110 with a minimum grade of D- or POSC 07200 with a minimum grade of D-) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04375 - Special Topics in Communication Credits: 3 This course provides students with an opportunity to thoroughly investigate specific areas critical to the field of communication. Course topics change as new trends develop and as student interest necessitates scheduling. Topics are selected on the basis of timeliness and the availability of expert staff. General topics are announced as the course is scheduled. This course is not offered annually. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04380 - Health Communication Credits: 3 This course provides an overview of health as enacted and defined in communication. Using varied approaches and applications, specific topics to be discussed include doctor-patient interaction, social and cultural issues of health, mediated representations of health/healthy behaviors, misinformation, health literacy, and health campaigns and strategies. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGL 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01201 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CourseTitle: Communication in Health Campaigns and Interventions
Description: CMS 04382 - Communication in Health Campaigns and Interventions Credits: 3 Communication in Health Campaigns and Interventions provides an overview of the theories and practices in the design, execution, and evaluation of health communication campaigns and interventions. Students will examine health promotion strategies used in national renowned mass media campaigns and new media campaigns, as well as in community-based and interpersonal-level health interventions. Students will gain hands-on experience in campaign development and message design when they complete a course project on the topic they choose. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01201 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, COMM, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04385 - Constructing Health Credits: 3 Constructing Health will address the various communicative means by which the concept and structure of “health” is socially defined.  Students taking this course will study the constructs of health, medicine, the body, and normalcy as enacted in rhetorical, mediated, organizational and interpersonal communication exemplars.  The relationship between power and these constructions is also interrogated. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04390 - Rhetorical Criticism Credits: 3 This course surveys ancient to modern methods for evaluating the social, ethical, and persuasive dimensions of communication. Students develop understandings of responsible and effective communication by studying historical and contemporary cases. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGL 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01201 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CourseTitle: Rhetoric of Science, Technology, and Medicine-WI
Description: CMS 04393 - Rhetoric of Science, Technology, and Medicine-WI Credits: 3 This course introduces students to the rhetorical study of health and science messaging. Students perform their own studies to offer suggestions for enhancing the ethics and impact of communication in scientific, technological, and medical contexts. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01201 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD, WRIT Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04395 - Rhetoric of Sport Credits: 3 This course examines the ancient connection between the art of rhetoric and the vocation of athletics. Students will explore the rhetorical dimensions of sport and sport culture using various rhetorical methodologies, such as metaphor, genre, or feminist criticism. Additionally, students will analyze the rhetorical form and function of variety of sports texts, both historical and contemporary. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01201 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGL 01112 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04405 - Independent Study - Communication Studies Credits: 1 to 3 This course provides students with an opportunity to work independently on specialized communication topics under the guidance of a faculty member. Generally, this course may not be substituted for any course offered by a department in the College of Communication. In addition to departmental permission, approval by the dean is also required. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04425 - Ethical Issues in Human Communication Credits: 3 Ethical Issues in Human Communication will address numerous ethical conundrums in our communicative activities. Specific ethical systems provide the groundwork for application to interpersonal, organizational, intercultural, political and rhetorical communication contexts. Case studies and class discussions will be used to encourage students to develop their own ethical frameworks for communication contexts. Prerequisite Courses: 88 credits are required as prerequisites to CMS 04425. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04440 - Rhetoric of Reality Television Credits: 3 This course examines rhetorical dimensions of the reality television genre. Students will analyze the various subgenres constituting Reality TV, with particular attention given to how such shows critique and/or validate certain identity positions in Western culture, including gender, gender identity, race, class, sexual orientation, and regional identity. Students will explore concepts of authenticity, truth, and suspension of disbelief as they relate to a television format based in documenting the “real.” Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01111 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01111 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01102 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CMS 04450 - Seminar in Communication Studies - WI Credits: 3 This writing intensive course provides a seminar experience in areas of communication that are not part of the regular course offerings.
