An introduction to biomechanical instrumentation (e.g., motion capture, force plates, etc.) will provide practical applications to address:  functional movement assessment, kinetic and kinematic qualities of movement, gait analysis for healthy populations and selected pathological conditions, and corrective exercises for proper human movement. Prerequisite Courses: ( BIOL 10210 with a minimum grade of C- and BIOL 10212 with a minimum grade of C-) or ( HES 00241 with a minimum grade of C- or PHED 35241 with a minimum grade of C-) and ( HES 00242 with a minimum grade of C- or PHED 35242 with a minimum grade of C-) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

HES 00347 - Wellness Programming for Children Seminar Credits: 1 This seminar prepares students who are not in a teacher preparation program to design and implement wellness programs and initiatives for children and adolescents using age-appropriate strategies and materials.  Students will apply the knowledge and skills they have learned about behavior change and program planning to non-school settings that serve children and adolescents. Prerequisite Courses: HPW 00340 with a minimum grade of C- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

CourseTitle: Human Disease and Epidemiology in Health and Exercise Science
Description: HES 00348 - Human Disease and Epidemiology in Health and Exercise Science Credits: 3 This course examines the etiology, pathophysiology and epidemiology of diseases and conditions that are often seen by health and fitness professionals working with clients in human performance and exercise science settings.  Included are cardiovascular disease, hypertension, asthma, Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes mellitus, overweight and obesity, osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, low back pain syndrome and cancer.  In addition, concerns specific to children, the elderly and in pregnancy are also addressed. Prerequisite Courses: HES 00345 with a minimum grade of C- or HES 00349 with a minimum grade of C- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

CourseTitle: Exercise Physiology for the Health Care Professions
Description: HES 00349 - Exercise Physiology for the Health Care Professions Credits: 4 The course specifically prepares students with the knowledge and skills essential for working in clinical settings related to health and healthcare professions. It intricately examines the interrelationship between physical activity and the consequential human physiological response. It prepares students to assess the physiology of the human body during acute responses and chronic adaptations to exercise and physical activity as a result of the training and conditioning process. Laboratory experiences will allow students to apply theoretical concepts to the health and health care professions in the areas of cardiovascular, metabolic, neuromuscular, pulmonary diseases, body composition, and exercise in thermal stress environments. Prerequisite Courses: ( HES 00241 with a minimum grade of C- and HES 00242 with a minimum grade of C-) or ( BIOL 10210 with a minimum grade of C- and BIOL 10212 with a minimum grade of C-) Course Attributes: CAT, LAB, UGRD Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

HES 00350 - Advanced Exercise Physiology Credits: 3 This course is designed to examine signal transduction pathways related to exercise with an emphasis on how the acute effects of aerobic and resistance exercise lead to chronic adaptations. Additional topics include exercise and immune function, as well as exercise in extreme environments. Students will also be expected to apply their knowledge in exercise physiology to evaluate existing literature and to critically appraise common beliefs in the field of exercise science. Prerequisite Courses: HES 00349 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

HES 00401 - Exercise Prescription Credits: 3 This course provides students with the knowledge and practical experience in exercise testing and prescription. It enables students to establish scientific foundations of exercise testing and prescription, identify risk factors for disease and prescribe exercise programs based on exercise test results and personal limitations. Practical experiences are provided for testing subjects in the laboratory. The course prepares students for professional exercise certifications. Prerequisite Courses: HES 00345 with a minimum grade of C- or HES 00349 with a minimum grade of C- Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, UGRD Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

CourseTitle: EKG Interpretation and Basic Pharmacology in Health and Exercise Science
Description: HES 00402 - EKG Interpretation and Basic Pharmacology in Health and Exercise Science Credits: 3 This course provides a thorough understanding of EKG interpretation and basic pharmacology related to cardiac, pulmonary, and diabetic conditions for professionals in human performance and exercise science fields.  Video streaming of EKG rhythms will provide students with practical experience.  Case studies will be used to understand how medications are used to treat a variety of health issues and the influence of these medications on exercise prescription. Prerequisite Courses: HES 00401 with a minimum grade of C- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

HES 00409 - Adventure Programming Credits: 3 This is an advanced course examining the role of an adventure course manager or outdoor leader. The class focuses on purposeful design, risk management, and safety of adventure programming. There will be managed adventure course scenarios where skills, judgment, and reactions will be assessed and reviewed. Students will learn to be environmentally-responsible wilderness users.  Finally, students will learn to organize and lead excursions. Prerequisite Courses: HES 00109 with a minimum grade of D- and HES 00209 with a minimum grade of D- and HES 00309 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

HES 00412 - Exercise for Special Populations Credits: 3 This course provides a study of exercise considerations for those with disease and special conditions. It covers the basic concepts of the physiologic effects of exercise and the application of these concepts to special cases. Cases included are respiratory and cardiovascular diseases, hypertension, obesity, diabetes, arthritis, osteoporosis, pregnancy, children/adolescents, and the elderly. In addition, students will learn exercise testing modifications and specific exercise prescriptions and the associated modifications. Prerequisite Courses: ( HES 00345 with a minimum grade of C- or PHED 35345 with a minimum grade of C- or HES 00349 with a minimum grade of C-) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

HES 00413 - Senior Seminar in Exercise Science Credits: 3 This application-oriented course is designed to review and assess the students knowledge and skills which were developed throughout the Exercise Science program.  Students will progress through a series of online seminars reviewing the key concepts and skills learned in the program that are necessary for a career in the field of Exercise Science.  In addition, students will work in group settings to continue to practice and develop key skills necessary for their career. Prerequisite Courses: HES 00401 with a minimum grade of C- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

HES 00415 - Nutrition for Fitness Credits: 3 This advanced nutrition course explores the relationship between nutrition, physical fitness, performance and disease prevention. Specific topics include nutrition fraud, supplementation, ergogenic aids, diet planning for athletes and the relationship between nutrition and chronic diseases such as cancer and heart disease. In addition, students continue to develop their skills as nutrition counselors and educators. Prerequisite Courses: ( NUT 00200 with a minimum grade of C- or INAR 06200 with a minimum grade of C-) and ( BIOL 10210 with a minimum grade of C- or HES 00241 with a minimum grade of C-) and ( BIOL 10212 with a minimum grade of C- or HES 00242 with a minimum grade of C-) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

CourseTitle: Senior Internship in Health and Exercise Science
Description: HES 00483 - Senior Internship in Health and Exercise Science Credits: 6 Students complete 400 hours of supervised field experience enabling them to gain practical experience in an environment focused on Health Promotion, Exercise Physiology, Community Health or other, related field.  Placements are made in agencies selected on the basis of students goals, interests, and program specialization.  The site will provide experiences that build on the skills, knowledge, and dispositions acquired during coursework and related professional experiences. Prerequisite Courses: HPW 00430 with a minimum grade of C- or HLTH 37430 with a minimum grade of C- or HES 00413 with a minimum grade of C- Course Attributes: CAT, EXIN, UGRD Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

HES 00484 - Senior Internship in Exercise Science Credits: 6 Students complete 250 hours of supervised field experience enabling them to gain practical experience in an environment focused on Exercise Science or other, related field. Placements are made in agencies selected on the basis of students goals, interests, and program specialization. The site will provide experiences that build on the skills, knowledge, and dispositions acquired during coursework and related professional experiences. 6 Credit hours Prerequisite Courses: HES 00413 with a minimum grade of C- Course Attributes: CAT, EXIN, UGRD Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

HES 00490 - Exercise Science Learning Assistant Credits: 3 As Learning Assistants, students will develop educational experiences in facilitating active learning techniques in a classroom with an Exercise Science faculty.  Being a Learning Assistant will enhance a students development and mastery of Exercise Science content as a result of facilitating student group interactions and activities that encourage engagement.  Students will meet weekly to develop teaching competencies that better prepare students for future education endeavors like teaching and/or graduate assistantships, or college instructors in their future careers. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

CourseTitle: Independent Study Health and Exercise Science
Description: HES 00492 - Independent Study Health and Exercise Science Credits: 1 to 3 Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

CourseTitle: The Pursuit of Happiness: Engaging Adventure Psychologically
Description: HLT 00375 - The Pursuit of Happiness: Engaging Adventure Psychologically Credits: 3 This course explores how adventure activities can promote lifelong wellness and personal growth, in context of psychological theories and process, such as positive psychology. Activities will emphasize the five elements of adventure: extraordinary experiences, uncertain outcomes, passion, mindfulness, and great companionship.  Students will learn how to integrate these principles into their daily lives for greater authenticity and purpose. Through a variety of challenge and leadership activities, including team-building exercises, trust activities, and problem-solving tasks, students will apply positive psychology to enhance their understanding of personal and group dynamics. The course emphasizes reflection, debriefing, and active participation. Prerequisite Courses: None Corequisite Courses: None Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

CourseTitle: Data Analysis for Evidence-Based Research in Health, Wellness and Sport
Description: HLT 00504 - Data Analysis for Evidence-Based Research in Health, Wellness and Sport Credits: 3 In this course, students will learn the language and process of data analysis and statistical methods in search of trends to answer questions relevant to health and sport.  Specifically, students will learn the sources of data, how this data is aggregated and analyzed and how to use the data to guide evidence-based practice.  Ethical issues surrounding data management and application will also be addressed. Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

CourseTitle: Historical and Social Perspectives in Health Disparities
Description: HLT 00505 - Historical and Social Perspectives in Health Disparities Credits: 3 This course focuses on the historical perspectives of health disparities. Students will focus attention on the investigation on the fundamental and root causes of inequity in the United States. Students will examine the empirical evidence to evaluate how historic policies and interventions in the United States have impacted groups differently. Societal and social factors that influence and impact health disparities will be evaluated. Health equity as a goal and aspiration for improved health in communities will be critically analyzed. Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

HPE 00101 - Swimming II: Intermediate Credits: 2 This introduction to Swimming II course is designed for intermediate to advance swimmers. Instruction and practice will include the progressive elements of swimming and water safety skills, emphasizing the basics of stroke development, rhythmic breathing, diving progressions, and the forms of open and closed turns. Students will gain basic rescue and water safety knowledge to create confident and competent swimmers, promoting safety in, on, and around, bodies of water ARC, 2014). Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

HPE 00102 - Lifeguard Training-Aquatics Credits: 3 The purpose of the American Red Cross Lifeguarding course is to provide entry-level lifeguard participants with the knowledge and skills to prevent, recognize and respond to aquatic emergencies and to provide care for breathing and cardiac emergencies, injuries and sudden illnesses until emergency medical services personnel take over. To be considered for certification prerequisite skills, course expectations and evaluation must be achieved (i.e. attendance, assessments, assignments, skills) Prerequisite Courses: HPE 00101 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

HPE 00103 - Water Safety Instructor Training-Aquatics Credits: 3 The purpose of the American Red Cross Water Safety Instructor course is to train candidates for teaching and delivery of aquatic courses and presentations for American Red Cross Swimming and Water Safety programming. Instructor candidates will develop their understanding of how to use the course materials, conduct training sessions, and how to evaluate students progress. Instructor candidates will learn to teach children and adults, and communities about the importance of water safety, survival and importance of learning to swim as a lifesaving skill. Prerequisite Courses: HPE 00101 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

HPE 00104 - Yoga and Mindfulness Credits: 2 This course provides each student with the skills and experiences to develop self-awareness, meditative practices, and an appreciation for healthy living through the understanding and practice of Hatha Yoga. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

HPE 00109 - Teaching Concepts of Driver Education Credits: 3 The course is designed for individuals seeking New Jersey Driver Education teacher endorsement.  The content includes learning to teach motor vehicle operation, driving environment and the student development of teaching techniques emphasizing safety, risk perception, and decision-making processes applied in a vehicle.  Learning how to instruct others in performing behind-the-wheel driving will be scheduled outside of class time. Prerequisite Courses: (ATR 00235 with a minimum grade of D- or PHED 35235 with a minimum grade of D-) and ( HPE 00325 with a minimum grade of D- or HLTH 37325 with a minimum grade of D-) or (ATR 00235 with a minimum grade of D- or PHED 35235 with a minimum grade of D-) and ( HPE 00326 with a minimum grade of D- or HLTH 37326 with a minimum grade of D-) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

HPE 00110 - Karate I Credits: 2 This course will prepare students to facilitate, lead, advocate, and engage in the scientific and philosophical art, of Karate, as a lifetime physical activity.  Students will develop the fundamental skill proficiencies, and knowledge of history, rules, strategies, and understanding of the three divisions of Modern Karate as a self-defense art, a physical art, and a sport, all of which are comprised of the same basic techniques. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

HPE 00111 - Walk, Jog, Run with Rowan Credits: 2 This course will prepare students to facilitate, lead, advocate, and engage in lifetime physical activity.  Students will develop the fundamental skill proficiencies, and learn basic concepts associated with the development and maintenance of physical activity, as well as be exposed to the different fitness opportunities offered in the local area while engaging in health-promoting and wellness activities. Walk, Run, Jog with Rowan, is a course designed to allow students to participate in physical activity of their choice at a time and location that best fits their schedule, and is electronically recorded and synced to your instructor using a fitness tracking device (Movband 4). Health and Physical Education majors (in the certification Specialization) must select, with advisement, at least one physical activity from each LEAP category (i.e., Net & Wall, Lifetime & Mind-Body Movement, Invasion, and Aquatics) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

CourseTitle: Capoiera Angola: Life Expression Through Martial Arts
Description: HPE 00112 - Capoiera Angola: Life Expression Through Martial Arts Credits: 2 This course will prepare students to facilitate, lead, advocate, and engage in Capoeira Angola as a cultural expression and lifetime physical activity.  Students will develop the fundamental skill proficiencies, and knowledge of history, rules, strategies, and understanding of Capoeira Angola as a physical art, and overall mind-body exercise which helps improve, movement, flexibility, balance and enhance overall well-being. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

HPE 00113 - Basic Training for Lifetime Wellness Credits: 2 This course is designed to enhance participants/students understanding of overall wellness, with a specific focus on weight training. Students will be empowered with the skills necessary to establish a muscle strengthening routine that is safe and effective to promote increased strength, tone and muscle mass for the total body. Throughout the semester, we will participate in discussions and activities that will increase your knowledge of how to self-test your strength levels, set realistic goals, and establish a planned course of action. You will learn a variety of techniques to accomplish symmetry and balance for optimum functionality. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

HPE 00118 - Basketball Basics Credits: 2 This introductory course will prepare students to facilitate, lead, advocate, and engage in Basketball as a lifetime physical activity. Students will develop the fundamental skill proficiencies, knowledge of history, rules, strategies, roles of responsibility of Basketball as a sport, and physical activity which can help improve the health-related components of fitness, promote personal and social responsibility, and enhance overall well-being. Students with varying levels of experience will have the opportunity to gain new skills or refine their technique through developmentally appropriate skills, drills, teaching, and practice. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

HPE 00119 - Flag Football Credits: 2 This introductory course will prepare students to facilitate, lead, advocate, and engage in Flag Football as a lifetime physical activity. Students will develop the fundamental skill proficiencies, knowledge of history, rules, strategies, roles of responsibility of Flag Football as a sport, and physical activity which can help improve the health-related components of fitness, promote personal and social responsibility, and enhance overall well-being. Students with varying levels of experience will have the opportunity to gain new skills or refine their technique through developmentally appropriate skills, drills, teaching, and practice. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

HPE 00240 - Motor Development and Motor Learning Credits: 3 This is an introductory course that includes the study of stability, locomotor and manipulative skills, and developmental and environmental factors that affect learning in these motor skill areas. The course will focus on motor behavior changes. Students will also be introduced to motor learning theories and concepts, assessment, and development of motor skills in various settings. This course requires students to acquire a NJDOE background check and a TB test and has a lab component. Prerequisite Courses: HPE 02210 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, GNED, SBS, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

HPE 00252 - Foundations of Fitness Credits: 3 This course is designed to provide students with the skills and knowledge to be able to design, implement, and assess a fitness program for K-12 students.  Content will focus on health and skill related fitness and include designing fitness programs for individuals with differing needs and abilities. Prerequisite Courses: HPE 02210 with a minimum grade of C- (may be taken concurrently) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

CourseTitle: Technology in Health and Physical Education
Description: HPE 00270 - Technology in Health and Physical Education Credits: 2 This course will prepare students in the Health and Physical Education program to use computers and technology for organizing information, amplifying presentation, developing written documents, and gathering and storing information.  Students will evaluate software, evaluate internet sources and mobile apps, and explore non-computer media applications as they apply to teaching and learning.  An introduction to data collection and basic descriptive statistics will also be a component of this course. Prerequisite Courses: HPE 02210 with a minimum grade of C- (may be taken concurrently) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

CourseTitle: Pedagogy and Instructional Practices in HPE
Description: HPE 00286 - Pedagogy and Instructional Practices in HPE Credits: 3 This course is designed to introduce students to teaching health and physical education in K-12 settings. Students explore the roles and responsibilities of teaching with emphasis on instructional and technical skills of teaching, student behaviors, and the classroom environment needed to achieve student learning outcomes which address the New Jersey State Student Learning Standards for Comprehensive Health and Physical Education.  Students explore the roles and responsibilities of teachers through the study of professional literature; class discussions and activities; simulation exercises; and direct on, and off-campus, required K-12 field observation experiences with students, teachers and administrators. Prerequisite Courses: HPE 00252 with a minimum grade of C- (may be taken concurrently) and HPE 00240 with a minimum grade of C- (may be taken concurrently) and HPE 00270 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, CE, EXIN, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

CourseTitle: Teaching Concepts of Secondary Physical Education
Description: HPE 00310 - Teaching Concepts of Secondary Physical Education Credits: 3 This course provides an opportunity for students to learn the characteristics of a skilled performance in a variety of activities, including target, individual, team sports and net/wall activities. Students will be able to describe and demonstrate the application of appropriate participation in each activity, as well as effective pedagogical techniques that lead to such participation. Prerequisite Courses: HPE 00316 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00336 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00452 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00325 with a minimum grade of D- Corequisite Courses: HPE 00326 and HPE 00392 and HPE 00450 and HPE 00453 Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

CourseTitle: Teaching Concepts of Dance in Physical Education
Description: HPE 00316 - Teaching Concepts of Dance in Physical Education Credits: 3 This course introduces health and exercise science majors specializing in teacher certification to the skills, concepts and knowledge necessary for instructing development and performance sequences in various rhythmic activities (creative rhythms, routines with small hand apparatus, and novelty dances) and dance forms (folk, social, square, contra, and line).  The study of selected rhythmic activities and dance forms include: terminology, relative movement patterns, techniques, skill performance, evaluation, basic musical structure, and teaching strategies. Prerequisite Courses: HPE 00286 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00240 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00252 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00270 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: ARTL, CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

CourseTitle: Teaching Concepts of Health Education I
Description: HPE 00325 - Teaching Concepts of Health Education I Credits: 3 This is the first in a series of two combined pedagogy and health education content courses which provide students with knowledge along with general scope and understanding of current health issues which occur in the human lifecycle. This course also develops an understanding of the competencies essential for planning school health education programs. Students are given learning opportunities to develop sensitivity for the importance of integrating health education in various settings and to address the New Jersey Core Curriculum Content Standards for Comprehensive Health and Physical Education (Standards 2.1 through 2.4) Actual lesson planning and teaching experiences are required. Topics which will be addressed are Alcohol, Tobacco and Other Drugs, Personal Growth and Development, Mental and Emotional Health, Aging and Death and Dying. Prerequisite Courses: HPE 00252 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00240 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00270 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

CourseTitle: Teaching Concepts of Health Education II
Description: HPE 00326 - Teaching Concepts of Health Education II Credits: 3 This is the second in a series of two combined pedagogy and health education content courses which provide students with knowledge along with general scope and understanding of current health issues which occur in the human lifecycle. This course also develops an understanding of the competencies essential for planning school health education programs. Students are given learning opportunities to develop sensitivity for the importance of integrating health education in various settings and to address the New Jersey Core Curriculum Content Standards for Comprehensive Health and Physical Education (Standards 2.1 through 2.4). Actual lesson planning and teaching experiences are required. Topics which will be addressed are Family Life and Human Sexuality, Personal Health, Chronic and Infectious Diseases, Environmental Health and Consumerism. Prerequisite Courses: HPE 00316 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00452 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00336 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00325 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

CourseTitle: Teaching Concepts of Elementary Physical Education
Description: HPE 00336 - Teaching Concepts of Elementary Physical Education Credits: 3 This course is an introductory survey course designed to help prepare health and exercise science teacher certification majors to teach relevant curriculum at the elementary school level. Students will be exposed to a number of important activities that comprise the focus of elementary school physical education. Methods, techniques and classroom management as they apply to teaching pertinent curriculum will be highlighted. Prerequisite Courses: HPE 00286 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

CourseTitle: Clinical Experience in Teaching Health and Physical Education
Description: HPE 00392 - Clinical Experience in Teaching Health and Physical Education Credits: 1 This course introduces students to the nature and operation of elementary and secondary schools.  Students learn to organize instructional materials into meaningful daily lessons in both health and physical education.  The course emphasizes the development of teaching strategies, classroom management techniques and use of educational media.  The field experience involves observation, tutoring, microteaching and practice in a variety of other instructional skills.  Field assignments are sought that involve the pre-service teacher in a realistic mainstreamed classroom environment.  As application for Clinical Experience must be submitted and approved through the Office of Educator Support and Partnerships. Prerequisite Courses: HPE 00316 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00336 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00452 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00325 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, CE, EXIN, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

CourseTitle: K-12 Health and Physical Education Curriculum and Instruction
Description: HPE 00450 - K-12 Health and Physical Education Curriculum and Instruction Credits: 3 K-12 Physical Education Curriculum and Instruction is a critical course designed to help prepare Health and Exercise Science majors to become successful physical education teachers in schools. Teacher candidates will develop expertise in curriculum construction, planning, instruction and evaluation in elementary, middle and high school. In developing this expertise, candidates will address the NJ Core Curriculum Content Standards for Comprehensive Health and Physical Education (Standards 2.1, 2.5 and 2.6). Prerequisite Courses: HPE 00316 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00336 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00452 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00325 with a minimum grade of D- Corequisite Courses: HPE 00392 Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

CourseTitle: Teaching Concepts of Adapted Physical Education
Description: HPE 00452 - Teaching Concepts of Adapted Physical Education Credits: 3 This course is designed to provide health and physical education teacher candidates with the knowledge and basic skills required to meet the professional and legal mandates pertaining to general physical education for students with unique needs, between ages 3 to 21. The course will focus on the law, placement decisions, assessment, individualized general physical education programming, service delivery, transition planning for individuals with disabilities, professionalism in the workplace, and awareness of the strengths and limitations of those with disabilities and methods for inclusion. This course includes instruction in modifying sports and games, dance, lifetime fitness, and aquatics. The course includes a lab component and completion of clinical experience hours. Prerequisite Courses: HPE 00286 with a minimum grade of D- (may be taken concurrently) and HPE 00240 with a minimum grade of D- Corequisite Courses: HPE 00316 and HPE 00325 and HPE 00336 Course Attributes: CAT, CE, EXIN, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

HPE 00453 - School Health Program Planning Credits: 2 This course develops an understanding of the competencies essential in planning of health programs in schools. Students are given opportunities for integrating and correlating health in K-12 school settings.  Field experiences, planning and teaching experiences are a part of this course. Prerequisite Courses: HPE 00316 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00336 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00452 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00325 with a minimum grade of D- Corequisite Courses: HPE 00392 Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

CourseTitle: Clinical Practice I in Health & Physical Education:  Elementary
Description: HPE 00457 - Clinical Practice I in Health & Physical Education:  Elementary Credits: 2 This course further develops teacher candidates knowledge of the operation of elementary schools.  Candidates will work under the guidance and direction of an experienced elementary health and physical education teacher.  Candidates will develop an understanding of teacher evaluation through the Danielson Framework for Teaching, and prepare for conducting their performance assessment (edTPA) in Clinical Practice II.  A minimum of 54 hours will be spent in an elementary school setting.  An application for Clinical Practice must be submitted and approved through the Office of Educator Support and Partnerships. Prerequisite Courses: HPE 00310 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00453 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00392 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00326 with a minimum grade of D- Corequisite Courses: HPE 00458 and HPE 00459 Course Attributes: CAT, EXIN, SEM1, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

CourseTitle: Clinical Practice I in Health and Physical Education:  Secondary
Description: HPE 00458 - Clinical Practice I in Health and Physical Education:  Secondary Credits: 2 This course further develops teacher candidates knowledge of the operation of secondary schools.  Candidates will work under the guidance and direction of an experienced secondary health and physical education teacher.  Candidates will develop an understanding of teacher evaluation through the Danielson Framework for Teaching, and prepare for conducting their performance assessment (edTPA) in Clinical Practice II.  A minimum of 54 hours will be spent in a secondary school setting.  An application for Clinical Practice must be submitted and approved through the Office of Educator Support and Partnerships. Prerequisite Courses: HPE 00310 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00392 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00453 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00326 with a minimum grade of D- Corequisite Courses: HPE 00457 and HPE 00459 Course Attributes: CAT, EXIN, SEM1, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

CourseTitle: Assessment Seminar in Health and Physical Education
Description: HPE 00459 - Assessment Seminar in Health and Physical Education Credits: 3 This course runs concurrently with Clinical Practice I.  It will prepare teacher candidates in the Health and Physical Education program to use a variety of resources, including technology, for planning and developing assessment strategies to evaluate student learning.  It is also designed to prepare students for completing their major performance assessment portfolio (edTPA) during Clinical Practice II.  Candidates will use the cycle of planning, instruction and assessment, to prepare them to be reflective practitioners.  AN introduction to simple statistical designs will also be a component of this course. Prerequisite Courses: HPE 00310 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00453 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00392 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00326 with a minimum grade of D- Corequisite Courses: HPE 00457 and HPE 00458 Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

CourseTitle: Clinical Practice II in Health and Physical Education: Elementary
Description: HPE 00460 - Clinical Practice II in Health and Physical Education: Elementary Credits: 5 This course allows teacher candidates to intern on a full time basis under the guidance and direction of an experienced elementary health and physical education teacher.  Teacher candidates gain experience and develop insight and skill in the teaching of elementary school health and physical education.  An application for Clinical Practice must be submitted and approved through the Office of Educator Support and Partnerships. Prerequisite Courses: HPE 00457 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00458 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00459 with a minimum grade of D- Corequisite Courses: HPE 00461 and HPE 00465 Course Attributes: CAT, EXIN, SEM2, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

CourseTitle: Clinical Practice II in Health and Physical Education: Secondary
Description: HPE 00461 - Clinical Practice II in Health and Physical Education: Secondary Credits: 5 This course allows teacher candidates to intern on a full time basis under the guidance and direction of an experienced secondary health and physical education teacher.  Teacher candidates gain experience and develop insight and skill in the teaching of secondary school health and physical education.  An application for Clinical Practice must be submitted and approved through the Office of Educator Support and Partnerships. Prerequisite Courses: HPE 00459 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00457 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00458 with a minimum grade of D- Corequisite Courses: HPE 00460 and HPE 00465 Course Attributes: CAT, EXIN, SEM2, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

CourseTitle: Professional Seminar in Health and Physical Education
Description: HPE 00465 - Professional Seminar in Health and Physical Education Credits: 2 This senior-level capstone course is designed to be taken concurrently with Clinical Practice II.  The seminar will focus on:  understanding the current issues in teaching health and physical education; evaluating the application of effective teaching; understanding the parameters of professional and ethical behaviors in teaching; and preparing for a career in the field. Prerequisite Courses: HPE 00459 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00458 with a minimum grade of D- and HPE 00457 with a minimum grade of D- Corequisite Courses: HPE 00460 and HPE 00461 Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

CourseTitle: Curriculum and Assessment in Adapting Physical Activity
Description: HPE 00552 - Curriculum and Assessment in Adapting Physical Activity Credits: 3 This course is designed to provide adapted physical activity specialists with the knowledge and basic skills required to assess children with disabilities for their physical education needs, make a referral, work with a team to set goals, plan individualized instruction, and advocate for children with disabilities in special education settings. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

HPE 00553 - Community-Based Adapted Physical Activity Credits: 3 This course is designed to provide adapted physical activity specialists with the knowledge and basic skills required to provide appropriate and safe community-based adapted physical activity programming. Prerequisite Courses: HPE 00552 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

CourseTitle: Pathology of Disability for the Adapted Physical Activity Specialist
Description: HPE 00554 - Pathology of Disability for the Adapted Physical Activity Specialist Credits: 3 This course is designed to provide adapted physical activity specialists with the knowledge and basic skills required to: (1) understand and interpret basic medical terminology; (2) list and describe characteristics of all 14 categories of disabilities listed by IDEA and the NJ DOE; (3) list modifications for physical activity participation for individuals with disabilities listed by IDEA/ NJ DOE plus several adult onset disabilities; and (4) discuss general causations, diagnostic procedures, and treatments for a variety of disabilities especially in ages 3-21. Prerequisite Courses: HPE 00552 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

CourseTitle: Introduction to Health and Physical Education
Description: HPE 02210 - Introduction to Health and Physical Education Credits: 1 to 3 This course will introduce teacher candidates to core educational instructional practices and pedagogies in health and physical education. Students will be asked to critically examine teaching in health and physical education-specific content that spans across grade spans, with an emphasis on students ability to develop, and identifies effective strategies and approaches to support the meaningful participation and learning of diverse students. Emphasis will be placed on creating inclusive and diverse educational environments in health and physical education. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Content Area Teacher Education

CourseTitle: Introduction to Health and Science Communication
Description: HSC 08100 - Introduction to Health and Science Communication Credits: 3 Students are introduced to the ways in which people communicate about health and illness, environmental risk, and science policy. This is the required introductory course for the program in the Health and Science Communication (HSC). The course is open to non-majors. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- (may be taken concurrently) or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D- (may be taken concurrently) or ENGR 01201 with a minimum grade of D- (may be taken concurrently) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CourseTitle: Health and Science Communication Learning Community
Description: HSC 08101 - Health and Science Communication Learning Community Credits: 1 The Health and Science Learning Community will introduce HSC students to the major, extracurricular activities, and career pathways. It will also allow students to develop community with their peers. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

HSC 08200 - Developing Health and Scientific Literacy Credits: 3 Developing Health and Scientific Literacies will help students navigate scientific and medical scholarship to better understand cutting edge research into issues that affect all of humanity, such as climate change and genetic engineering. In this course, students will learn to identify, evaluate, and report on scholarly sources, gaining comfort with reading and understanding technical language. Students will learn about how scientific and medical scholarship is produced and circulated, and what institutions, practices, and ethical standards influence those processes. Students will practice reading and summarizing scholarly sources, as well as translating them for lay audiences. Students will also learn to engage health and scientific scholarship for its intersections with social concerns and communal values. Prerequisite Courses: COMP 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or HONR 01112 with a minimum grade of D- or ENGR 01201 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CourseTitle: Special Topics in Health and Science Communication
Description: HSC 08350 - Special Topics in Health and Science Communication Credits: 3 This course will allow students studying Health and Science Communication the opportunity to investigate specific topics areas within these major disciplines. The course will be made up of lectures, class discussions, and a variety of assignments involving health and science communication. Areas of study would cover major trends and other developments within these disciplines, such as climate change, nanotechnology, genetics, or the cultural competence of health communication. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CourseTitle: Senior Seminar in Health and Science Communication
Description: HSC 08450 - Senior Seminar in Health and Science Communication Credits: 3 In this seminar students will integrate what they have learned as Health and Science Communication majors by creating a culminating, researched project. Students will produce a work that draws on the theoretical foundations of the field, that demonstrates a keen understanding of their audience, and that follows disciplinary standards and reflects their chosen concentrations. Students will share their final products during a symposium where they will  represent their work visually and orally. Prerequisite Courses: ( HSC 08100 with a minimum grade of D- and HSC 08200 with a minimum grade of D-) and ( CMS 04350 with a minimum grade of D- or CMS 04390 with a minimum grade of D- or PR 06310 with a minimum grade of D- or JRN 02363 with a minimum grade of D- or WA 01201 with a minimum grade of D-) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Communication Studies

CourseTitle: Program Planning and Leadership in Health Promotion and Wellness
Description: HPW 00340 - Program Planning and Leadership in Health Promotion and Wellness Credits: 3 This course identifies and explains the components of a successful health promotion program. Students learn how to conduct a needs assessment, set goals and objectives, design intervention strategies, promote the program, find resources, prepare a budget and evaluate a program. In addition, students sharpen their professional skills related to public speaking, time management and business writing. Prerequisite Courses: HPW 00350 with a minimum grade of C Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, UGRD Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

HPW 00350 - Health Behavior Theory and Counseling Credits: 3 This course examines the factors that influence an individuals choices and behaviors related to health and the process of motivating change within the individual to adopt healthful behaviors and discontinue unhealthful ones. Several theories of health behavior are examined and applied. The different roles of the client and educator are addressed as the student is prepared to counsel others in making positive health behavior changes. Prerequisite Courses: HPW 00210 with a minimum grade of C- or HLT 00200 with a minimum grade of C or NUT 00230 with a minimum grade of C- or HES 00105 with a minimum grade of C- Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, UGRD Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

HPW 00351 - Wellness Coaching Seminar Credits: 1 This course provides students an opportunity to learn and practice Wellness Coaching skills and Motivational Interviewing strategies that were introduced in HPW 00350  Health Behavior:  Theory and Practice.  Building upon the foundational content of prior coursework, students will have an opportunity to apply basic wellness coaching skills and receive individualized, constructive feedback on their skills.  In addition, students will learn and practice more advanced coaching skills related to Powerful Questioning and different types of Reflection Statements designed to elicit internal motivation within a coaching client. Prerequisite Courses: HPW 00350 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

CourseTitle: Facility and Program Management in Wellness
Description: HPW 00360 - Facility and Program Management in Wellness Credits: 3 This course examines the skills necessary to effectively manage a health promotion facility and program through the study of the health and fitness facility management industry. Topics include training and managing staff, marketing programs and services, customer service, financial management, legal concerns, equipment selection and health and safety issues. Prerequisite Courses: HPW 00210 with a minimum grade of C- or HLTH 37310 with a minimum grade of C- or HES 00105 with a minimum grade of C- or HLT 00200 with a minimum grade of C- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

CourseTitle: Practicum in Health Promotion and Wellness Management
Description: HPW 00430 - Practicum in Health Promotion and Wellness Management Credits: 3 This is an application-oriented course in which students design and implement a health promotion/ fitness program for the Rowan community. While the major emphasis is on the implementation of the program, students continue to meet weekly to discuss and evaluate their progress. Specific topics related to the field, such as legal liability and resume preparation are also addressed. In addition, students complete a formal evaluation of their professional qualities and skills for the health promotion and fitness field. Prerequisite Courses: ( HPW 00340 with a minimum grade of C- or HLTH 37340 with a minimum grade of C-) and (PHED 35343 with a minimum grade of C- or HES 00343 with a minimum grade of C-) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

HCNV 07401 - Inter-professional Teamwork in Healthcare Credits: 2 This seminar course will provide students from various healthcare disciplines with opportunities to work together to develop skills needed to engage in inter-professional collaborative practice. Students will complete pre-work online and then attend meetings with other healthcare disciplines to develop care plans for patient cases. Specific, but not limited to, areas of study include ethics for inter-professional practice, roles and responsibilities of healthcare providers, inter-professional communication strategies and developing quality healthcare teams to enhance patient outcomes. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

HCM 51101 - Introduction to Healthcare Management Credits: 3 This introductory course discusses the roles of patients, physicians, hospitals, insurers, and pharmaceutical companies within the context of healthcare and the interaction among these groups.  Students will be introduced to resource management, managing people, complex systems, and processes within healthcare services in the changing environment of healthcare delivery and services. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Professional Studies

HCM 51201 - Healthcare Informatics Credits: 3 Healthcare management professionals need to know information management practices within healthcare delivery systems. This course will cover a variety of data management strategies and security practices that conform to HIPPA in various healthcare settings, including: in hospitals, clinics, doctors offices, nursing homes, pharmacies, insurance companies, to improve healthcare quality, respond to regulations, and contain costs.  Additional topics will include, ethical issues and the patient record, electronic health records (EHRs), data collection standards, legal aspects of health information, medical coding, and reimbursement. Prerequisite Courses: HCM 51101 with a minimum grade of D- (may be taken concurrently) or HLT 00200 with a minimum grade of D- (may be taken concurrently) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Professional Studies

HCM 51204 - Healthcare Marketing Credits: 3 This course introduces healthcare professionals to marketing fundamentals and applications in their healthcare organizations, and connects marketing principles to innovation, operations and strategy in the healthcare industry. This course is designed to focus on what drives health care consumers needs and their choices. Making use of these insights and taking into account a companys constraints and the competitive environment, firms can come up with new products/services or modify their existing portfolios to serve unmet needs. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Professional Studies

HCM 51255 - Data Analytics in Healthcare Management Credits: 3 This introductory level course provides foundational skills and knowledge in healthcare data analytics that will acclimate students with the use of technology in the capture, delivery, and analysis of health data. The course focuses on the use of electronic health records, data mining, statistical collection of health data, quality data management, report generation and health data project management that enables decision-making. Students will also focus on information governance strategies in the healthcare field and information planning throughout a healthcare organization. Students will analyze clinical information and data to identify trends of quality, safety, and effectiveness of healthcare. Prerequisite Courses: HCM 51101 with a minimum grade of D- or HLT 00200 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Professional Studies

HCM 51280 - Healthcare Law and Ethics Credits: 3 This course introduces students to the laws, regulations, and ethical principles governing structure, delivery, and reimbursement in health services industry. Emphasis is placed on analysis of the legal and healthcare environment and its relationship to medical ethics. The course examines the legal aspects of the relationship between the patient and the obligations of health care service providers. Students will learn about the structure and forces impacting the U.S. Healthcare system and examine case studies to identify and respond to legal and ethical issues. Additionally, the health information management profession, the role of health informatics, and the role of technology in todays healthcare environment will be discussed. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Professional Studies

HCM 51301 - Healthcare Delivery and Quality Credits: 3 This course provides an overview of the health care system, delivery of care, and the quality of care.  Parts of the course will emphasize payment, delivery, and emerging health care issues including:  quality measurement, patient safety, and technological advancement and understanding incentives that drive health care quality and delivery decisions such as financing, public programs, consumer safety, and economic incentives in health care. The course will emphasize the impact of various federal and state implications for providers, payers, and consumers within larger healthcare systems  and understand, analyze, evaluate options and best practices for addressing health care delivery and quality issues. Prerequisite Courses: HCM 51201 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Professional Studies

HCM 51327 - Consumer Health Decisions Credits: 3 This course examines the rights and responsibilities of a consumer faced with increasing amounts of information related to his or her overall well-being. It examines the major problem of health fraud and the components of scientific research. The role of advertising is explored, as well as sound principles for purchasing nutrition, fitness and other health-related products and services. Students learn important concepts related to health insurance and hospitals, traditional and alternative medical care and how to better manage the decisions they make. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Professional Studies

HCM 51329 - Research Methods for Healthcare Managers Credits: 3 This course introduces basic methods for undertaking research and program evaluation within health services organizations and systems. The course develops the basic skill of critically analyzing research findings and the role and scope of research as it relates to the support of decision making. Research methods are introduced with emphasis placed on analyzing key elements of research reports as a basis for determining the appropriateness of the research results for evidence-based health services practice. Students examine the basic components required to conduct health-related research and are provided with the analytic tools needed to understand and assess research methods described in the scientific literature. They will also propose, design, and conduct a small research project, work collaboratively and effectively with other people to meet a common goal, and present their research findings through written and oral communication. Prerequisite Courses: HCM 51101 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Professional Studies

HCM 51344 - Strategic Management in Healthcare Credits: 3 Students will learn key principles of strategic management within a broadly-defined health care setting to include the ongoing planning, monitoring, analysis, negotiating, problem solving, and decision making necessary within a risk-based environment.  The course examines strategic management and the role of managers at every level of healthcare organizations designed to meet organizational goals and objectives within healthcare enterprises including: public health organizations, physician practices and clinics, hospitals and health systems, agencies and service organizations, for-profit firms, and not-for-profits. Prerequisite Courses: HCM 51101 with a minimum grade of D- and HCM 52101 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Professional Studies

HCM 51351 - Healthcare Finance and Decision Making Credits: 3 This course examines the current system of financing care within the healthcare industry related to the revenue cycle, disbursement, budgeting/forecasting, internal control, financial reporting, contract management, reimbursements, budgeting/forecasting, and financial reporting within the healthcare industry in order to use data to make financial decisions. Prerequisite Courses: ACC 03405 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Professional Studies

CourseTitle: Healthcare Management and Administration Internship I
Description: HCM 51488 - Healthcare Management and Administration Internship I Credits: 3 The Internship I course provides students the opportunity for a meaningful healthcare management career-related experience in a variety of organizational settings. It is expected that students will practice and expand upon their knowledge and skills learned in the classroom in a substantive healthcare environment. This experience should provide a better understanding of healthcare organizations to facilitate the transition from the classroom to the career environment. While each placement will have a unique opportunities, students will be expected to complete 120 clock hours as part of this experience. Prerequisite Courses: ( HCM 51301 with a minimum grade of D- (may be taken concurrently) or HCM 51351 with a minimum grade of D- (may be taken concurrently)) and HCM 51101 with a minimum grade of D- and ( MGT 98242 with a minimum grade of D- or HCM 51280 with a minimum grade of D-) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Professional Studies

CourseTitle: Healthcare Management and Administration Internship II
Description: HCM 51489 - Healthcare Management and Administration Internship II Credits: 3 Prerequisite Courses: HCM 51488 with a minimum grade of D- Academic Department: Professional Studies

HCM 51498 - Advanced Topics in Healthcare Management Credits: 3 This course examines a variety of emerging healthcare administration topics.  These topics are drivers of the industry that impact quality, cost transparency, consumers, strategic planning, implementation, privacy, public policy, legal regulations, labor relations, and the role of leadership in overcoming the challenges of managing the cost of healthcare. Prerequisite Courses: HCM 51101 with a minimum grade of D- and HCM 51329 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Professional Studies

HIED 06602 - Higher Education Research and Assessment Credits: 3 The ability to recognize, evaluate, utilize and carry out research in diverse settings and with diverse populations is essential for successful student affairs educators and higher education administrators. With increasing accountability, it is incumbent on educators to find ways of better informing their practice through various assessment methods. Understanding and learning how to conduct assessment, research, and program evaluations provide an invaluable means of accomplishing this goal. The course emphasizes educational research and assessment in higher education settings. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Educational Leadership, Administration & Research

HIED 06605 - Higher Education in America Credits: 3 This course focuses on issues and trends within higher education regarding institutional mission, the student body, curriculum, faculty, student services, governance, administration, finance, and community service (including economic development). The course will examine the challenges and opportunities confronting higher education. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Educational Leadership, Administration & Research

HIED 06606 - Selected Topics in Higher Education Credits: 3 This course explores a topic of importance in the field of higher education. The focus will be different each time that the course is offered. Examples of courses that might be offered include: Crisis Management, New Directions in Financial Aid; Outcomes Assessment; Distance Learning; State Higher Education Systems; Federal Policy and Higher Education; Student Activism. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Educational Leadership, Administration & Research

HIED 06607 - Higher Education Administration Credits: 3 This course introduces students to the fundamentals of administration in the higher education setting. Topics include authority and power, implementation of institutional policy, decision-making in higher education, conflict resolution, staff supervision, and program assessment. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Educational Leadership, Administration & Research

HIED 06614 - College Student Development Credits: 3 This course will focus on contemporary college student development theories. We will explore and understand the nature, culture, and development of college students in the United States. The course will examine a range of developmental theories offering insight into the processes of student learning, growth, and development during the college years. There will be an emphasis on exploring the historical, philosophical, and theoretical foundations of student development theory related to student affairs practice. Additionally, special focus will be directed towards understanding the implications of these models for the policies and practices of higher education and student affairs administration as well as the possibilities, limitations, and barriers for enacting student development theory in practice. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Educational Leadership, Administration & Research

HIED 06615 - Academic Advising in Higher Education Credits: 3 The purpose of this course is to provide students with an in-depth exploration of academic advising on college campuses.  Students will gain a broad view of the role and function of academic advising.  Specifically, students will learn about the historical development of academic advising; the role of academic advising in the multiple academic settings (community colleges, four year universities, special mission institutions); and how to assist students in planning their academic processes.  This course will provide students with relevant skills and understanding of current research, models, and considerations for working with diverse and special populations.  The readings, discussions, and assignments are intended to provide information for student affairs professionals, administrators, or faculty members. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Educational Leadership, Administration & Research

CourseTitle: Planning and Resource Allocation in Higher Education
Description: HIED 06616 - Planning and Resource Allocation in Higher Education Credits: 3 This course will teach students practical approaches to strategic and operational planning in higher education, as well as how to develop budgets that are driven by institutional mission and that support the institutional plan. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Educational Leadership, Administration & Research

HIED 06617 - Diversity in Higher Education Credits: 3 The purpose of this course is to provide students with an in-depth exploration of diverse populations on college campuses. Students will utilize a broad view of diversity, including race, ethnicity, gender, religious and spiritual values, sexual orientation, socioeconomic  status, disability status, and age, as well as unique characteristics of various ethnic and cultural groups that affect college students and campuses. This course will provide students with relevant skills and understanding of current theories, models, and issues within diverse populations and community building on diverse campuses. The readings, discussions, and assignments are intended to provide information for student affairs professionals, administrators, or faculty members. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Educational Leadership, Administration & Research

HIED 06618 - Procedures and Evaluation in Research Credits: 3 The course helps students develop an understanding of research and statistics sufficient to enable them to read and evaluate research, and develop and carry out full scale research projects. Prerequisite Courses: HIED 06602 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Educational Leadership, Administration & Research

HIED 06620 - Legal Issues in Higher Education Credits: 3 This course examines the legal principles that guide the administration of higher education. Students will study current and emerging legal issues in higher education, focusing primarily on student rights, student life, and general administration legal concepts. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Educational Leadership, Administration & Research

HIED 06626 - Crisis Management in Higher Education Credits: 3 This course provides an introduction to both theories of and practical approaches to managing crises within higher education and student affairs. This course also helps students to understand the definition of crises as well as the magnitude of crises impacting higher education (including but not limited to environmental, facility, and human crises). Through exploring past and recent case studies, the course will help students evaluate how institutions have handled various crisis situations. In addition, students will have the opportunity to analyze current literature on crisis management and to learn from student affairs leaders with expertise in this area. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Educational Leadership, Administration & Research

CourseTitle: Seminar/Supervised Practice in Higher Education I
Description: HIED 06628 - Seminar/Supervised Practice in Higher Education I Credits: 3 This course is the first of a two course sequence which is intended to serve as the capstone experience for the M.A. program in higher education. Students will utilize a workplace in a higher education setting as a laboratory to study the application of higher education administrative theory to practice and to begin work on a major capstone research project. Prerequisite Courses: HIED 06618 with a minimum grade of D- or EDST 24501 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Educational Leadership, Administration & Research

CourseTitle: Seminar/Internship in Higher Education Administration II
Description: HIED 06629 - Seminar/Internship in Higher Education Administration II Credits: 3 This course is the second of a two course sequence which is intended to serve as the capstone experience for the M.A. program in higher education. Students will utilize a workplace in a higher education setting as a laboratory to study the application of higher education administrative theory to practice and to complete work on a major capstone research project. Prerequisite Courses: HIED 06628 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Educational Leadership, Administration & Research

MHP 00610 - Basic Laboratory Techniques-Biology Credits: 3 This course will teach students the most basic techniques used in a modern biomedical laboratory, to prepare them to integrate these techniques into more advanced processes they will use later. *This course is only open to students in the Masters in Histopathology program.* Prerequisite Courses: MBS 00501 with a minimum grade of C and MBS 00502 with a minimum grade of C Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Translational Biomedical Engineering & Sciences

MHP 00611 - Histology I: Basic Tissue Types Credits: 3 This course introduces students to the basic tissue types, as well as some of the common stains used to differentiate elements of tissue. In addition, students will learn to use a microscope and analyze photomicrographs critically. *This course is only open to students in the Histopathology and Anatomical Sciences programs.* Prerequisite Courses: MBS 00501 with a minimum grade of C and MBS 00502 with a minimum grade of C) or ANS 00501 with a minimum grade of C Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Translational Biomedical Engineering & Sciences

MHP 00612 - Histology II: Techniques Credits: 4 This lab-intensive course builds upon the theory learned in Histology I: Basic Tissue Types. Students will be trained in histological techniques in a hands-on setting, in order to develop the critical skills required to become a histotechnologist. Students will learn to section various animal tissue utilizing a microtome and cryostat, and perform basic staining procedures. *This course is only open to students in the Masters in Histopathology program.* Prerequisite Courses: MHP 00610 with a minimum grade of C and MHP 00611 with a minimum grade of C Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Translational Biomedical Engineering & Sciences

MHP 00613 - Histology III: Organ Systems Credits: 3 In this course, students will apply their knowledge of tissue types to develop an understanding of organ structure and function. This will include information specific to commonly used animal models (e.g. rats, mice, rabbits). *This course is only open to students in the Histopathology and Anatomical Sciences programs.* Prerequisite Courses: MHP 00611 with a minimum grade of C and MBS 00503 with a minimum grade of C Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Translational Biomedical Engineering & Sciences

MHP 00614 - Basic Laboratory Animal Techniques Credits: 4 This basic animal techniques course will teach students mouse colony management and preclinical research techniques. This course is lab-intensive. Students will receive one-on-one instruction for each of the indicated skills listed in the syllabus. This format will allow students to develop basic skills in managing a mouse colony and processing of tissues. *This course is only open to students in the Masters in Histopathology program.* Prerequisite Courses: MHP 00610 with a minimum grade of C and MHP 00611 with a minimum grade of C and MHP 00612 with a minimum grade of C Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Translational Biomedical Engineering & Sciences

MHP 00615 - Advanced Animal Techniques Credits: 4 This advanced animal techniques course will reinforce what students learned about basic mouse colony management and teach students advanced preclinical research techniques. This course is lab-intensive. Students will receive one-on-one instruction for each of the indicated skills listed in the syllabus. This format will allow students to develop advanced animal research skills, including the ability to perform various surgical procedures and familiarity with a variety of mouse models of disease. *This course is only open to students in the Masters in Histopathology program. Prerequisite Courses: MHP 00614 with a minimum grade of D- and MHP 00610 with a minimum grade of D- and MHP 00612 with a minimum grade of D- and MHP 00611 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Translational Biomedical Engineering & Sciences

MHP 00616 - Topics in Pathology Credits: 2 This course will provide students with exposure to the pathology of major organ systems. *This course is only open to students in the Histopathology and Anatomical Sciences programs.* Prerequisite Courses: MBS 00503 with a minimum grade of D- and MHP 00611 with a minimum grade of D- Corequisite Courses: MHP 00613 Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Translational Biomedical Engineering & Sciences

MHP 00640 - Histopathology Independent Study Credits: 3 This course introduces students to the use of histopathology techniques in research by preparing a review of published scholarly literature on a topic of their own interest. With the guidance of a faculty advisor, students will identify a suitable topic and develop the skills of literature research, writing, revision, and oral presentation. Students will prepare an essay of at least 6,000 words that presents the current understanding of the topic aimed at an audience of professionals. The student will also prepare an oral presentation which will be delivered at the end of the semester. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Translational Biomedical Engineering & Sciences

MHP 00650 - Histopathology Internship Credits: 3 Students will perform internships at affiliate sites throughout the semester in order to build upon their basic histological techniques in various histology lab settings. The grading for this 3 credit course is Pass/Fail. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Translational Biomedical Engineering & Sciences

MHP 00690 - Histopathology Thesis Research Credits: 9 The Histopathology program trains students in hundreds of hours of hands-on lab training in histology, pathology, molecular biology, and lab animal techniques. The goal of this course is to enhance the development of Masters students for jobs in research laboratories (academic and industry) and to enter PhD programs by giving them an opportunity to utilize the technical skills they mastered in years 1 and 2 of the program to a research project. Students will work on a research project under the direction of a faculty mentor, thesis advisory committee, and the program directors. Prerequisite Courses: MBS 00501 with a minimum grade of D- AND MBS 00502 with a minimum grade of D- AND MCBN 00910 with a minimum grade of D- AND MBS 00503 with a minimum grade of D- AND MHP 00610 with a minimum grade of D- AND MHP 00611 with a minimum grade of D- AND MHP 00612 with a minimum grade of D- AND MHP 00614 with a minimum grade of D- AND MBS 00609 with a minimum grade of D- AND MHP 00615 with a minimum grade of D- AND MHP 00613 with a minimum grade of D- AND MHP 00616 with a minimum grade of D- AND MHP 00650 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: GRAD Academic Department: Translational Biomedical Engineering & Sciences

HIST 00490 - Seminar in Global Health Perspectives Credits: 3 This advanced seminar  focuses on the juxtaposition of global health issues from a cultural perspective through a lens of diversity and equity. The intention is for students to concentrate attention to global health issues from various  perspectives considering how the historical, political and social dynamics intertwine.  The culminating project of the course will be a paper or project that demonstrates an in depth understanding of the cultural significance of a chosen topic. Prerequisite Courses: HLT 00355 with a minimum grade of D- and ( HLT 00302 with a minimum grade of D- or ANTH 02355 with a minimum grade of D- or ANTH 02215 with a minimum grade of D-) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Health & Exercise Science

CourseTitle: The West in the World to 1600
Description: HIST 05100 - The West in the World to 1600 Credits: 3 This course examines the entanglements of European peoples and nations in the region and wider world before 1600. It emphasizes cultural, social, intellectual, political and economic transformations, and interactions with other parts of the world from neolithic times to the 17th century. This course introduces students to the principles and methodology of history. Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, GNED, HHL, HUML, UGRD Academic Department: History

CourseTitle: The West in the World since 1600
Description: HIST 05101 - The West in the World since 1600 Credits: 3 This course examines the entanglements of European peoples and nations in the region and wider world after 1600. It emphasizes cultural, social, intellectual, political and economic transformations, and interactions with other parts of the world from the 17th century to the present. This course introduces students to the principles and methodology of history. Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, GNED, HHL, HUML, UGRD Academic Department: History

HIST 05110 - History of Now Credits: 3 This course introduces students to the importance of history in todays world, allows them to explore how history is made, and encourages them to develop analytical skills.  Students will have the opportunity to do history by encountering and interpreting documents and artifacts from the past, and they will consider how history affects their own daily lives.  The thematic focus will change from semester to semester. Course Attributes: CAT, HUML, UGRD Academic Department: History

HIST 05120 - World History since 1500 Credits: 3 This course studies the key changes in the patterns of interaction among the major cultures of the earth from the beginnings of European Expansion in the 1500s. The course covers the roots of European Expansion, the response of the Confucian, modern, and non-Eurasian cultures, and the emergence of a non-Western Third World Block since 1914. Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, GLBL, GNED, HHL, MCUL, UGRD Academic Department: History

HIST 05150 - United States to 1865 Credits: 3 This course examines the historical roots of the American democratic traditions, with the emphasis on understanding the political, social and cultural forces developed in the new physical setting of North American and finally welded into a unified nation. Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, GNED, HHL, HUML, UGRD Academic Department: History

HIST 05151 - United States since 1865 Credits: 3 This course analyzes the principal political, social and cultural factors conditioning the life of the nation since the Civil War. It emphasizes the issues facing modern America with the impact of industrialization and the problems of world leadership. Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, GNED, HHL, HUML, UGRD Academic Department: History
