After a review of the fundamentals, Music Theory I begins the study of diatonic harmony, tonal sight singing, and melodic dictation.  Admission by departmental examination or successful completion of MUS 04118 Music Fundamentals and MUS 04110 Sight Singing and Ear Training. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 04110 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 04118 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04104 - Music Theory II Credits: 4 A detailed and integrated study of written music theory and aural skills.  Music Theory II covers diatonic harmony, tonal sight singing, and melodic and harmonic dictation. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 04103 with a minimum grade of C- or ( MUS 04130 with a minimum grade of C- and MUS 04132 with a minimum grade of C-) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04110 - Sight Singing and Ear Training Credits: 2 The techniques of singing at sight, solfeggio, and taking dictation are reviewed and applied. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04118 - Music Fundamentals Credits: 3 This course leads to a broader understanding of music through study of its basic elements: melody, rhythm, harmony and form. Course Attributes: ACE, CAT, GNED, RE, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04119 - Composition Workshop Credits: 1 Composition Workshop is a composition community that provides forum for feedback and performance of original works within a community of music composers. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04129 - Jazz Improvisation Credits: 1 to 2 This course presents the blues scale, major, and minor scales/chords for a thorough understanding of the blues form. Students learn the fundamentals of improvisation through performance and written composition. Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Music
MUS 04140 - Wind Ensemble Credits: 0 to 1 Variable credit is given to those students who participate. Course Attributes: ACE, GNED, RE, UGRD Academic Department: Music
MUS 04152 - Saxophone Ensemble Credits: 0 to 1 Variable credit is given to those students who participate. Course Attributes: ACE, GNED, RE, UGRD Academic Department: Music

CourseTitle: Music Composition and Theory for Media I
Description: MUS 04190 - Music Composition and Theory for Media I Credits: 3 This course introduces students to materials and techniques of contemporary musical composition through their application in the digital audio workstation. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 04118 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

CourseTitle: Intro to Diction and I.P.A.: English and Latin
Description: MUS 04201 - Intro to Diction and I.P.A.: English and Latin Credits: 1 “Intro to Diction and IPA: English and Latin” is a fundamental course designed to acquaint the student with the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) and its symbols used in classical repertoire.  Students will immerse themselves in understanding, reading, writing and using IPA.  The class will also cover the correct pronunciation of Latin and English consonants and vowels and the lyric diction rules of these languages. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04202 - Language Through Vocal Repertoire (Italian) Credits: 1 Study of the phonetic rules and sounds of the classical pronunciations of Italian as found in Art Song and Opera.  The International Phonetic Alphabet is utilized.  Singing and class performance is required. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04203 - Language Through Vocal Repertoire (French) Credits: 1 Study of the phonetic rules and sounds of the classical pronunciations of French as found in Art Song and Opera.  The International Phonetic Alphabet is utilized.  Singing and class performance is required. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04204 - Language Through Vocal Repertoire (German) Credits: 1 Study of the phonetic rules and sounds of the classical pronunciations of German as found in Art Song and Opera.  The International Phonetic Alphabet is utilized.  Singing and class performance is required. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04216 - Music Theory III Credits: 4 A detailed and integrated study of written music theory and aural skills.  Music Theory III covers chromatic harmony and continues the study of tonal sight singing and melodic and harmonic dictation. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 04104 with a minimum grade of C- or ( MUS 04131 with a minimum grade of C- and MUS 04133 with a minimum grade of C-) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04217 - Music Theory IV Credits: 4 A detailed and integrated study of written music theory and aural skills.  Music Theory IV covers musical form, 20th century techniques, tonal and atonal sight singing, and melodic and harmonic dictation. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 04216 with a minimum grade of C- or ( MUS 04240 with a minimum grade of C- and MUS 04242 with a minimum grade of C-) Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04244 - Sophomore Proficiency Credits: 0 The Sophomore Proficiency is a performance given in front of a faculty jury. Students must pass the Sophomore Proficiency in order to enter the fifth semester of applied lessons. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

CourseTitle: Music Composition and Theory for Media II
Description: MUS 04290 - Music Composition and Theory for Media II Credits: 3 A continuation of MUS 04190, Composition and Theory for Media II continues the study of materials and techniques of contemporary musical composition in the digital environment. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 04190 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04329 - Junior Recital Credits: 0 The Junior Recital is the recital performance culminating six semesters of applied lessons for performance majors. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 04244 with a minimum grade of P Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04333 - Stage Band Rehearsal Techniques Credits: 3 For music majors only, required in the Jazz Studies and Jazz Education Program and may be elected by others. The course examines the history of big bands, interpretation and conducting for different styles and eras. Score reading, score preparations and high school level rehearsal techniques are examined. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04361 - Arranging for Large/Small Jazz Ensembles Credits: 3 This course provides the experience of writing for the traditional big band and jazz studio orchestra, as well as a small number of instruments. Students explore the possibilities with voicings, chord selection and compositional structures used in the aforementioned ensembles. In addition, contemporary compositional techniques are introduced to encourage the continuation of the ensembles in jazz music of the 21st century. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04363 - Writing In Contemporary/Traditional Jazz Styles Credits: 3 Students explore contemporary and traditional jazz styles by listening to and analyzing the music of masters such as Chick Corea, Miles Davis, Duke Ellington, Sammy Nestico along with songs from the be-bop, hard-bop and cool eras. Students compose scores in this style for performance in class and in Department of Music jazz concerts. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04403 - Choral Arranging Credits: 2 Students explore the art of arranging songs for choral groups with or without accompaniment. Music for different choral ensembles is written, rehearsed and sung by the class. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04404 - Orchestration Credits: 2 Characteristics of string, wind and percussion instruments (including harp) are examined through lectures and demonstrations. Transcriptions for ensembles and orchestra are made from piano music and performed in class. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04409 - Small Group Jazz Ensemble Credits: 0 to 1 Small Group Jazz Ensembles are designed to help students develop the skills necessary to perform in performer led ensembles. The ensembles range in size from three to six performers and rehearse once a week for fifty minutes. All groups perform in two concerts per semester. In the small group jazz ensemble students acquire the skills necessary to perform standard and original composition with and without the aid of written arrangements. All students are involved in choosing repertoire, creating arrangements, and leading rehearsal and performances. Course Attributes: ARTL, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04410 - Vocal Jazz Ensemble Credits: 1 This ensemble is designed to help students develop the skills necessary to perform in performer-led ensembles. Students will acquire the skills necessary to perform standard and original compositions with and without the aid of written arrangements. A variety of current styles will be examined as well as aspects of form, lyrics, melody and harmony in modern songwriting. Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Music
MUS 04412 - Independent Study Credits: 0.5 to 4 Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04430 - Senior Recital Credits: 0 The Senior Recital is the recital performance culminating eight semesters of applied lessons for majors in the Bachelor of Music programs. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 04244 with a minimum grade of P Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04450 - Form and Analysis Credits: 3 An in-depth study and examination of musical scores from various style periods with an emphasis on large-scale forms and structures. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04455 - Counterpoint Credits: 3 This course is a study of the principles of constructing a multilinear musical texture and the application of those principles analytically to music literature. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music
MUS 04476 - Music Composition VIII Credits: 3 Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04536 - Chamber Music I Credits: 1 The study and performance of selected repertoire for specific instrumental groups and combinations. Students will be assigned to a small ensemble and will be required to rehearse and to perform the chosen repertoire in a public setting. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04537 - Chamber Music II Credits: 1 The study and performance of selected repertoire for specific instrumental groups and combinations. Students will be assigned to a small ensemble and will be required to rehearse and to perform the chosen repertoire in a public setting. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04540 - Jazz Arranging and Composition Credits: 3 The course presents techniques in arranging and composition in the jazz idiom and is tied to the course CD Project in that it coordinates the needs of the second course through preparation in Jazz Arranging and Composition. Students will be required to arrange and orchestrate existing compositions and compose original music in the jazz idiom. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04541 - Jazz Piano Credits: 1 This course in applied music for the non-pianist focuses on the basic keyboard skills needed by the professional jazz musician, especially the use of the piano to realize harmonic progressions and concepts. The student must have passed the piano proficiency exam before enrolling for this course. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04545 - Opera Role Study I Credits: 3 A complete opera role from the standard repertoire will be learned and performed in each semester through private instruction and coaching, either in staged or unstaged, in public. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04546 - Opera Role Study II Credits: 3 A complete opera role from the standard repertoire will be learned and performed in each semester through private instruction and coaching, either in staged or unstaged, in public. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04551 - Piano Accompanying I Credits: 1 This course in applied piano accompanying will pair the student with a vocal or instrumental student under the supervision of the piano instructor. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04552 - Piano Accompanying II Credits: 1 This course in applied piano accompanying will pair the student with a vocal or instrumental student under the supervision of the piano instructor. Course Attributes: GRAD Academic Department: Music
MUS 04555 - Counterpoint Credits: 3 The principles of counterpoint and its practical application in musical literature are studied. Academic Department: Music
MUS 04556 - Independent Study Credits: 0.5 to 4 Course Attributes: GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04557 - Advanced Orchestration Credits: 3 This course will introduce the conducting student to the practical considerations of performance on orchestral instruments and their use in orchestral repertoire. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04560 - Form and Analysis Credits: 3 The course presents important contemporary approaches to the analysis and understanding of music of all periods including those of the present. Students will present analyses of works appropriate to their graduate level studies in their major area. This is a required course for all students in the master of music program. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04561 - Score Reading I Credits: 1 This course begins training the conducting student to read orchestral scores, including the mastery of clefs and transposition. It is a requirement for the Master of Music in Instrumental Conducting. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04562 - Score Reading II Credits: 1 This course continues training the conducting student to read orchestral scores, including the complete mastery of clefs and transposition, and the study of score reductions. It is a requirement for the Master of Music in Instrumental Conducting. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04565 - Seminar in Band Conducting Credits: 3 This course will involve classroom discussion, research, and scholarly presentations of topics related to the business of conducting, where students will share their views with other students and the facilitator. The class will visit rehearsals of professional organizations and bands and will interview known professionals in the field. A lecture presentation by each student on a relevant conducting topic will conclude the semester. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04570 - 20th Century Literature and Techniques Credits: 3 This course explores 20th century music and the compositional techniques it embodies. Emphasis will be upon important trends and developments that are still current in the music of today. Each student will present his/her own research in this area of study as it relates to their major area of study. This is a required course for the master of music in composition. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUS 04590 - Music Education Graduate Applied Credits: 2 A study of the major instrument in pursuit of developing ones musicianship in order to support their music teaching practice. Specific course goals will be co-created by the student and instructor. This course is only available to graduate students in the MMEd program and is able to be repeated for a maximum total of 6 credits. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUS 08100 - Wind Ensemble Credits: 0 to 1 The Wind Ensemble is the universitys premier wind band, performing difficult and challenging repertoire. Membership is by audition only. Instructor permission required for 0-credit option. This is a designated Major Ensemble. Course Attributes: ACE, ARTL, CAT, GNED, RE, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 08108 - String Ensemble Credits: 0 to 1 The String Ensemble performs a variety of chamber music repertoire. Instructor permission required for 0-credit option. With pre-approval of the Faculty Ensemble Committee, this ensemble can serve as a major ensemble. Course Attributes: ACE, ARTL, CAT, GNED, RE, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 08116 - College Band Credits: 0 to 1 The College Band is open to all Rowan students and performs a wide variety of wind band repertoire. Instructor permission required for 0-credit option. This is a designated Major Ensemble. Course Attributes: ACE, ARTL, CAT, GNED, RE, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 08124 - Jazz Band Credits: 0 to 1 The Jazz Band performs and explores the history of the traditional and contemporary Big Band repertoire such as Duke Ellington, Count Basie, Woody Herman, Stan Kenton, Maynard Ferguson, Buddy Rich, Bob Mintzer and more. Instructor permission required for 0-credit option. This is a designated Major Ensemble. Course Attributes: ACE, ARTL, CAT, GNED, RE, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 08132 - Orchestra Credits: 0 to 1 The Orchestra performs a wide range of symphonic orchestral repertoire and is open by audition only. Instructor permission required for 0-credit option. This is a designated Major Ensemble. Course Attributes: ACE, ARTL, CAT, GNED, RE, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 08148 - Concert Choir Credits: 0 to 1 The Concert Choir is the universitys premiere vocal ensemble. Course Attributes: ACE, ARTL, CAT, GNED, RE, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 08156 - Contemporary Music Ensemble Credits: 0 to 1 Dedicated to the performance of new music, this ensemble performs the works of Rowan composition students and other contemporary composers. MUS 08180 - Flute Ensemble Credits: 0 TO 1 The Flute Ensemble explores repertoire composed for flute choir. Instructor permission required for 0-credit option. MUS 08188 - Opera Company Credits: 0 to 1 The Opera Company is designed to give singers the opportunity to develop and refine singing/acting skills through the study of operatic literature. Students will present the assigned literature in a staged performance at the end of the semester. Solo roles by audition. The opera chorus is open to all without audition. Previous choral experience is suggested. Instructor permission required for 0-credit option. With pre-approval of the Faculty Ensemble Committee, this ensemble can serve as a major ensemble. Course Attributes: ACE, ARTL, CAT, GNED, RE, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 08193 - Opera Company Credits: 0 to 1 The Opera Company is designed to give singers the opportunity to develop and refine singing/acting skills through the study of operatic literature. Issues such as accompanying melody, accompanying soloists and vocalists, setting up introductions, chord melody presentation, voicing with other chord instruments, leading endings, starting songs, reading chord symbols and single lines are extensively analyzed and mastered. Instructor permission required for 0-credit option. With pre-approval of the Faculty Ensemble Committee, this ensemble can serve as a major ensemble. Course Attributes: ARTL, CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 08236 - Composition Workshop Credits: 1 Composition Workshop is a composition community that provides forum for feedback and performance of original works within a community of music composers. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 08252 - University Chorus Credits: 0 to 1 University Chorus is a mixed-voice ensemble that is open to all majors from the entire campus community who have previous choral experience. Literature is varied and representative of all periods of Western music including contemporary compositions and non-Western genres. Performances are scheduled throughout each semester and may include collaborations with other ensembles. In addition to performance, there is an emphasis on improving sight-singing, diction, and ensemble skills. Instructor permission required for 0-credit option. With pre-approval of the Faculty Ensemble Committee, this ensemble can serve as a major ensemble. Course Attributes: ACE, ARTL, CAT, GNED, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 08255 - University Chorus Credits: 0 to 1 University Chorus is a mixed-voice ensemble that is open - by audition - to all majors from the entire campus community. Literature is varied and representative of all periods of Western music including contemporary compositions and non-Western genres. Performances are scheduled throughout each semester and may include collaborations with other ensembles. In addition to performance, there is an emphasis on improving sight-singing, diction, and ensemble skills. Instructor permission required for 0-credit option. With pre-approval of the Faculty Ensemble Committee, this ensemble can serve as a major ensemble. Course Attributes: ACE, ARTL, GNED, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 08260 - Chamber Choir Credits: 1 to 99 Chamber Choir, commonly referred to as Cantati Tutti, is a mixed-voice ensemble that is open to every musician from the entire campus community without audition.  The aim of the choir is to facilitate access to music making at a high level of artistry through singing together as a community, utilizing non-traditional repertoire and performance practices.  This course is open to music majors, non-majors, all members of the university community including faculty and staff, and includes alumni and community members and welcomes singers at all musical skill levels. Course Attributes: ACE, ARTL, CAT, GNED, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 08265 - Chamber Choir Credits: 1 to 99 Chamber Choir, commonly referred to as Cantati Tutti, is a mixed-voice ensemble that is open to every musician from the entire campus community without audition. MUS 08268 - Marching Band Credits: 0 to 1 Students rehearse and perform as members of the Rowan University Marching Band for home football games, select off-campus events, and other special presentations. Instruction will focus on the techniques of both instrumental music performance and marching/movement. Instructor permission required for 0-credit option. Marching Band can serve as a Major Ensemble for instrumental music majors (only once per student); however, students must be enrolled concurrently in another Major Ensemble. NOTE: Attendance at a pre-season band camp prior to the start of fall semester classes is required. Course Attributes: ARTL, CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 09106 - Symphonic Band Credits: 0 to 1 The Rowan University Symphonic Band is an ensemble for woodwind, brass and percussion players. Repertoire performed is representative of the finest in wind literature, including musical styles from the Renaissance through today. Innovative programming allows student-musicians to perform and interact with Rowans outstanding faculty, visiting guest artists, and composers from around the world. Instructor permission required for 0-credit option. With pre-approval of the Faculty Ensemble Committee, this ensemble can serve as a major ensemble. Course Attributes: ARTL, CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 09114 - String Orchestra Credits: 0 to 1 String Orchestra is for students who have some experience with the violin, viola, cello or double bass, but who are not music majors. The orchestra will rehearse twice a week and give one public concert each semester. No audition is necessary. Instructor permission required for 0-credit option. 
This course may be repeated. Course Attributes: ARTL, CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 10573 - Graduate String Orchestra Credits: 0 to 1 Graduate String Orchestra is for students who have some experience with the violin, viola, cello or double bass, but who are not music majors. The orchestra will rehearse each week and give one concert per semester. No audition necessary. This course may be repeated. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUS 32218 - Vocal Pedagogy Credits: 3 Basic principles and techniques of training the solo voice are addressed in this course.  A survey of the history of vocal pedagogy, the anatomy of the voice and resource materials for teaching voices of all ages included.  Students will experience practical training in teaching voice through class demonstration.  Recommended for vocal majors at junior level and above. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 04103 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 32219 - Piano Pedagogy Credits: 1 Method books for beginners and elementary students are examined and compared.  The pedagogy of piano technique and interpretation is emphasized.  Must be preceded by freshman and sophomore piano class or waiver of these requirements.  This course may not be offered annually. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 32220 - Instrumental Pedagogy Credits: 1 The focus of this course is on the practical application of teaching solo repertoire in a one-on-one instruction setting. A brief survey of pedagogy is included. The majority of the course consists of practical instrumental pedagogy training through class demonstration. Recommended for instrumental music majors at a junior level or above. This course meets for 50 minutes each week. This course may not be offered annually. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40111 - Business of Music I Credits: 3 The student will be able to learn about the commercial aspects of the music business; introduces music students to music publishing, music copyright laws, music licensing, artist management, recording industry, music in advertising, etc. Field trips play a very important role in the development of this course. Finally, the students will be made aware of careers in music other than music education and performance. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40113 - Business of Music II Credits: 3 This course is a continuation of Business of Music I. Record deals, touring, promotion, publishing, and copyright are studied in more detail. Research and analysis of music-industry business models are introduced. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 40111 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40121 - Audio Recording I Credits: 3 This course explores the techniques of audio recording. A study of equipment, microphones and microphone placement, sequencing programs and acoustics is integrated with hands-on training. Students actually record and produce finished products of recorded music or speech. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40122 - Computer Technology and Music I Credits: 3 This course focuses on the development of the students skills in using digital audio software to create and edit audio files, repair field recordings, mix multi-track arrangements, synchronize audio and video, and perform other creative sound design techniques.  Projects in these software environments are designed to develop fundamental musicianship, creativity, and a refined aesthetic sensibility. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40201 - History of Popular Music Credits: 3 A survey of the history and influence of popular music on modern culture, particularly in the United States and United Kingdom. Students will learn about how music has evolved, influenced, and been influenced by popular culture in the 20th and 21st centuries. Course Attributes: ACE, ARTL, CAT, GNED, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40202 - Introduction to Music Performance Credits: 3 This course will provide a basic introduction of the typical performance skills utilized by performance ensembles. Students will participate in a variety of workshops and performances and learn how each popular instrument is played (including guitar, bass, piano, drums, stings, and wind instruments  as well as percussion workshops). In-class performances will teach performance skills such as how to develop a stage presence, using body language, handling a microphone, and dealing with unexpected situations during a live performance. This course culminates in a  final concert. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40211 - Music Industry Internship I Credits: 3 This internship course provides students with field experience in the music industry. Under professional supervision, students practice theories and skills learned in the classroom and learn professionalism that will prepare them for productive employment upon graduation. Students keep a detailed log of working hours, write an analytical critique of the practicum, begin building a professional network, and are evaluated by their faculty supervisor and employer exit survey. The learning process is monitored by Music Industry program faculty members. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 40111 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40113 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, EXIN, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40212 - Music Publishing Credits: 3 The course provides an in-depth view of the music publishing industry. Topics covered include copyrights, publishing contracts, songwriter deals, how to register musical work, collection royalties, and revenue streams. This business aspects of music writing and composition are covered, as is a brief history of music publishing industry. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 40111 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40113 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40213 - Touring and Concert Promotion Credits: 3 This course provides an in-depth view of the touring and concert promotion industry. Topics covered include bookings, ticketing, planning a tour, promotion, working with key players in the industry, logistics, contracts, and more. Students will participate in the production of a live concert. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 40111 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40113 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40221 - Audio Recording II Credits: 3 In this course, students make a recorded project using advanced recording techniques. Topics include advanced microphone techniques, compressor types, classic EQ models, effects and professional standards for digital audio recording, mixing and delivery formats. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 40121 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40222 - Computer Technology and Music II Credits: 3 In this course, students make a recorded project using advanced recording techniques. Topics include advanced microphone techniques, compressor types, classic EQ models, effects and professional standards for digital audio recording, mixing and delivery formats. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 40122 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40223 - Survey of Record Production Credits: 1 This course provides an overview of how records have been produced in the United States and United Kingdom from the 1950s to today. Topics include technological advances in the audio recording field, key record producers and their ‘sounds,” the role of the producer, and record production techniques. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40311 - Music Industry Internship II Credits: 3 This internship course provides students with a second field experience in the music industry. Under professional supervision, students practice theories and skills learned in a classroom and learn professionalism that will prepare them for productive employment upon graduation. Students keep a detailed log of working hours, write analytical critique of the practicum, begin building a professional network, and are evaluated by their faculty supervisor and employer exit survey. The learning process is monitored by Music Industry program faculty members. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 40111 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40113 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40211 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, EXIN, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40314 - Artist Services I Credits: 2 This course is the first section of a three-term course sequence that also includes Artist Services II and Artist Services III. It provides the hands-on experience of working at a record company. Learning activities include choosing a band for a record release, developing an image for the project and managing the recording production. Students take on the roles and responsibilities of the real record-label positions, and these roles are emphasized at all stages of the record-production process. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 40111 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40113 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40315 - Entrepreneurship in the Music Industry Credits: 3 This course provides an in-depth view of the major technological disruptions and the ensuring business opportunities that have shaped the music industry, from wax cylinder to vinyl record, cassette, CD, MP3, and Internet streaming services, with a particular focus on how the digital age has utterly transformed the music industry. Comprehensive research and analysis of current and cutting-edge music business models and marketing strategies complete this course curriculum. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 40111 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40113 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40212 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40321 - Producing the Record Credits: 3 This course is the continuation of Audio Recording I and Audio Recording II. Students apply record production techniques learned in previous terms in a hands-on settings by producing an album in partnership with a band. Learning activities include choosing a band to record, pre-production tasks, managing a recording studio schedule and budget, recording a band, managing musicians during recording sessions, overdubbing, and analog mixing a mastering. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 40121 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40221 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40322 - Audio for Video Credits: 3 Students will develop and understanding of the technology, business, and function of music as it pertains to various types of linear, non-linear and interactive visual media through studying the technical, creative, and post-production processes of real-world projects and through hand-on projects of their own. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 40122 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40222 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40323 - Sound Reinforcement I Credits: 3 This course gives students the skill sets to understand and operate professional sound-reinforcement systems for live music and theatre performances. Topics covered include live audio mixing, sound systems, venues, audio equipment, microphone techniques for live situations, and how to work with artists, management, and venue personnel. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 40121 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40221 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40331 - Game Audio Credits: 3 Students will develop an understanding of technology, composition techniques, and sound design concepts that are unique to the video game industry through real-world projects and analyses of popular game titles. Classroom learning will come to life as students compose music and create custom sound effects in an actual video-game engine. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 40122 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40222 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40332 - Recording Studio Design and Maintenance Credits: 3 Students will learn to perform basic recording studio repairs and will develop and understanding of acoustics and studio design. The topics covered in this course include cables, connectors, transformers, power supplies, sound absorption, diffusion, and room acoustics. By the end of the course, students will be able to identify the sources of common signal path disruptions, read electronics schematics, and perform basic repairs as well as choose and install sound treatment in a recording-studio setting. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 40121 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40221 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40333 - Sound Synthesis and Remixing Credits: 3 The main objective of this course is to develop an understanding of sound synthesis, sampling, and remixing through in-class demonstrations, lectures, and hands-on projects. This course gives students in-depth instruction and experience in the various advanced techniques of MIDI sequencing, digital audio recording, editing, and mixing used in the making of modern pop, dance, and hip-hop recordings. Students will deliver custom-made synthesizer sounds, a sampling kit, and a remix integrating all aspects of the course. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 40122 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40222 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40335 - Sound Reinforcement II Credits: 3 Sound Reinforcement II is an advanced elective designed to enhance skills learned in Sound Reinforcement I and further explore the technical knowledge needed for a career in live sound.  Learn the various types of sound systems used in venues today and what changes are being made in the near future.  Understand the skills and tools needed for system design and optimization.  Study the industry trends that are advancing in the field including networking audio and RF coordination.  Research and design a sound system for a venue. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 40121 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40221 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40323 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40341 - Music Industry Contracts and Copyrights Credits: 3 This course provides an in-depth view of music industry contracts and copyright issues. Topics covered include an advanced study of major record deals, independent record deals, touring contracts, music copyrights, publishing deals, and agreements between band members. Students will learn to protect their interests and avoid common problems. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 40111 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40113 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40212 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

CourseTitle: Public Relations in the Music Industry
Description: MUS 40342 - Public Relations in the Music Industry Credits: 3 This course provides an in-depth view of the public relations of the music industry, covering the skills involved in creating and distributing effective press release, press kits, and artist kits, cultivating relationships for radio and tour promotion, and canny social media management and internet communications techniques. Public Relations in the Music Industry addressed these topics from various points of view. Whether you want to become a PR agent or a recording artist, tour promoter, or label owner, among other roles, this course offers valuable insights on this vital function of the music industry. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 40111 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40113 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40343 - Songwriting Credits: 3 This course provides skills and knowledge related to writing a pop song. Students will analyze songs, hooks, rhythm, chord progressions, melodies, arrangements, and lyrics to understand what makes a hit. Students will be required to write and perform their own original songs and workshop the music and lyrics within the context of the class, working toward finished songs as class projects. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 40122 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

CourseTitle: Hip Hop Culture:  Music, Lifestyle, Fashion and Politics
Description: MUS 40344 - Hip Hop Culture:  Music, Lifestyle, Fashion and Politics Credits: 3 The main objectives of this course are to discuss the origins of Hip Hop culture and study its influence around the world.  Students will explore the key elements of Hip Hop, understand the importance and necessity of entrepreneurship and analyze how the Hip Hop Culture has evolved into a dominant force over the years.  Students will examine the impact that Hip Hop has on fashion by helping to catapult the sales and positioning of major fashion and sneaker brands as well as creating independent clothing lines by way of entrepreneurship.  The course will discuss and analyze the unprecedented effects and influence that Hip Hop has on global lifestyles, language, and politics. Course Attributes: ARTL, CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

CourseTitle: Capstone Project in Music Industry I
Description: MUS 40412 - Capstone Project in Music Industry I Credits: 2 This capstone course is required of all Music Industry majors in their senior years and leads into Capstone Project in Music Industry II (MUS 40413). This two-semester hands-on-project integrates the material covered in Music Industry courses with practical experience, so that students can integrate various elements of their learning into career-related experience. It also affords students an opportunity to complete a complex, realistic project where they must utilize and hone skills from their coursework and internships. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

CourseTitle: Capstone Project in Music Industry II
Description: MUS 40413 - Capstone Project in Music Industry II Credits: 2 This capstone course is required of all Music Industry major in their senior years and is a continuation of Capstone Project in Music Industry I (MUS 40412). This two-semester hands-on project integrates the material covered in Music Industry courses with practical experience, so that students can integrate various elements of their learning into career-related experience. It also affords students an opportunity to complete a complex, realistic project where they must utilize and home skills from their coursework and internships. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 40412 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40414 - Artist Services II Credits: 2 This course is the second section of a three-term course sequence that includes Artist Services I and Artist Services III. It provides the hands-on experience of working at a record company. Learning activities include managing the recording production, developing an album artwork and creating a marketing strategy, as well as analyzing industry trends. Students take on the roles and responsibilities of real record-label positions, and these roles are emphasized at all stages of the record-release process. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 40111 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40113 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40314 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40415 - Artist Services III Credits: 2 This course is the final section of a three-term course sequence that also includes Artist Services I and Artist Services II. It provides the hands-on experience of working at a record company; at the end of the third term, students release and launch their record. Learning activities include managing the mix and mastering of an album, marketing activities, and record launch, as well as analyzing industry trends. Students take on the roles and responsibilities of real record-label positions, and these roles are emphasized at all stages of the record-release process. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 40111 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40113 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40314 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40414 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 40431 - Mixing and Mastering Credits: 3 This course builds upon the skills acquired in Computer Technology and Music I (MUS 401220) and Computer Technology and Music II (MUS 40222). Topics includes an advanced look at mixing music for a wide range of music styles, sound trends, processing. EQing, setting up levels, panning, automation, and using effects such as reverb and delays in professional and creative ways. The mastering section of the course emphasizes understanding audio signal quality, loudness, processing. EQing and how to achieve a professional master for various formats such as CD, MP3, and vinyl record. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 40122 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 40222 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 50509 - Music Education Workshop Credits: 2 to 3 Students will engage in hands-on, active music making and learning connected to a variety of topics and content areas in music education. All workshops will emphasize practical application of content to music teaching settings. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

CourseTitle: Special Topics Seminars in Music Education
Description: MUS 50510 - Special Topics Seminars in Music Education Credits: 3 Seminars will focus on special topics designed to reflect contemporary and changing practices and concerns in the field of music education. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUS 50511 - Research Methods in Music Education Credits: 3 Research in Music Education Course Description: In this introductory course, students will explore and analyze music education research in several research paradigms. Students will learn to locate, digest, and apply the research literature in music education to their own practice, as well as prepare an action research proposal for potential implementation in their school setting. Students will also focus on building skills that allow them to write in a clear and concise manner and within APA guidelines. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

CourseTitle: Social and Psychological Environments of Music Learning
Description: MUS 50540 -  Social and Psychological Environments of Music Learning Credits: 3 This course is focused on the psychological and sociological foundations of music education, and how theory influences research and curriculum in the field.  Different perspectives in the field of music education will be explored and discussed in terms of how these theories operate in current practice. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUS 50610 - Masters Final Presentation and Project Credits: 3 Students have the option of completing a capstone final project or a thesis. The nature and structure of the capstone project will be proposed by the student (to be approved by the faculty) and may include a curriculum project, a literature review, or other artifact that connects theory to practice. Both capstone options will be completed under the supervision of a faculty member and will require a public presentation of the work as a criteria for program completion. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUS 50621 - Masters Thesis in Music Education Credits: 3 This course is taken at the end of the masters program in music education, and provides the student with the opportunity to write and defend a masters thesis based on original scholarship and publish it. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUS 50630 - Equity, Access, and Music Education Credits: 3 This course is focused on topics related to equity and access as it relates to the field of music education.  Literature related to issues of social justice, critical pedagogy, and inclusion will be explored and discussed in terms of current practices and issues in the field. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUS 50650 - Philosophy of Music Education Credits: 3 This course is focused on the philosophical discourses that influence education in general and music education specifically.  Taking both local-historical and global perspectives, students will critique and critically examine the purpose and role of music education in communities and schools. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUS 50660 - Innovation in Curriculum and Instruction Credits: 3 In this course we will explore the issues related to developing music curricula for students in grades PK-12, in music teacher education programs, and beyond. Together we will consider what, why, how, and who we teach through historical, philosophical, psychological, and sociological lenses, and gain a deeper understanding of educational policy and its impact on curricula. Students will examine and evaluate existing frameworks, assessment tools, and instructional strategies, and design their own individualized curriculum unit/project. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUS 50670 - Global Musics in Education Credits: 3 The purpose of this course is to acquaint students with the many musics of the world, to provide strategies for its use in the music classroom, and to facilitate an understanding of the study of music and culture. The three strands of the course, world music, world music pedagogy, and ethnomusicology, will be addressed through reading, listening, planning, presenting, and discussing course content. Upon completion of this course, one will be to able to accurately identify musical characteristics of a variety of musics, utilize a culturally informed approach to teaching world music, and incorporate ethnomusicological fieldwork methods to explore an unfamiliar musical culture. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

CourseTitle: Diversity, Inclusion, and Antiracism in Music Theory Pedagogy
Description: MUS 50680 - Diversity, Inclusion, and Antiracism in Music Theory Pedagogy Credits: 3 In this course, students will explore current trends towards equity and antiracism in music theory pedagogy. Students will examine critiques of the “traditional” undergraduate/AP theory curriculum, evaluate various perspectives towards music theory teaching, and develop their own lesson and course plans that incorporate curricular revisions. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUS 97100 - Piano Class I Credits: 1 Instruction is given in classes including sight reading, improvising, and playing by ear. These courses must be taken in sequence, simultaneously with or after the indicated theory courses: Piano Class I (MUS97.100) with or after Written Theory I (MUS04.130); Piano Class II (MUS97.101) with or after Written Theory II (MUS04.131); Piano Class III (MUS97.200) with or after Written Theory III (MUS04.240), and Piano Class IV (MUS97.241) with or after Written Theory IV (MUS04.217). Not open to non-music majors. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 97101 - Piano Class II Credits: 1 Instruction is given in classes including sight reading, improvising, and playing by ear. These courses must be taken in sequence, simultaneously with or after the indicated theory courses: Piano Class I (MUS97.100) with or after Written Theory I (MUS04.130); Piano Class II (MUS97.101) with or after Written Theory II (MUS04.131); Piano Class III (MUS97.200) with or after Written Theory III (MUS04.240), and Piano Class IV (MUS97.241) with or after Written Theory IV (MUS04.217). Not open to non-music majors. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 97100 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 97102 - Piano I for Non-Music Majors Credits: 3 Beginning piano taught in a class. No previous experience in music is necessary. For Non-Music Majors. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music
MUS 97111 - String Class-Low Credits: 1 The fundamentals of cello and bass are studied. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 97112 - String Class-High Credits: 1 Fingering and bowing patterns, tone production, tuning, methods and materials are studied for the violin and viola. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music
MUS 97116 - Woodwind Class Credits: 1 This course focuses on teaching the fundamentals of woodwind instruments pedagogy in the instrumental music classroom. Academic Department: Music

MUS 97117 - Brass Class Credits: 1 This course focuses on teaching the fundamentals of brass instruments pedagogy in the instrumental music classroom. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music
MUS 97118 - String Class Credits: 1 This course focuses on teaching the fundamentals of string pedagogy in the instrumental music classroom. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 97119 - Instrumental Lab Credits: 1 This course focuses on teaching the fundamentals of woodwind, brass, and string pedagogy at the 4-12 grade level in a laboratory ensemble setting. By Performing in a laboratory ensemble setting, students learn to curate music based on the needs of their ensemble, conduct, perform, and rehearse an instrumental music ensemble. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 97200 - Piano Class III Credits: 1 Instruction is given in classes including sight reading, improvising, and playing by ear. These courses must be taken in sequence, simultaneously with or after the indicated theory courses: Piano Class I (MUS97.100) with or after Written Theory I (MUS04.130); Piano Class II (MUS97.101) with or after Written Theory II (MUS04.131); Piano Class III (MUS97.200) with or after Written Theory III (MUS04.240), and Piano Class IV (MUS97.241) with or after Written Theory IV (MUS04.217). Not open to non-music majors. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 97101 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 97201 - Piano Class IV Credits: 1 Instruction is given in classes including sight reading, improvising, and playing by ear. These courses must be taken in sequence, simultaneously with or after the indicated theory courses: Piano Class I (MUS97.100) with or after Written Theory I (MUS04.130); Piano Class II (MUS97.101) with or after Written Theory II (MUS04.131); Piano Class III (MUS97.200) with or after Written Theory III (MUS04.240), and Piano Class IV (MUS97.241) with or after Written Theory IV (MUS04.217). Not open to non-music majors. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 97200 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 97212 - Conducting-Instrumental I Credits: 2 This course demonstrates and rehearses the skills of instrumental conducting through music for instrumental ensembles. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 97213 - Conducting-Choral I Credits: 2 This course is an introduction to the art of choral conducting.  Gestural techniques, (preparation, pattern, cues, releases, fermata, expression, and left-hand independence), are developed through class participation and other ensemble situations. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 97228 - Classroom Guitar Credits: 1 This course is designed to enable classroom teachers to utilize and instruct basic guitar techniques with an emphasis on accompaniment skills. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music
MUS 97229 - Guitar Class I Credits: 3 A study of the guitar performance and a study of the materials available. Course Attributes: ARTL, CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music
MUS 97230 - Guitar Class II Credits: 3 A continuation of the study of the guitar through performance and a study of the materials available. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music
MUS 97300 - French Horn Class Credits: 0.5 Designed for Music Education majors, this course addresses horn pedagogy and basic horn performance. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 97301 - Trombone Class Credits: 0.5 Designed for Music Education majors, this course addresses trombone pedagogy and basic trombone performance. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 97302 - Percussion Class Credits: 1 A study of rudimental and ensemble techniques of snare drum, timpani, bass drum, cymbals and accessory instruments. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 97309 - Trumpet Class Credits: 0.5 Designed for Music Education majors, this course addresses trumpet pedagogy and basic trumpet performance. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music
MUS 97310 - Tuba Class Credits: 0.5 Designed for Music Education majors, this course addresses tuba pedagogy and basic tuba performance. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 97312 - Conducting-Instrumental II Credits: 2 This course demonstrates and rehearses the skills of instrumental conducting through music for instrumental ensembles. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 97212 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 97313 - Conducting-Choral II Credits: 2 Students apply basic conducting techniques to repertoire spanning each of the major time periods.  In addition to gesture, great emphasis is given to score reading and score analysis skills. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 97213 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 97400 - Voice Class Credits: 1 A study of the basic principles of singing taught in a group setting.  Students will learn beginners breathing technique, tone placement and projection through the singing of group and solo repertoire.  Course is open to non-music majors. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music
MUS 97401 - Bassoon Class Credits: 0.5 This course teaches the fundamentals of the bassoon. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 97402 - Clarinet Class Credits: 0.5 Designed for Music Education majors, this course addresses clarinet pedagogy and basic clarinet performance. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 97403 - Saxophone Class Credits: 0.5 Designed for Music Education majors, this course addresses saxophone pedagogy and basic saxophone performance. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music
MUS 97409 - Flute Class Credits: 0.5 Designed for Music Education majors, this course addresses flute pedagogy and basic flute performance. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music
MUS 97410 - Oboe Class Credits: 0.5 Designed for Music Education majors, this course addresses oboe pedagogy and basic oboe performance. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98101 - Foundations of Music Therapy Credits: 3 Develop an understanding of the methodological and theoretical foundations of this discipline.  Learn how to use music as a therapeutic tool to treat a variety of clients, as well as the sociological, psychological, and philosophical theories of music. Course Attributes: CAT, GCAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98102 - Principles of Music Therapy I Credits: 3 In Principles of Music Theory I students will learn to interact with people who have learning, neurological, motor, and medical problems.  Students will need to focus on music therapy literature specific for this group of people and be ready to apply their theoretical studies to clinical work. Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98103 - Music Therapy Practicum I Credits: 1 This course will provide an opportunity for students to acquire supervised experience using music therapy, including assessment, treatment planning, evaluation, and other aspects that support clinical practice.  Students will complete a total of 60 supervised clinical hours as part of this course. Course Attributes: EXIN, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98104 - Therapeutic Principles for Music Therapists Credits: 1 This course focuses on understanding of therapeutic principles and the therapeutic relationship that are at the basis of music therapy treatment.  Topics covered are foundational to music therapy, focusing on therapeutic principles underlying music therapy.  These include awareness of personal motivation and values in therapy, dynamics and process of the therapeutic relationship, awareness of ethical issues in therapy, group dynamics, multicultural awareness and applications to therapy, and theories underlying various approaches to therapy. Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98105 - Clinical Piano Skills I Credits: 2 Students learn piano skills needed to implement music therapy in clinical settings.  Includes harmonization, accompanying in various styles, and various styles of improvisation.  Course includes application of musical concepts and terminologies, such as modes, idioms, styles, scales, and various musical forms into clinical scenarios. Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98106 - Clinical Guitar Skills Credits: 2 This course is designed to enable students to accompany themselves and to lead others in the singing of simple folk and popular songs, progressing from simple strumming and finger picking to more advanced accompaniment patterns, transposition and the use of the capo. Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Music

CourseTitle: Music Applications to Music Therapy I
Description: MUS 98107 - Music Applications to Music Therapy I Credits: 1 This course will provide an opportunity for music therapy students to apply the music skills that they are learning in other courses (music and music therapy) to the type of musical situations that they will encounter as music therapists.  Skills to be practiced include leading songs using simple accompaniment styles, playing and singing songs of basic music therapy repertoire using Q-chord, autoharp, and percussion instruments, and sight reading basic music therapy repertoire. Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98108 - Psychology of Music Credits: 3 This course will provide an opportunity for students to learn about psychological foundations of music, including neurology and the brain, music cognition and perception, emotional meaning of music, musical development and learning, and testing for musical ability.  Students will be expected to apply the knowledge acquired in this course in music therapy, music education, and other musical interests. Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98109 - Principles of Music Therapy II Credits: 3 In Principles of Music Therapy II students will learn to interact with people who have learning, neurological, motor, and medical problems.  Students will need to focus on music therapy literature specific for this group of people and be ready to apply their theoretical studies to clinical work. Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98110 - Music Therapy Research Methods Credits: 3 This course will focus on research methods in conducting, reading, and interpreting music in the context of music therapy; it will include quantitative, qualitative, and mixed methodologies. Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98111 - Music Therapy Practicum II Credits: 1 This course will provide an opportunity for students to acquire supervised experience using music therapy, including assessment, treatment planning, evaluation, and other aspects that support clinical practice.  Students will complete a total of 60 supervised clinical hours as part of this course. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 98103 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: EXIN, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98112 - Clinical Piano Skills II Credits: 2 Further development of piano skills needed to implement music therapy in clinical settings.  Includes harmonization, accompanying in various styles, and various styles of improvisation.  Course includes application of musical concepts and terminologies, such as modes, idioms, styles, scales, and various musical forms into clinical scenarios.  Builds on material learned in Clinical Piano Skills I and includes additional applications to clinical settings. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 98105 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Music

CourseTitle: Music Applications to Music Therapy II
Description: MUS 98113 - Music Applications to Music Therapy II Credits: 1 This course will provide an opportunity for music therapy students to apply the music skills that they are learning in other courses (music and music therapy) to the type of musical situations that they will encounter as music therapists.  Skills to be practiced include leading songs using simple accompaniment styles, playing and singing songs of basic music therapy repertoire using Q-chord, autoharp, percussion instruments, and guitar, and sight reading basic music therapy repertoire. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 98107 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98115 - Music Therapy Practicum III Credits: 1 This course will provide an opportunity for students to acquire supervised experience using music therapy, including assessment, treatment planning, evaluation, and other aspects that support clinical practice.  Students will complete a total of 60 supervised clinical hours as part of this course. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 98111 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: EXIN, UGRD Academic Department: Music

CourseTitle: Music Applications to Music Therapy III
Description: MUS 98116 - Music Applications to Music Therapy III Credits: 1 This course will provide an opportunity for music therapy students to apply the music skills that they are learning in other courses (music and music therapy) to the type of musical situations that they will encounter as music therapists, refining their skills in these areas.  Skills to be practiced include leading songs using simple accompaniment styles, playing and singing songs of basic music therapy repertoire using Q-chord, autoharp, percussion instruments, guitar, and piano and keyboard, and sight reading basic music therapy repertoire. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 98113 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98117 - Residency in Music Therapy Credits: 2 Residency of 1040 hours at an AMTA-or Rowan-approved clinical training center.  Application is made upon departmental approval.  Development of music therapy clinical skills.  Requires clinical work and ongoing supervision from the clinical site (residency supervisor) and/or music therapy faculty.  Student will plan and lead individual and group music therapy sessions, write assessment and goal plans, participate in treatment teams, and take part in other activities of the clinical facility.  The residency should be taken at a medical facility. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 98101 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98108 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98102 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98109 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98110 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98103 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98111 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98115 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98105 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98112 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98106 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98107 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98113 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98116 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98104 with a minimum grade of D- and PSY 03200 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: EXIN, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98205 - Clinical Piano Skills I Credits: 2 Students learn piano skills needed to implement music therapy in clinical settings. Includes harmonization, accompanying in various styles, and various styles of improvisation. Course includes application of musical concepts and terminologies, such as modes, idioms, styles, scales, and various musical forms into clinical scenarios. Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98206 - Clinical Guitar Skills Credits: 2 This course is designed to enable students to accompany themselves and to lead others in the singing of simple folk and popular songs, progressing from simple strumming and finger picking to more advanced accompaniment patterns, transposition and the use of the capo. Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Music

CourseTitle: Recreative and Compositional Applications to Music Therapy
Description: MUS 98207 - Recreative and Compositional Applications to Music Therapy Credits: 1 This course will provide an opportunity for music therapy students to apply the music skills that they are learning in other courses (music and music therapy) to the type of musical situations that they will encounter as music therapists. This course will focus on recreative and compositional methods, including leading songs using simple accompaniment styles using various percussion and digital/electronic instruments, group singing, arranging songs for vocal and instrumental groups, and composing simple songs for clinical use. Course Attributes: P_C, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98208 - Psychology of Music Credits: 3 This course will provide an opportunity for students to learn about psychological foundations of music, including neurology and the brain, music cognition and perception, emotional meaning of music, musical development and learning, and testing for musical ability.  Students will be expected to apply the knowledge acquired in this course in music therapy, music education, and other musical interests. Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98212 - Clinical Piano Skills II Credits: 2 Further development of piano skills needed to implement music therapy in clinical settings.  Includes harmonization, accompanying in various styles, and various styles of improvisation.  Course includes application of musical concepts and terminologies, such as modes, idioms, styles, scales, and various musical forms into clinical scenarios.  Builds on material learned in Clinical Piano Skills I and includes additional applications to clinical settings. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 98205 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98213 - Receptive Applications to Music Therapy Credits: 1 This course will provide an opportunity for music therapy students to apply the music skills that they are learning in other courses (music and music therapy) to the type of musical situations that they will encounter as music therapists. Students will develop skills in selecting and providing live and recorded music experiences for a wide range of client needs, for the purposes of relaxation or facilitating nonmusical expression in a range of modalities. Course Attributes: P_C, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98301 - Principles of Music Therapy I Credits: 3 In Principles of Music Theory I students will learn to interact with people who have learning, neurological, motor, and medical problems. Students will need to focus on music therapy literature specific for this group of people and be ready to apply their theoretical studies to clinical work. Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98303 - Music Therapy Practicum I Credits: 1 This course will provide an opportunity for students to acquire supervised experience using music therapy, including assessment, treatment planning, evaluation, and other aspects that support clinical practice.  Students will complete a total of 60 supervised clinical hours as part of this course. Course Attributes: EXIN, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98307 - Improvisational Applications to Music Therapy Credits: 1 This course will provide an opportunity for music therapy students to apply the music skills that they are learning in other courses (music and music therapy) to the type of musical situations that they will encounter as music therapists, refining their skills in these areas. Students will develop skills in improvisational music experiences using instrumental and/or vocal improvisation, and with varying levels and kinds of structures to suit a wide range of client needs. Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98310 - Music Therapy Research Methods Credits: 3 This course will focus on research methods in conducting, reading, and interpreting music in the context of music therapy; it will include quantitative, qualitative, and mixed methodologies. Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98401 - Principles of Music Therapy II Credits: 3 In Principles of Music Therapy II students will learn to interact with people who have learning, neurological, motor, and medical problems. Students will need to focus on music therapy literature specific for this group of people and be ready to apply their theoretical studies to clinical work. Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98403 - Music Therapy Practicum II Credits: 1 This course will provide an opportunity for students to acquire supervised experience using music therapy, including assessment, treatment planning, evaluation, and other aspects that support clinical practice.  Students will complete a total of 60 supervised clinical hours as part of this course. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 98303 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: EXIN, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98404 - Music Therapy Practicum III Credits: 1 This course will provide an opportunity for students to acquire supervised experience using music therapy, including assessment, treatment planning, evaluation, and other aspects that support clinical practice. Students will complete a total of 60 supervised clinical hours as part of this course. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 98403 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: EXIN, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98406 - Advanced Clinical Guitar Skills Credits: 2 This course focuses on the use of acoustic guitar to accompany voice and the use of both to facilitate music therapy sessions by building on and reinforcing skills from Clinical Guitar Skills, and introducing them to more advanced material. This will include more complex strumming and fingerpicking patterns, more advanced chord progressions, and further development of clinical improvisation and composition techniques. Following review of some repertoire from Clinical Guitar Skills, new repertoire for use with children and adults including: pop, country, folk, blues, spirituals, jazz, and multicultural, will be introduced. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 98206 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98409 - Therapeutic Principles for Music Therapist Credits: 1 This course focuses on understanding of therapeutic principles and the therapeutic relationship that are at the basis of music therapy treatment.  Topics covered are foundational to music therapy, focusing on therapeutic principles underlying music therapy.  These include awareness of personal motivation and values in therapy, dynamics and process of the therapeutic relationship, awareness of ethical issues in therapy, group dynamics, multicultural awareness and applications to therapy, and theories underlying various approaches to therapy. Course Attributes: UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUS 98410 - Residency in Music Therapy Credits: 2 Residency of 1040 hours at an AMTA-or Rowan-approved clinical training center.  Application is made upon departmental approval. Development of music therapy clinical skills. Requires clinical work and ongoing supervision from the clinical site (residency supervisor) and/or music therapy faculty.  Student will plan and lead individual and group music therapy sessions, write assessment and goal plans, participate in treatment teams, and take part in other activities of the clinical facility.  The residency should be taken at a medical facility. Prerequisite Courses: MUS 98101 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98208 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98301 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98401 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98310 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98303 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98403 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98404 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98205 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98212 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98206 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98207 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98213 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98307 with a minimum grade of D- and MUS 98409 with a minimum grade of D- and PSY 03200 with a minimum grade of D- Course Attributes: EXIN, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUSG 05547 - Music and the Related Arts Credits: 3 The aesthetics of music is approached from the point of view that the same forces motivate all the arts and that significant parallels exist among them. This course may not be offered annually. Course Attributes: GCAT, GRAD Academic Department: Music

MUSG 06102 - General Music History Credits: 3 An introduction to styles and analysis of music through a historical overview. The techniques of listening and aural analysis of representative works serves as exercise material for the course. Course Attributes: ACE, ARTL, CAT, GNED, RE, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUSG 06109 - Music Appreciation Credits: 3 Music literature is approached through recordings, live performance and appropriate reading. Course Attributes: ACE, ARTL, CAT, GNED, RE, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUSG 06115 - Growth and Development of Jazz Credits: 3 African and European influences, the evolution of jazz styles and the influence of jazz on the musical world are covered. Course Attributes: ACE, ARTL, CAT, GNED, MCUL, RE, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUSG 06117 - Expressing Music Through Technology Credits: 3 The elements of music and the development of classical, jazz, and popular musics are studied through hands-on technology-based activities.  No prior musical or technology experience is necessary. Course Attributes: ACE, CAT, GNED, RE, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUSG 06120 - Keyboard Literature Credits: 3 The course is a survey of the important compositions written for keyboard instruments, primarily piano, from ca. l600 to the present. This course may not be offered annually. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

MUSG 06210 - Vocal Literature Credits: 3 A survey of solo vocal literature through these vocal periods:  Renaissance, Baroque, Classical, Romantic, Late Romantic and Contemporary.  Through lecture, demonstration and presentation, students will study the composers of each period, their body of work, style, interpretation and performance practice. Course Attributes: CAT, UGRD Academic Department: Music

CourseTitle: History and Literature of Western Music Repertories I
Description: MUSG 06214 - History and Literature of Western Music Repertories I Credits: 3 A study of the history of Western music from the Ancient Greeks until the mid-Baroque period. (Students who are not music majors must have the instructors permission to take this course.) Course Attributes: ACE, CAT, GNED, RE, UGRD Academic Department: Music

CourseTitle: History and Literature of Western Music Repertories II
Description: MUSG 06215 - History and Literature of Western Music Repertories II Credits: 3 A study of the history of Western music from the mid-Baroque period until the crisis of tonality. (Students who are not music majors must have the instructors permission to take this course.) Course Attributes: ACE, CAT, GNED, RE, UGRD Academic Department: Music
